questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient is diagnosed with gastric carcinoma. Which of the following is the best investigation to assess the depth of cancer in locally invasive gastric carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Endoscopic ultrasound is the best investigation to assess the depth of cancer in locally advanced gastric cancer.

Endoscopic ultrasound is the most sensitive investigation used to assess the preoperative local staging of gastric carcinoma. Five layers of the gastric wall can be visualized and the depth of invasion (T component of the staging) of cancer can be assessed with more than 90% accuracy. It can also show enlarged perigastric and celiac lymph nodes. In addition, it can identify liver metastases and assess gastric emptying. 

The limitation of this investigation is operator dependency and it may underestimate the lymph node involvement as normal-sized nodes (<5 mm) may harbor metastasis.

Other options:

Option A- MRI has a higher sensitivity in detecting liver metastasis of gastric carcinoma than conventional CT imaging.

Option B- CT scan of the abdomen/pelvis with intravenous and oral contrast is the best in preoperative staging of gastric cancer. However, it lacks sensitivity in detecting smaller lesions and is less accurate in T staging than endoscopic ultrasound.

Option C- Barium swallow is up to 75% sensitive in gastric tumors but has been replaced with endoscopic ultrasound in most centers as it is the gold standard for the diagnosis of gastric carcinoma.

Related Pearl: Risk factors for carcinoma stomach

Risk factors for carcinoma stomach:

  • Dietary
    • Low fat or protein consumption
    • Consumption of salted meat or fish with high nitrate content
    • High complex carbohydrate consumption
    • Smoking, alcohol consumption
    • Spicy food, high salt diet
    • Lack of fresh fruits and vegetables
    • Dietary anti-oxidant deficiency
  • Genetic and familial
    • E cadherin – hereditary diffuse type of gastric cancer
    • Blood group A
    • FAP
    • Li-Fraumeni syndrome
    • HNPCC
    • BRCA 2 mutation
  • Premalignant lesions
    • Chronic atrophic gastritis
    • Adenomatous polyp (FAP)
    • Pernicious anemia
    • Intestinal metaplasia (H. pylori)
    • Menetrier’s disease
    • Stump carcinoma from stomach remnants in Billroth II GJ or vagotomy GJ
  • Others
    • Low socioeconomic status
    • Male gender
    • Rubber and coal workers
    • EBV infection

Related Pearl: TNM staging of gastric carcinoma

TX

T0

Tis

Carcinoma in situ: intraepithelial tumor without invasion of the lamina propria

T1

T1b

questions.text: Jai Vigyan Mission Mode project is for community control of:
questions.solution:
Jai Vigyan Mission Mode project on community control of RF/RHD in India is being carried out with four main components:

  • To study the epidemiology of streptococcal sore throats
  • Establish registries for RF and RHD
  • Vaccine development for streptococcal infection
  • Conducting advanced studies on pathological aspects of RF and RHD

questions.text: A 30-year-old male patient presents to the emergency department with a history of acute breathlessness. On examination, there are soft heart sounds, JVP is increased, and an inspiratory decline in systolic blood pressure of 14 mmHg is observed. Which of the following statements about the condition is true?
questions.solution:
A 30-year-old male patient with acute breathlessness, falling BP, rising JVP, and soft heart sounds suggest a diagnosis of cardiac tamponade. In a cardiac tamponade, the ECG findings are low voltage and electrical alternans.

Cardiac tamponade:

Accumulation of fluid in the pericardial space raises the intrapericardial pressure, hence poor ventricular filling and fall in cardiac output.

It is characterized by:

  • Hypotension
  • Pulsus paradoxus
  • Increased pulse rate
  • Prominent X descent
  • Muffled heart sound
  • Ewart’s sign (bronchial breathing at left angle of scapula)
  • Beck’s triad: Falling BP, Raised JVP, Small quiet heart or soft heart sound.

Investigation:

  • X-ray chest - Big globular heart
  • ECG - Low voltage, Electrical alternans
  • ECHO - Echo free zone around the heart
  • Cath - Diastolic collapse of right atrium and right ventricle

Treatment: Drainage of fluid

Other options:

  • Option A: Kussmaul sign is a rise or a lack of fall in JVP with inspiration.It is not seen in cardiac tamponade.
  • Option C: y descent is attenuated or absent in cardiac tamponade because of limited or absent late diastolic filling of ventricle. Prominent x and y descent is seen in constrictive pericarditis.
  • Option D: The diastolic dip-and-plateau pattern, also known as a square root sign, is produced when early rapid diastolic inflow into the ventricle commences but is then abruptly halted by an opposing force. It is not seen in the cardiac tamponade.

questions.text: Which of the following is a component of the scheme depicted by the logo given below?
questions.solution:
National Health Protection Mission is a component of the Ayushman Bharat scheme.

Ayushman Bharat-National Health Protection Mission (AB-NHPM) aims to build a comprehensive need-based health care service and targets to build a 'New India 2022'. Its components are:

  • Creation of 1,50,000 Health and Wellness Centres- these centres will provide Comprehensive Primary Health Care (CPHC), covering both maternal and child health services and non-communicable diseases, including free essential drugs and diagnostic services. 
  • National Health Protection Mission (NHPM) provides health protection cover to poor and vulnerable families, screening for non-communicable diseases, and follow-up of hospitalization cases among others.

Beneficiary Level: 

  • The government provides health insurance cover of up to Rs. 5,00,000 per family per year.
  • All families listed in the Socio-Economic Caste Census (SECC) database as per defined criteria will be covered. No cap on family size and age of members.
  • Priority to a girl child, women, and senior citizens.
  • Free treatment is available at all public and empanelled private hospitals in times of need.
  • Covers secondary and tertiary care hospitalization.
  • 1,350 medical packages covering surgery, medical and daycare treatments, cost of medicines, and diagnostics.
  • All pre-existing diseases are covered. Hospitals cannot deny treatment.
  • Cashless and paperless access to quality health care services.
  • Hospitals will not be allowed to charge any additional money from beneficiaries for the treatment.
  • Can reach out for information, assistance, complaints, and grievances to a 24X7 helpline number.

Ayushman Bharat Diwas is being celebrated across the country on April 30.

questions.text: Inferior pancreaticoduodenal artery is a branch of
questions.solution:
Inferior pancreatico-duodenal artery is a branch of superior mesenteric artery.

On the other hand, the superior pancreatico-duodenal artery is a branch of the gastroduodenal artery. 

 

The main vessels supplying the duodenum are superior and inferior pancreaticoduodenal arteries.

questions.text: Osborn J waves are not seen in :
questions.solution:
Osborn J waves are not seen in hyperkalemia.

Osborn J waves are the distinctive convex elevations of the J point as seen in the image.

It consists of an extra deflection on the ECG at the terminal junction of the QRS complex and the beginning of the ST-segment takeoff.

  • Usually, it occurs when the core body temperature falls below 90°F (32°C), seen in conditions such as hypothermia (option A) secondary to severe hypothyroidism (option B)
  • Results from an exaggerated outward potassium current leading to repolarization abnormality
  • They can also be found in other conditions, such as hypercalcemia (option C)
  • Other causes include brain injury, subarachnoid hemorrhage, cardiopulmonary arrest from oversedation, vasospastic angina, and idiopathic ventricular fibrillation

Related Pearl: Normal ECG waves and intervals

ECG wave/interval

Physiological correlates

P wave

Atrial depolarization

QRS complex (up to 0.10s)

Ventricular depolarization

T wave

Ventricular repolarization

U wave

Repolarization of ventricular myocytes with long action potential

PR interval  (0.12-0.2s) 

Atrial depolarization and conduction through AV node

QT interval  (up to 0.43s)

Ventricular depolarization and Ventricular repolarization

ST interval (Average 0.32s)

(QT minus QRS)

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential+ Ventricular repolarisation

ST segment

Plateau portion of ventricular action potential

questions.text: Pin index given for oxygen gas under pin index system is _________
questions.solution:
Pin index system for oxygen gas is 2, 5.

Pin index safety system(PISS) is a safety measure to prevent incorrect cylinder attachment.

Related Pearl: Pin index safety system (PISS):

Note:

  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with more than 7% CO2: 1,6
  • Mixtures of CO2 and O2 with less than 7% CO2: 2,6

questions.text: A 75-year-old man, who has been frequently misplacing his spectacles, becomes agitated and started shouting at his son, who criticized him for not keeping his spectacles in the same place. In spite of consoling, the old man keeps on accusing his son and starts crying. Condition showing this phenomenon will not show ______________
questions.solution:
The above phenomenon is known as catastrophic reaction which is a feature of dementia. Apraxia, aphasia and agnosia are seen in dementia. Abreaction is not seen.

From the history – Age and the frequent misplacing of spectacles (Anterograde memory loss) point more towards dementia.

Some patients with dementia exhibit catastrophic reactions when confronted with their cognitive limitations or when facing changes in routine or environment. They over react to trivial setback or a minor criticism and become agitated, scream, shout or accuse other people for no reason.

Abreaction: A therapeutic process by which a painful experience or conflict, is brought back to consciousness. During the process, the person recalls and also relives the experience. It is accompanied by an appropriate emotional response. Insight usually results from the experience.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about Pheochromocytoma?

choices.text: Definitive diagnosis of malignancy is based on metastasis

questions.solution:
Definitive diagnosis of malignancy in pheochromocytomas is based on presence of metastasis. Capsular and vascular invasion, cellular pleomorphism, may be seen in some benign forms of Pheochromocytoma.

Malignant form is more common in tumors arising in extra adrenal site than adrenal site.

Pheochromocytoma is associated with:

  • MEN-2
  • Familial paraganglioma syndrome
  • Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome
  • Neurofibromatosis type 1

 

Note: Pheochromocytoma is commonly associated with MEN2 (seen in 50% individuals). However rare association with MEN1(0-3%) can also be seen.

questions.text: An individual will not shed the infectious organism in ______
questions.solution:
Latent infection refers to a state in which the infectious agent remains dormant within the host without symptoms and the host does not shed the organism.

Carriers of a disease and cases with subclinical infections, in most conditions, shed the organism.

Elements of a carrier state:

  • Presence of disease agent in the body
  • Absence of recognizable symptoms and signs of the disease
  • Shedding of the disease agent in the discharges or excretions, thus acting as a source of infection for other persons.

questions.text: Services provided by the establishment bearing the following logo is  ________
questions.solution:
The given logo is of Suraksha clinics, where color-coded STI/RTI (sexually transmitted infections/Reproductive tract infections) kits are provided.

The NACO has branded the STI/RTI services as Suraksha Clinic and it has developed a communication strategy for generating demand for these services.

The kits are:

  • Kit 1– grey, for urethra discharge, anorectal discharge, and cervicitis
  • Kit 2 – green, for vaginitis
  • Kit 3 – white, for genital ulcers
  • Kit 4 – blue, for genital ulcers
  • Kit 5 – red, for genital ulcers
  • Kit 6 – yellow, for lower abdominal pain
  • Kit 7 – black, for inguinal bubo

Note: Anti retroviral therapy is given at ART centres under the National Aids Control Program- IV.

Related Pearl: Syndromic Management of Sexually Transmitted Infections

Partner Management when asymptomatic is not required for Gardenella vaginalis, Candida and Herpes infections.

questions.text: Embolism of the circumflex branch of the left coronary artery would result in ischemia of which of the following areas of the heart?

questions.solution:

questions.text: The eukaryotic initiation factor (eIF) that helps in cap binding is?
questions.solution:
The eukaryotic initiation factor (eIF) that helps in cap binding is eIF 4.

eIF are accessory proteins that help initiate protein synthesis.

Functions of eIF:

  • eIF3 & eIF 1A: First step of initiation involves dissociation of the ribosome into its 40S and 60S subunits. eIF3 & eIF 1A bind to newly dissociated 40s ribosomal subunit and hence delays the association of 40s and 60s.
  • eIF2: It is involved in the formation of binary complex (GTP+eIF). This complex binds to met t RNA. Further, the GTP-eIF-2-tRNAi ternary complex binds to the 40S ribosomal subunit to form the 43S preinitiation complex. This is the second step of initiation.
  • eIF4: It forms the cap binding complex.  It binds to 5′ terminal of mRNA molecules which are capped. The mRNA would then bind to the 43S preinitiation complex to form the 48S initiation complex, in the third step of initiation.
  • eIF5: It is involved in the hydrolysis of GTP bound to eIF2. This results in binding of 60s subunit with 48s initiation complex to form the 80s initiation complex. This is the fourth step of initiation.

questions.text: A pregnant lady acquires chicken pox 2 days prior to delivery. She delivers by normal vaginal route. Which of the following statements in her case is true ?

choices.text: Both mother and baby are safe
Give antiviral treatment to mother intrapartum
Give antiviral treatment to baby immediately after birth
Baby will develop neonatal varicella syndrome

questions.solution:
Baby will develop neonatal varicella syndrome.

The severity of neonatal infection is inversely related to the concentration of maternal antibodies present in the newborn circulation. The mother starts producing and transferring antibodies approximately five days after the onset of her disease. Thus babies born 5 days or more from the beginning of maternal disease will be protected.

Varicella zoster IG is recommended for neonates whose mothers develop VZV rash from five days before delivery up to two days after delivery. Neonates born before or after this time probably do not need passive immunization because they are not at risk of severe neonatal chickenpox.

If signs of neonatal infection develop despite VZIG, then the neonate should be treated with acyclovir.

Antiviral treatment should be started in a neonate exposed to varicella when there is a disseminated disease( pneumonia, encephalitis, thrombocytopenia and severe hepatitis)

questions.text: The egg given in the image below belongs to ___.
questions.solution:
The egg in the image above belongs to Schistosoma haematobium.

Points in favor: Ovoid, about 150 μm by 50 μm, non-operculated, with a brownish-yellow transparent shell carrying a terminal spine at one pole. The terminal spine is characteristic of the species.

Species differentiation of Schistosoma is based on the location of the spine:

  • Terminal spine: S. haematobium
  • Lateral spine: S. mansoni
  • Rudimentary spine: S. japonicum

The illustration given below shows the life cycle of schistosomes with the intermediate snail host.

Related Pearl: Eggs of Schistosoma

questions.text: Which among the following about cidofovir is not true?

choices.text: Hepatotoxicity is the principle side effect

questions.solution:
Hepatotoxicity is not the principle side effect of cidofovir. Nephrotoxicity is the principle dose-limiting side effect.

Cidofovir is metabolized to its active diphosphate form by cellular enzymes. Cidofovir inhibits viral DNA synthesis by slowing and eventually terminating chain elongation.

It has very low oral bioavailability and is administered intravenously.

It has been used for treating:

  • CMV retinitis in HIV-infected patients
  • Acyclovir-resistant mucocutaneous HSV infection
  • Adenovirus disease in transplant recipients
  • Extensive molluscum contagiosum in HIV patients

questions.text: The drug cevimeline acts on which receptor for the expulsion of the secretions from the salivary gland?
questions.solution:
Cevimeline is a muscarinic agonist with affinity for both M1 and M3 receptors on the lacrimal and salivary glands.

While M1 activation results in increased secretion, M3 activation results in smooth muscle contraction and expulsion of the secretions.

Cevimeline has a long-lasting sialogogic action and may have fewer side effects than pilocarpine.

Cevimeline enhances lacrimal secretions in Sjögren’s syndrome. The usual dose is 30 mg three times daily.

questions.text: In the formula for urea clearance, C = U × V/P,  U denotes

choices.text: Concentration of urea in gm/24 hour
Concentration of urea in urine in mg/ml
Concentration of urea in blood in mg/ml

questions.solution:
In the formula for urea clearance, C=U × V/P , U denotes concentration of urea in urine mg/ml.

Renal clearance is the volume of plasma completely cleared of a substance by the kidneys per unit time.

  • It is calculated by the formula:

C = Clearance (mL/min)

[U]x = Urine concentration of substance x (mg/mL)

V= Urine flow rate per minute (mL/min)

[P]x = Plasma concentration of substance x (mg/mL)

questions.text: Paralysis of 3rd, 4th, 6th nerves with the involvement of ophthalmic division of 5th nerve, localizes the lesion to:

choices.text: Apex of the orbit and Cavernous sinus
Cavernous sinus and Superior orbital fissure
Cavernous sinus and Inferior orbital fissure

questions.solution:
Based on the contents, cavernous sinus lesion and superior orbital fissure lesion may be associated with paralysis of 3rd, 4th, 5th (ophthalmic division)  & 6th nerve.

Direct content of Cavernous Sinus:

  • Internal carotid artery and
  • Abducent nerve.

Structures in the lateral wall:

  • Oculomotor nerve
  • Trochlear nerve
  • Ophthalmic nerve

Superior orbital fissure is divided into three compartments by the common tendinous ring.

Compartments

Contents

Superolateral compartments

Lacrimal, frontal and trochlear nerve (LFT). Superior ophthalmic vein

Intermediate compartment

Superior and inferior division of oculomotor, Nasociliary nerve, Abducent nerve

Inferomedial compartment

Inferior ophthalmic vein

 

Related Pearl: Superior orbital fissure

Structures passing through the Superior orbital fissure

Above the common tendinous ring: LFT (Superolateral compartment)

  • Lacrimal nerve
  • Frontal nerve
  • Trochlear nerve
  • Superior opthalmic vein

Within the common tendinous ring: BAN (Intermediate compartment)

  • Both divisions of oculomotor nerve
  • Abducens nerve
  • Nasociliary nerve

Below the common tendinous ring (Inferomedial compartment)

  • Inferior ophthalmic vein

questions.text: Suresh, a 30-year-old male has a history of major depressive disorder with psychotic symptoms. He came to OPD with history of delusions and hallucinations for the last 2 weeks; his mood has been normal in the same duration. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Presentation with psychotic symptoms (delusions and hallucinations) with the absence of mood symptoms in a patient with a history of major depressive disorder with psychotic symptoms, is consistent with schizoaffective disorder.

Schizoaffective disorder:

DSM-5 criteria:

  • A continuous period of illness with mood symptoms concurrent with psychotic symptoms.
  • Presence of more than 2 weeks of delusions or hallucinations in absence of mood symptoms.
  • Mood symptoms present for the majority of total illness.
  • Not due to substances or another medical condition.

Differential diagnosis:

  • Major depressive or bipolar disorder with psychotic features: Psychotic symptoms occur exclusively during mood episodes
  • Schizophrenia: Mood symptoms are absent or present for only brief periods

Note: According to DSM -5 guidelines, for a definitive diagnosis of schizoaffective disorder, there has to be two psychotic episodes. One of the psychotic episodes, has to be concurrent with a severe affective (depression or manic) episode. The other psychotic episode should be for two or more weeks in the abscence of affective symptoms. And affective symptoms should dominate the major part during the life time course of the illness.

Accoridng to ICD-10 Schizoaffective disorder should only be diagnosed when both definite schizophrenic and definite affective symptoms are prominent simultaneously, or within a few days of each other, within the same episode of illness, and when, as a consequence of this, the episode of illness does not meet criteria for either schizophrenia or a depressive or manic episode.

Related Pearl: Psychotic disorders

Differential diagnosis of DSM-5 psychotic disorders

Psychotic disorder

 Criteria for diagnosis
Brief psychotic disorder

Sudden onset and a full return to function

Duration: > 1 day and < 1 month
Schizophreniform disorder

Same symptoms as schizophrenia and functional decline not required

Duration: > 1 month & < 6 months
Schizophrenia

Requires functional decline

At least 6 months (includes at least 1 month of active symptoms, can include prodromal and residual periods)
Schizoaffective disorder

With concurrent mood episode. Active-phase symptoms of schizophrenia with at least a 2 weeks of lifetime history of delusions or hallucinations in absence of prominent mood symptoms
Delusional disorder

One or more delusions for > 1 month

No other psychotic symptoms and normal functioning apart from the direct impact of delusions
Shared psychotic disorder (folie a deux)

Development of delusions in a person who is in a close relationship (ex: spouse, child) with someone who has a delusional disorder (the inducer)

questions.text: Incorrect match about nuclei and functional columns is
questions.solution:
Cranial nerve with parasympathetic function consists of 3,7,9,10 cranial nerves.

Functional Columns and Nuclei of Cranial Nerve:

Sulcus limitans divide the mantle zone of the brain stem and spinal cord into anterior motor efferent BASAL plate and posterior sensory afferent alar plate.

Sensory component form in dorsal alar plate and motor component in ventral basal plate.

Efferent

Afferent

General somatic efferent

  • Supply striated muscles
  • III, IV, VI and XII.

General somatic afferent 

  • Carry general sensation
  • Chief sensory, spinal nucleus and mesencephalic nucleus of trigeminal nerve

Special visceral efferent

  • Pharyngeal arch muscles
  • V, VII, IX, X, XI
  • Nucleus ambiguus - fibers from IX, X and XI mingle

Special somatic afferent

  • Carry special sensation
  • I, II and VIII

General visceral efferent – (parasympathetic)

  • Supply the glands and smooth muscles
  • III, VII, IX and X.

General visceral afferent

  • Carry general sensation from viscera (heart, lung, git)

 

Special visceral afferent

  • Carry special sensation taste from tongue
  • Nucleus of solitary tract (VII, IX and X)

 

NUCLEUS AMBIGUUS

  • Elongated motor neuron extending throughout the medulla
  • It is not clearly defined in sections of medulla hence the name
  • Occupies position dorsal to inferior olivary nucleus
  • Fibres from this nucleus mingle with IX, X, XI A and emerge in the posterolateral sulcus of medulla.
  • These fibres supply the muscles derived from III, IV & VI arch

NUCLEUS TRACTUS SOLITARIUS

  • Situated in medulla
  • Rostral part of nucleus is concerned with taste sensation and receives afferent fibres from VII, IX & X and referred to gustatory nucleus
  • The caudal part of nucleus receives general visceral sensation
  • Axons from this nucleus to the thalamus and hypothalamus through solitariothalamic and solitariohypothalamic tract
  • Then these fibres join the medial lemniscus of the opposite side on their way to thalamus and hypothalamus
  • The neurons from thalamus then project to the cerebral cortex

questions.text: False about malignant melanoma of choroid is_______

choices.text: Originates from inner layer of choroid

questions.solution:
Malignant melanoma of choroid arises from the outer layers of the choroid.

It forms at first a lens-shaped mass, raising the retina over it. As it grows, it stretches the elastic membrane of Bruch, which finally ruptures.

The cells are usually spindle-shaped. They may also be cylindrical or palisade-like, arranged in columns or around blood vessels, or even resemble endothelial cells in appearance.

Classified by cell type as:

  • Spindle A—predominance of slender spindles with a flattened nucleus and no nucleolus.
  • Spindle B—predominance of larger spindles with round/oval nucleus and prominent nucleolus.
  • Epithelioid—large cells with nuclei that are round and eccentric. There is a high mitotic figure count.
  • Mixed type

The lymph nodes are not commonly affected, but metastases occur abundantly in the liver.

questions.text: Histology under KOH preparation showed the following bodies. This is seen in case of _________
questions.solution:
The image shows medlar bodies which are seen in chromoblastomycosis.

Histologically on potassium hydroxide preparation, the lesions show the presence of the fungus as round, irregular, dark brown, yeast like bodies with septae called sclerotic bodies/ medlar bodies/ copper penny bodies. These structures multiply by septation, and they induce a purulent and granulomatous inflammatory reaction in tissue.

Chromoblastomycosis is the most common form of chromomycosis, which is a chronic fungal infection of the skin and the subcutaneous tissue caused by dematiaceous (pigmented) fungi.

The M/C fungi responsible are species of the genera Fonsecaea (Fonsecaea pedrosoi or Fonsecaea compacta).

questions.text: The secretion of breast milk is ________
questions.solution:
Mammary gland cells secrete milk protein casein by merocrine secretion. Milk lipid is secreted by apocrine secretion.

Types of glands: 

  • Exocrine 
  • Endocrine 

Exocrine glands: The secretions are initially packaged into membrane-bound vesicles. These are then conveyed to the cell surface.

  • Merocrine: It is the most common type. Vesicles fuse with the plasma membrane and secrete on the surface. e.g. sweat glands, protein in mammary gland, pancreas, salivary gland.
  • Apocrine: Apical portion is pinched off for secretion. e.g. milk fat in the mammary gland, atypical sweat glands, ceruminous glands, glands of Moll.
  • Holocrine: Entire gland disintegrates to liberate secretion. e.g. sebaceous gland.
  • Eccrine: Active transportation from plasma as exudate. E.g., previously sweat gland was eccrine, now moved under merocrine.

Endocrine glands: Direct secretion into connective tissue interstitium and then into the circulation.

Related Pearl: Various Types of Exocrine Glands with Examples

Simple gland: All the secretory cells of an exocrine gland discharge into one duct.

Compound gland: There are a number of groups of secretory cells, each group discharging into its own duct. These ducts unite to form larger ducts that ultimately drain on to an epithelial surface.

In both simple and compound glands, the secretory cells may be arranged in various ways.

  1. The secretory element may be tubular. The tube may be straight, coiled, or branched.
  2. The cells may form rounded sacs or acini.
  3. They may form flask shaped structures called alveoli.

questions.text: When blood samples are taken for measurement of glucose, glycolysis is inhibited by taking the sample into tubes containing fluoride. This is due to the inhibition of _________
questions.solution:
Glycolysis is inhibited due to the presence of fluoride in the test tube, since fluoride inhibits enolase enzyme. Inhibition of glycolyis prevents measurement of blood glucose to be falsely estimated as low.

Inhibitors of glycolytic enzymes:

  • Iodoacetate: It inhibits Glyceraldehyde 3 PO4 dehydrogenase. Thus conversion of glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate to 1,3 bisphosphoglycerate is inhibited.
  • Arsenate: It inhibits 1,3 bisphosphoglycerate kinase. 1,3 bisphosphoglycerate kinase converts  1,3 bisphosphoglycerate to 3 phosphoglycerate. Arsenate competes with inorganic phosphate (Pi) in this reaction to give 1-arseno-3-phosphoglycerate which undergoes spontaneous hydrolysis to 3-phosphoglycerate without forming ATP.
  • Fluoride: It inhibits enolase enzyme which is responsible for conversion of 2-phosphoglycerate to phosphoenolpyruvate.

questions.text: A patient with radiologically confirmed reflux nephropathy develops nephrotic-range proteinuria. What is the most likely cause?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of nephrotic syndrome due to a secondary cause (reflux nephropathy). Secondary nephrotic syndrome in adults is most likely due to focal segmental glomerulosclerosis (FSGS).

FSGS is the most common cause of nephrotic syndrome in adults. It is a podocytopathy, with degeneration and focal disruption of visceral epithelial cells and effacement of foot processes. Glomerular hyalinosis and sclerosis are seen due to the entrapment of plasma proteins and increased extracellular matrix deposition.

FSGS is classified as follows:

  • Primary
    • Idiopathic FSGS
  • Secondary
    • HIV associated
    • Heroin addiction
    • Sickle cell disease
    • Obesity
    • Hypertensive nephropathy
    • Renal conditions
      • Focal glomerulonephritis (e.g. IgA nephropathy)
      • Renal ablation
      • Unilateral renal agenesis or renal dysplasia
      • Reflux nephropathy
  • Inherited
    • Mutated proteins of the slit diaphragm - podocin, alpha-actinin 4, TRPC6

Electron microscopy of FSGS shows: 

  • Diffuse effacement of the podocyte foot processes
  • Focal detachment and degeneration of the epithelial cells
  • Absence of electron-dense deposits

questions.text: Which of the following  is a mTOR pathway inhibitor for the treatment of metastatic hormone receptor positive, HER 2 negative breast cancer:

Everolimus is a mTOR (Mammalian target of rapamycin inhibitors) pathway inhibitor recently approved for treatment of metastatic hormone receptor positive, HER 2 negative breast cancer.

Treatment of metastatic breast cancer by targeting PI3k/AKT/mTOR pathways has led to newer chemotherapeutic drugs, which are as follows:

mTOR pathway inhibitors

Phophatidyl-inositol 3 kinase (PI3k) inhibitors

  • Buparlisib – Not approved, but trials are underway for treatment of metastatic breast carcinoma

AKT (Protein kinase B) inhibitors

  • Ipatasertib: Not approved, but found beneficial for metastatic triple-negative breast cancer

questions.text: Among the water-soluble radiological contrasts, Iodine: particle ratio is highest in?
questions.solution:
Non ionic dimers have highest iodine particle ratio of 6:1.

Contrast agents can be divided into water-soluble (iodine-containing) and non-water-soluble (barium) compounds.

Classification of iodinated contrast:

  • Ionic – Monomer and dimer
  • Non ionic– Monomer and dimer

Ionic monomer has Iodine: particle ratio of 3:2. They have an osmolarity of 1400-1600 mOsm. Ionic monomers are not preferred due to high osmolarity. They have advantages of forming better images in IVP and having anticoagulant property. Examples are:

  • Urograffin – Sodium/Meglumine diatrizoate
  • Conray – Iothalamate

Ionic dimer has Iodine: particle ratio of 6:2 or 3:1 and osmolality of 600-800 mOsm. Ioxaglate is an example. Dye has retained its anticoagulant property despite a low osmolarity.

Non-ionic monomer has Iodine: particle ratio of 3:1 and osmolarity of 600 – 800 mOsm.  Examples are:

  • Iohexol (Omnipaque) - commonly used
  • Ioversol (Optiray)
  • Iopamidol

Non-ionic Dimer has particle ratio of 6:1. The osmolarity is 300 mOsm, hence it is iso-osmolar to plasma. e.g Iodixanol

questions.text: Sulfonylurea therapy, which is used to treat type 2 diabetes mellitus, can also be useful in _________
questions.solution:
Sulfonylurea therapy is most useful in maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY) and Type 2 DM.

Maturity-onset diabetes of the young (MODY):

  • Autosomal-dominant form of Type 2 diabetes mellitus affecting the younger population. Onset of diabetes is seen after 30 years but less than 50 years. It is associated with cystic kidneys.
  • Definite positive family history is present.
  • Impaired Glucose-induced insulin secretion.
  • MODY 3 is the most common form.
  • It is a monogenic diabetes i.e only one gene mutation is present.
    • Types 1,3,5: HNF Mutation – Hepatocyte nuclear transcription factor
    • Type 2: Glucokinase mutation
    • Type 4: Insulin Promotor Factor-1 (IPF 1) mutation
  • There is insulinopenia with no antibodies and no insulin resistance.
  • The patient does not have obesity, hypertension or hyperlipidemia
  • Responds to sulfonylureas: OHA

Other options:

  • Option c: Wolfram syndrome is an autosomal recessive neurodegenerative disorder first evident in childhood. It consists of diabetes insipidus, diabetes mellitus, optic atrophy, and deafness. Hence the acronym DIDMOAD. It is due to mutations in a gene named WFS I , which encodes a transmembrane protein localized in the endoplasmic reticulum. Cranial diabetes insipidus and sensorineural deafness develop during the second decade in 60-75% of patients.
  • Option d: Non obese LADA is slow onset type 1 diabetes.There will be complete damage to pancreas however the damage is slow and delayed but presents by 30 years as opposed to second decade in Type 1 diabetes. Patients with LADA should be prescribed insulin when the disease is diagnosed and treated like patients with type l diabetes.

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient with a past history of cryptorchidism presented with a scrotal mass.  Scrotal skin was normal.  Ultrasonography confirmed testicular carcinoma. Which of the following group of lymph nodes are unlikely to be involved in this condition?
questions.solution:
The inguinal group of lymph nodes are only affected in testicular carcinoma if the scrotal skin is involved.

The following groups of lymph nodes are involved in the lymphatic drainage of testes:

  • Right testis- inter-aortocaval nodes ---> pre-aortic and para-aortic nodes 
  • Left testis- pre-aortic and para-aortic noes ---> inter-aortocaval nodes
  • Scrotal skin- inguinal nodes ---> external iliac nodes ---> common iliac nodes
  • Retroperitoneal lymph nodes

Seminoma is the most common type of germ cell tumour and it commonly occurs in patients with a history of cryptorchidism. It is the testicular equivalent of an ovarian dysgerminoma. Immunohistochemistry is positive for KIT, OCT3/4, and placental alkaline phosphatase (PLAP). 

Patients usually present with painless testicular enlargement. Heaviness may be felt if the size is 2-3 times normal. Rarely, it may present with symptoms of metastatic disease.

The gross specimen shows a homogeneous, grey-white, lobulated cut surface, devoid of haemorrhage or necrosis.

questions.text: An elderly lady presented to the clinic following a head injury. She exhibited an unsteady drunk-like gait while entering the examination room. She also had nodding movements of the head and nystagmus. Which region of the cerebellum marked in the following image was most likely affected by the bleed?
questions.solution:
Area marked as 4 is most likely affected by the bleed, i.e., vestibulocerebellum (or flocculonodular lobe).

Cerebellum has three parts based on function.

  • Vestibulocerebellum (or flocculonodular lobe): This lobe is the oldest part of the cerebellum. It has vestibular connections concerned with equilibrium and eye movements. Therefore, in lesions of the flocculonodular lobe, patients will have gait ataxia, nodding of the head and axial body (known as titubation), and nystagmus.
  • Spinocerebellum: This is the region that receives proprioceptive inputs from the body as well as from the motor cortex. By comparing plan from the motor cortex with performance, it smoothens and coordinates movements that are ongoing.
  • Cerebrocerebellum: This is the newest part of the cerebellum. They coordinate with the motor cortex in planning and programming movements. Patients will have dysmetria, dysarthria, dysdiadochokinesis, hypotonia, or intention tremor in one or both extremities. 

Lesions in the cerebellum may present with the following symptoms:

  • Wide-based, drunk-like unsteady, stumbling gait, which is also called staggering gait
  • Ataxia - Defects in movement and coordination
  • Dysdiadokinesia - Inability to perform alternating movements (e.g. supination, pronation) at a fast pace
  • Dysequilibrium - Loss of balance
  • Nystagmus
  • Intention tremor - This tremor is not present during rest, but is present during voluntary movements of limbs. The tremor increases when it reaches the target object of its movement.
  • Speech - Slurred or scanning
  • Hypotonia

Related Pearl: Functional divisions of the cerebellum

  Dorsal Spinocerebellum Ventral Spinocerebellum Cerebrocerebellum (neocerebellum) Vestibulocerebellum (flocculonodular lobe) 
Constituents Vermis (except the nodulus) The adjacent medial portion of the hemisphere The lateral portion of hemispheres Nodulus and flocculus 
Afferent (input) Somatosensory from the trunk, visual, auditory, and vestibular Somatosensory input from the limbs From the cerebral motor cortex, premotor, and somatosensory cortex  Vestibular input, visual input, somatosensory from the neck
Efferent (output) Via Fastigial nucleus to the medial descending system Via interposed nucleus to lateral corticospinal and rubrospinal systems Via dentate nucleus to motor, premotor and prefrontal cortex  To vestibular nuclei in the brain stem (direct projection)
Functions    

Maintains posture and helps in the execution of gross movements

It controls the interplay between agonist and antagonist group of muscles

 Controls the  distal muscles of the limbs (smoothens and coordinates movements) Planning the sequence of voluntary movements    

 Participates in maintaining equilibrium and posture

 

Controls ocular movements

It is responsible for regulating the stability of the head and body in space

questions.text: Which of the following occupies the interval between the renal fascia and the anterior layer of the thoracolumbar fascia?
questions.solution:
Paranephric fat is the outermost covering among the following which occupies the interval between the renal fascia and the anterior layer of the thoracolumbar fascia.

The 4 coverings of the kidney from inwards to outwards are as follows:

  • True capsule (Fibrous capsule): It is formed by the condensation of the fibrous stroma of the kidney
  • False capsule (Peri-nephric or Peri-renal capsule): It consists of fat and occupies the space between the fibrous capsule and the renal fascia.
  • Renal fascia
  • Para-nephric/Para-renal fat 

Clinical significance:

Perinephric fascia of Gerota (or false capsule) is important in staging renal cell carcinoma in perirenal space (Perirenal space is bound by Perirenal facia, Pararenal fat is outside perirenal space).

questions.text: According to the national framework for malaria elimination in India, states were categorized based on ______.
questions.solution:
The annual parasite index (API) is used to categorize states/union territories under the national framework for malaria elimination in India.

The national framework for malaria elimination in India was launched in February 2016 with the following goals:

  • Eliminate malaria throughout the entire country by 2030
  • Maintain malaria-free status in areas where transmission has been interrupted and prevent re-introduction

It uses the annual parasite index to classify states/union territories into four categories.

  • Category 0 (Prevention of re-establishment phase): States/union territories with zero cases
  • Category 1 (Elimination phase): States/union territories with all their districts having API <1
  • Category 2 (pre-elimination phase): States/union territories with API <1, but some of their districts having API≥1
  • Category 3 (Intensified control phase): States/union territories with API≥1

API is calculated by the formula: confirmed cases during one year X 1000 / population under surveillance.

Regions with API≥ 2 are considered as high-risk areas and are eligible for vector control.

Other options:

Option B: Slide positivity rate is used to describe the percentage of slides positive for the malarial parasite. The type of species is not taken into account.

Option C: Slide falciparum rate is the percentage of slides that are positive for Plasmodium falciparum species. 

Option D: Annual blood examination rate is derived by the formula - number of slides examined X 100/ Population. It is considered an index of operational efficiency.

 

 

Related Pearl: Malaria in the National Vector Borne Disease Control Programme (NVBDCP)

National Framework for Malaria Elimination in India (2016-2030)

  • Goals: To eliminate malaria and maintain malaria-free status.
  • Objectives:
    • By 2022, transmission of malaria interrupted and zero indigenous cases.
    • By 2024, incidence of malaria to be reduced to <1 case per 1000 population.
    • By 2030, malaria to be eliminated throughout the country.

Classification of states/UTs according to the Annual Parasite Index (API):

 

Category  Criteria  Major measures:
Category 0  States/UTs with zero indigenous cases  Detect re-introduced cases and notify and maintain malaria-free status. 
Category 1  Elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 and all their districts reporting API <1  Interruption of local transmission.
Category 2  Pre-elimination phase – States/UTs with API <1 but some districts reporting API ≥1. 

Screening. 

Setting up one-stop mobile centres/clinics. 

 
Category 3  Intensified control phase – States/UTs with API ≥1.   Same as category 2

 

  • The National Strategic Plan (NSP) for Malaria Elimination (2017-22) was launched by the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare under NVBDCP, which is based on the National Framework for Malaria Elimination (2016 – 2030).
  • The NSP focuses mainly on the districts which function as the operational units.

Accordingly, all the districts are classified into the following four categories:

Category of districts Definition
Category 0: Prevention of re-establishment phase  Includes all districts in which no incidence of malaria was reported in the last 3 years.
Category 1: Elimination phase  Districts with API <1 per 1000 population.
Category 2: Pre elimination phase  Districts with API in between 1-2 per 1000 population.
Category 3: Intensified control phase  Districts with API >2 per 1000 population.

The above classification is more operational than the classification mentioned in the NFME which is state focussed.

The goal of NSP strategy is the phased elimination of malaria in India. The National Framework for Malaria Elimination (NFME) in India has set 2030 as the goal for eliminating malaria, and the goals of NSP in consonance with overall goals.

The goals of NSP 2017 – 2022 are:

  • Eliminate malaria in category 1 (API < 1) districts by 2020, and category 2 (API 1-2) districts by 2022.
  • Reduce transmission in category 3 districts to stabilize API at <1 by 2022.

 

Related Pearl: Responsibilities of Health Workers

questions.text: Most common type of pelvis associated with deep transverse arrest is?
questions.solution:
The most common type of pelvis associated with deep transverse arrest is an android pelvis, especially due to its progressive narrowing. 

Pelvis and their most common associations:

  • Deep tranverse arrest : Android
  • Face to pubes delivery : Anthropoid
  • Occipito- posterior position : Android
  • Direct occipito-posterior / persistent occipito-posterior : Anthropoid

questions.text: A 9-year-old boy has swelling of knee joints and non-blanching rashes as seen in the picture. Urine exam reveals haematuria +++ and proteinuria +. Platelet levels are normal. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing swelling of knee joints (arthritis), non-blanching rash in the lower limbs (palpable purpura), along with hematuria and proteinuria (renal involvement) in a child is suggestive of Henoch Schonlein purpura (HSP).

HSP (IgA vasculitis) is a small vessel vasculitis most commonly seen in the age group of 3-8 years. It generally follows an upper respiratory tract infection and there is a history of atopy in one-third of the cases.

The pathology of HSP involves leukocytoclastic vasculitis and the deposition of IgA in the affected blood vessels. IgA is deposited in the glomerular mesangium in a distribution similar to that of IgA nephropathy.

Clinical manifestations include palpable purpura, the hallmark feature of HSP, which characteristically involves the extensor surfaces of arms and legs. Musculoskeletal symptoms such as arthritis and arthralgia are common. Gastrointestinal symptoms can include abdominal pain, vomiting, diarrhea, and bleeding. Renal involvement may lead to gross or microscopic hematuria, nephritic syndrome, or nephrotic syndrome. Renal manifestations are more severe in adults. A rapidly progressive form of glomerulonephritis is seen in some cases. Nephritis usually follows the appearance of the rash. 

Diagnosis of HSP is primarily based on clinical findings, including the palpable purpura, along with the presence of other symptoms. Laboratory tests are not specific to HSP but may show nonspecific markers of inflammation and sometimes elevated levels of IgA. Imaging studies and biopsies of affected tissues can provide additional diagnostic information

Treatment of HSP is generally supportive, focusing on hydration, pain relief, and nutrition. Corticosteroids may be used in severe cases or for significant gastrointestinal involvement. Intravenous immune globulin (IVIG) and plasma exchange are occasionally employed for severe disease. Nephritis due to IgA vasculitis should be treated with immunosuppressants like prednisolone and azathioprine. Complications of HSP can include serious gastrointestinal problems, kidney disease, and recurrences, but overall, the prognosis for childhood HSP is favorable. Regular monitoring of blood pressure and urine is recommended to detect and manage potential complications.

questions.text: Transection at level 1 with the cutting of the vagal nerve leads to:
questions.solution:
If the vagal nerve is cut along with transection at level 1 i.e. above the level of the pons, then regular breathing with deep inspiration ensues.

Due to the stretching of the lungs during inspiration, impulses are generated in afferent pulmonary vagal fibres. These impulses inhibit inspiratory discharge. Hence, if vagi are cut, the depth of inspiration increases.

Apneusis will occur if the vagus is cut, along with damage to the pneumotaxic centre (Level 2).

Regular breathing continues

questions.text: SMAC/DIABLO is

choices.text: Both apoptotic and anti apoptotic protein

questions.solution:
SMAC/DIABLO is a pro apoptotic protein.

In Intrinsic pathway of Apoptosis, mitochondrial permeability is increased and proteins like cytochrome c and pro apoptotic Smac/Diablo leaks out. SMAC/DIABLO inhibits cytoplasmic IAP (Physiological inhibitor of apoptosis). IAP inhibits caspases and keeps cell alive.

The released Cytochrome C binds to apoptotic activating factor-1 to form apoptosome complex that triggers caspase-9 activation.

questions.text: A 1 year old child presented to emergency with intermittent cry and blood stained stool. On ultrasonography a target sign was seen. This is probably a case of __________
questions.solution:
A 1-year-old child with bloodstained stool and USG image depicting target sign is suggestive of intussusception.

The target sign of intestinal intussusception is also known as the doughnut sign or bull's eye sign. The appearance is generated by concentric alternating echogenic and hypoechogenic bands. The echogenic bands are formed by mucosa and muscularis whereas the submucosa is responsible for the hypoechoic bands.

Ultrasound signs include:

  • Target sign (also known as the doughnut sign)
  • Pseudokidney sign: this is seen in the longitudinal section of the bowel. The edematous bowel resembles renal parenchyma and the mesentery which is dragged into the intussusception resembles renal hilum.
  • Crescent in a doughnut sign.

questions.text: The drug efavirenz inhibits
questions.solution:
The drug efavirenz inhibits HIV reverse transcriptase. It is an NNRTI.

There are five classes of drugs in combination can be termed antiretro viral therapy (ART), combination antiretroviral therapy (cART) or highly active antiretroviral therapy (HAART).

Antiretroviral drugs are classified by the phase of the retrovirus life cycle that the drug inhibits.

questions.text: A 60-year-old female has been admitted for a thorough evaluation following a history of right-sided weakness that resolved by the time she reached the hospital 2 hours after the onset. MRI of the brain reveals no signal changes. During rounds the next morning, the resident is asked about the patient's ABCD2 score. What does this score measure?
questions.solution:
Transient ischemic attack (TIA) is defined as an episode of stroke symptoms that last <24 hours, which is the likely diagnosis according to the clinical scenario. The ABCD2 Score is used to measure the risk of stroke in a patient following TIA.

TIAs occur due to an embolic clot to the brain or a thrombosis within an intra-cranial vessel similar to what happens in an ischemic stroke, but in TIA, the vessel lumen opens up spontaneously leading to resolution of the neurologic symptoms. The risk of developing a stroke following a TIA is high especially during the first few hours-days, and hence patients are usually admitted to the hospital and started on dual anticoagulation with aspirin + clopidogrel, which has been found to prevent stroke following TIA. Thrombolysis is not indicated in TIA but is indicated in early stroke occurring following TIA.

Other options:

Option B: The CHA2DS2 VASc Score is to assess the risk for embolic stroke in patients with atrial fibrillation. Based on the risk determined, the need for anticoagulation is decided.

Option C: The risk for developing pulmonary embolism is based on the Well’s, Modified Well’s and Pulmonary Embolism Rule-out Criteria (PERC) scoring systems.

Option D: The severity of sub-arachnoid hemorrhage according on the clinical status of the patient at the time of presentation is based on the Hunt and Hess Score. It is used to predict the clinical outcome of the patient, ie, higher score indicates poorer outcome.

Pulmonary embolism rule out criteria (PERC):

This is a quick OPD/casualty tool to rule out pulmonary embolism in patients with low clinical probability. It comprises eight clinical variables. If the patient meets all eight criteria, there is no need for further investigations. The variables include: 

  1. Age <50 years
  2. Heart rate <100 bpm
  3. SpO2 ≥95%
  4. No unilateral leg swelling
  5. No hemoptysis
  6. No recent trauma or surgery
  7. No history of venous thromboembolism
  8. No use of hormonal therapy.

questions.text: Which among the following is a motilide?
questions.solution:
The name "motilide" refers to a motilin-like macrolide. The effects of motilin can be mimicked by erythromycin.

Erythromycin induces phase III migrating motor complex.

It has multiple effects on upper GI motility, increasing lower esophageal pressure and stimulating gastric and small-bowel contractility. However, it has little or no effect on colonic motility.

Erythromycin is used as a prokinetic agent in patients with diabetic gastroparesis, where it can improve gastric emptying in the short term.

Rapid development of tolerance (~28 days) to erythromycin, possibly by downregulation of the motilin receptor, and antibiotic effects (undesirable in this context) limit the use of this drug as a prokinetic agent.

A standard dose of erythromycin for gastric stimulation is 1.5–3 mg/kg intravenous infusion every 6 h in a hospital setting or 125 mg orally every 12 h.

At doses higher than 3 mg/kg, it can produce a spastic type of contraction in the small bowel, resulting in cramps, impairment of transit, and vomiting.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about fibrous proteins?

choices.text: Axial ratio is less than or equal to 3

questions.solution:
Elastin is a fibrous protein.

Fibrous Protein Globular Protein
  • Structural functions
  • Minimal water solubility
  • Axial ratio ≥10
  • Eg. Collagen, Keratin, Elastin
  • Dynamic functions
  • Good water solubility

  • Eg. Albumin, Globulin, most enzymes

Axial ratio is the ratio of their longest to shortest dimension.

questions.text: Newer inclusion in 2015 WHO classification of squamous cell carcinoma of lung includes?
questions.solution: The WHO classification of Squamous cell carcinoma of lungs include Keratinizing and Non keratinizing variants along with Basaloid and Pre-invasive types.

questions.text: Cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy (CADASIL)  is caused by mutations in _____________
questions.solution:
Cerebral autosomal dominant arteriopathy with subcortical infarcts and leukoencephalopathy (CADASIL) is caused by a mutation in the NOTCH 3 gene on chromosome19.

  • CADASIL is characterized by vasculopathy involving small arteries, arterioles & capillaries (predominantly in the brain). This is because Notch-3 protein is preferentially expressed in vascular smooth muscle cells & capillary pericytes.
  • CADASIL usually presents clinically as
    • Migraine with aura 
    • TIAs / Ischemic Stroke (Important cause of stroke in young)
    • Cognitive impairment / progressive dementia
    • Neuropsychiatric disturbances 
  • MRI is the preferred neuroimaging modality and usually reveals extensive subcortical white matter changes (lacunar infarcts) often including the anterior temporal lobes.
  • Diagnosis can be absolutely confirmed by 
    • Confirming NOTCH3 gene mutation
    • Skin biopsy to demonstrate vasculopathy by deposition of the misfolded Notch-3 protein [Granular osmiophilic material (GOM)]

questions.text: The triad of Reiter’s syndrome does not include _____
questions.solution:
The triad of Reiter’s syndrome includes:

  • Conjunctivitis,

Reiter’s syndrome is associated with the presence of HLA B27 antigen.

Chlamydia trachomatis is the most common cause of nongonococcal urethritis (NGU) and post gonococcal urethritis (PGU).

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about prolactin levels in pregnancy?

choices.text: Lowest in pregnancy and increases after delivery
Highest at term and reduces after delivery
Increases during pregnancy and plateaus during lactation

questions.solution:
The maternal plasma prolactin level is highest at term and reduces after delivery. Despite this high level, milk secretion does not occur during pregnancy due to the action of estrogen and progesterone.

Prolactin secretion returns to the nonpregnant level a few weeks after delivery. The levels of estrogen and progesterone fall and hence, prolactin can promote milk secretion even at a lesser concentration.

questions.text: A lady was found to have the feature seen in image A, which is characteristic of a certain disease. On further investigations, she was found to have the immunofluorescence pattern seen in image B. Positivity of which of the following antibodies would predict a high risk of interstitial lung disease in her?
questions.solution:
Image A showing classical prominent perioral radial furrowing and microstomia and image B showing nucleolar pattern are suggestive of systemic sclerosis. Anti-Scl-70 positivity in this disease is useful in predicting those at high risk for interstitial lung disease.

Scleroderma or systemic sclerosis (SSc) is an autoimmune rheumatic disease in which there is a 4:1 female predominance.

A wide spectrum of clinical features is seen in scleroderma. Initially, the fingers may be puffy and have nonpitting edema. The skin later becomes indurated, thickened, and fixed to underlying structures resulting in sclerodactyly. Severe pruritus, vasospasm, and digital ulceration may be present. 

Mask-like facies is seen due to the waxy nature of skin and lack of wrinkles, expressionless facies, mat‐like telangiectases, microstomia (fish mouth appearance), perioral furrowing, and beak‐like nose.

Around 90% of patients suffering from scleroderma have dysphagia and gastroesophageal reflux at the level of the esophagus. The intense sclerosis of organs and primarily the fibrosis of the skin has devastating effects on the affected patients.

The nucleolar pattern (some spots of fluorescence within the nucleus, representing antibodies against RNA) is most often seen in systemic sclerosis. 

Anti-topoisomerase I (Scl-70) and anti-RNA polymerase III are seen in diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis, which can have pulmonary manifestation as interstitial lung disease.

Other options:

Option A - Anti-U3-RNP (anti-fibrillarin) autoantibodies are associated with patients of Afro-Caribbean origin and can identify patients with SSc who are younger at disease onset and display a higher prevalence of myositis.

Option B - Anti-centromere antibody is most specific for CREST syndrome.
 
Option D - Anti-U1-RNP is seen in mixed connective tissue disease.

Related Pearl: Pattern of nuclear body suggests the type of antibody present in patient’s serum.

Five basic patterns of nuclear fluorescence is recognized for anti-nuclear antibodies:

Staining pattern Antigen
Homogenous or diffuse nuclear staining Antibodies to chromatin, histones, and occasionally double-stranded DNA
Rim or peripheral staining Antibodies to double-stranded DNA, and sometimes to nuclear envelope proteins
Speckled pattern

One of the most commonly observed patterns of fluorescence, the least specific. 

Antibodies to non-DNA nuclear constituents such as Sm antigen, ribonucleoprotein, and SS-A and SS-B reactive antigens.
Nucleolar pattern

Few discrete spots of fluorescence within the nucleus and represent antibodies to RNA.

Seen in systemic sclerosis.
Centromeric pattern

Seen in systemic sclerosis

Often contain antibodies specific for centromeres, which give rise to this pattern.

questions.text: The structure in the myeloblast seen in the slide given below is made of __________
questions.solution:
The slide shows Auer rods in myeloblasts. Auer rods are needle-shaped azurophilic intracytoplasmic inclusion bodies formed by the fusion of lysosomes.

Auer rods contain peroxidase and lysosomal enzymes. 

Auer rods are seen in:

  • acute leukemia (myeloblastic, promyelocytic, monomyelocytic and monocytic)
  • myelodysplastic syndromes (RAEB-2) 
  • chronic myelomonocytic leukemia

Myeloblasts with bundles of Auer rods are known as faggot cells which are seen in acute promyelocytic leukemia.

questions.text: In the 1980s, David Philip Vetter was a prominent case of Severe Combined Immunodeficiency (SCID), who later died at the age of 12.  In such children, the defective DNA repair mechanism is:
questions.solution:
SCID is associated with a defective Non-Homologous End Joining (NHEJ).

Non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ) is a mechanism by which a group of proteins mediates the recognition, processing, and direct ligation of the ends of two DNA fragments where a double-strand break in DNA has occurred. This is in contrast to homologous repair (HR), another mechanism, where an undamaged homologous DNA template is required to replace an adjacent damaged one.

The type of repair depends on the phase of cell cycles:

The phase of the cell cycle     Repair mechanism
 G0 /G1 Phase   Nonhomologous End Joining Repair
S, G2, M Phase   Homologous Repair

NHEJ deficiency confers combined immunodeficiency due to a failure to carry out recombination efficiently. NHEJ also functions in class switch recombination, another step enhancing T and B cell diversity.

Severe combined immunodeficiency (SCID) occurs due to defects in both humoral and cell-mediated immune responses. Patients with SCID are extremely susceptible to recurrent, severe infections by a wide range of pathogens, including Candida albicans, Pneumocystis jirovecii, Pseudomonas species, cytomegalovirus, varicella, etc. The most common form is X-linked SCID, and hence, SCID is more common in boys than in girls. The genetic defect in the X-linked form is a mutation in the common γ-chain (γc) subunit of cytokine receptors and the most common cause of autosomal-recessive SCID is a deficiency of adenosine deaminase (ADA) enzyme.

questions.text: In which position of vocal cord, cricoarytenoid joint will be in neutral position?
questions.solution:
The cricoarytenoid joint is in neutral position when vocal cord is in intermediate or cadaveric position.

The neutral point of a joint is in the position where there is least amount of support from the ligaments and other non-muscular tissues around the joint. In this position, stress to the joint is minimized, which helps the joint to function well over time.
