questions.text: The instrument given below is used to measure __________
questions.solution:
The instrument given above is globe thermometer which is used to measure mean radiant temperature.

Other options : 

Option A - Measurement of humidity:

  • Dry and wet hygrometers are the most widely used instrument
  • Sling psychrometer/Whirling psychrometer:  It is used to measure the relative humidity

Option C - The air velocity is measured by an instrument called the "anemometer".

Option D - Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time. It contains both mercury and alcohol.

Related Pearl: Measurement of Air Temperature

A number of thermometers that employ mercury or alcohol are used for measuring air temperature.

These thermometers are mounted on a special screen called Stevenson screen as air should have free access to their bulbs and they must be protected from radiant heat.

The instruments used to measure air temperature are:

1) Dry bulb thermometers:

These are ordinary mercury thermometers mounted on a Stevenson screen at about 1.20 to 1.80 metres above sea level

2) Wet bulb thermometers:

These are just like the dry bulb variants but the bulb is kept wet by a muslin cloth that is fed with water from a bottle through a wick.

3) Maximum thermometer

This is a mercury thermometer that has a very fine constriction near the neck of the bulb

4) Minimum thermometer

The liquid in this thermometer is a spirit that has a dumb-bell shaped index immersed in it

5) Six’s maximum-minimum thermometer

  • This thermometer has both mercury and alcohol
  • It measures the maximum and minimum air temperatures reached over a period of time
  • A mercury-free variant of this thermometer is available

5) Globe thermometer:

  • It is used for the direct measurement of the mean radiant temperature of the surroundings.
  • It has a hollow metal globe (6 inches diameter) that has matte black paint which absorbs radiant heat. A specially calibrated mercury bulb thermometer is kept inside.
  • The difference between the readings of the globe thermometer and the bulb thermometer is the measure of the radiant heat.

7) Kata thermometers:

  • It is an alcohol thermometer and consists of a wet kata and a dry kata.
  • A wet kata reading of 20 and above and a dry kata reading of 6 and above were taken as indices of thermal comfort.
  • It was originally used to measure the cooling power of the air (air temperature, humidity and air movement) but currently it is used only as an anemometer to measure low air velocities.

questions.text: The following instrument is used in

choices.text: To correct fracture of nasal bones
Alignment of fracture of a long bone

questions.solution:
Payr's intestinal clamp is used for crushing and clamping of intestine, stomach and appendix.

It has longitudinal serrations and is applied to the part of intestine which is being removed as vaibility of the tissue is lost once the clamp is applied.

questions.text: Refsum’s disease is an enzymatic deficiency in alpha oxidation of fatty acid. This alpha oxidation of fatty acid usually takes place in _______________
questions.solution:
Alpha oxidation of fatty acid takes place in peroxisome.

The branched-chain fatty acid, phytanic acid, is not a substrate for acyl CoA dehydrogenase due to the methyl group on its third carbon. Instead, it is hydroxylated at the α-carbon by fatty acid α-hydroxylase. The product is decarboxylated and then activated to its CoA derivative, which is a substrate for the enzymes of β-oxidation.

Refsum disease is a rare, autosomal recessive disorder caused by a deficiency of α-hydroxylase. This results in the accumulation of phytanic acid in the plasma and tissues. The symptoms are primarily neurologic, and the treatment involves dietary restriction to halt disease progression.

Related Pearl: Types, Location and Properties of Fatty acid oxidation

Types of Oxidation

Location

Properties

Associated Disease

Beta oxidation

Mitochondria

A catabolic process by which two-carbons are cleaved from the fatty acid molecule and released as acetyl CoA starting from the carboxyl end.

The chain is broken between the α(2) and β(3) carbon.

1 round of beta-oxidation yield 1FADH2, 1NADH, and 1 Acetyl CoA.

  

Alpha oxidation

Peroxisome

The presence of the 3-methyl group of phytanic acid prevents degradation by beta-oxidation.

The chain is broken between the terminal carboxyl group and α(2) carbon removing that carbon as CO2. The remaining chain is activated with CoA and then undergoes β-Oxidation.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Classic Refsum's Disease

Defective enzyme- Phytanoyl Coa hydroxylase.

Clinical features include:

Ichthyosis, Retinitis pigmentosa, Decreased vision, Peripheral neuropathy, Ataxia

 

Omega oxidation

Endoplasmic Reticulum

An alternative pathway to beta-oxidation occurs in microsomes.

Involves the oxidation of the ω carbon (terminal methyl group) resulting in dicarboxylic acid.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

  

Peroxisomal Beta oxidation

Peroxisome

Very-long-chain fatty acids undergo preliminary β-oxidation in peroxisomes up to octanoyl CoA. The shortened fatty acids undergo further β-oxidation in the mitochondria.

It is not an energy-yielding process.

Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome

A rare inherited absence of peroxisomes in all tissues.

They accumulate C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue and also exhibit a generalized loss of peroxisomal functions. The disease causes severe neurologic symptoms, and most patients die in the first year of life.

questions.text: Denileukin diftitox, a drug approved for the treatment of recurrent/refractory cutaneous T-cell lymphomas, is an immunotoxin made of:

choices.text: Fusion protein of IL-2 and pertussis toxin
Fusion protein of IL-2 and diptheria toxin

questions.solution:
Denileukin diftitox is an immunotoxin made from the genetic recombination of IL-2 and the catalytically active fragment of diphtheria toxin. 

It is indicated for advanced cutaneous T-cell lymphoma in patients with >20% of T cells expressing the surface marker CD25. After binding to the IL-2 receptors, it is internalized by endocytosis. The active fragment of diphtheria toxin then is released into the cytosol, where it inhibits protein synthesis through ADP ribosylation, leading to cell death.

Immunotoxins are proteins that contain a toxin along with an antibody that binds specifically to target cells.

Antibody-drug conjugates are complex molecules composed of an antibody linked to a biologically active cytotoxic (anticancer) drug. These antibody-targeted drug therapies are cell-specific to kill efficiently the target cells that bind and internalize the drug conjugate. Examples are:

  • Gemtuzumab ozogamicin - Monoclonal antibody against CD33 linked to a semisynthetic derivative of calicheamicin, a potent antitumor antibiotic. It was approved for the treatment of acute myeloid leukemia.
  • Brentuximab vedotin - Anti-CD30 IgG1 monoclonal antibody linked with the microtubule-disrupting agent MMAE. It is used for the treatment of Hodgkin and anaplastic lymphoma.
  • Ado-trastuzumab emtansine - It combines the HER2-targeted properties of trastuzumab with the antimicrotubule agent DM1 (derived from maytansine), allowing preferential intracellular drug delivery to HER2+ cells. It is used in the treatment of HER+ breast cancer.

questions.text: Fundal changes shown in the image given below can be seen in the case of
questions.solution:
The given image shows severe cupping and thinning of the neuroretinal rim seen in glaucoma.

Glaucomatous changes in the optic disc

Early Glaucomatous changes

  • Slit defects of the retinal nerve fiber layer
  • Splinter hemorrhages on disc margin
  • Large cup: 0.7 or more
  • Asymmetry of the cups: A difference equal to or more than 0.2 between two eyes is significant
  • Vertically oval cup

Advanced Glaucomatous changes

  • Marked cupping (Beanpot cupping)
  • Thinning of neuroretinal rim
  • Bayonetting sign - Sharp angulation of vessel at the margin of the excavated cup.
  • Laminar dot sign

questions.text: The image given below depicts the steps in glycogenolysis. Match the enzymes involved correctly.

choices.text: A - Phosphorylase, B - Glucan transferase, C - Debranching enzyme
A - Debranching enzyme, B - Phosphorylase, C - Glucan Transferase
A - Glucan Transferase, B - Phosphorylase, C - Debranching enzyme
A – Debranching enzyme, B – Glucan transferase, C - Phosphorylase

questions.solution:
A - Phosphorylase, B - Glucan transferase, C - Debranching enzyme.

Steps of glycogenolysis:

  • Step 1: There is breaking of alpha 1,4 linkages in glycogen by glycogen phosphorylase (rate limiting step)
  • Step 2: There is transfer of trisaccharide residue from one branch to another by glucan transferase, forming new alpha 1, 4 bond. Thus the alpha 1,6 branch point from where the residue is transferred, is exposed.
  • Step 3: Alpha 1,6 glucosidase hydrolyses this exposed branching point, leading to glucose 1 phosphate.
  • Step 4: Glucose 1 phosphate is converted to glucose 6 phosphate by phosphoglucomutase.
  • Step 5: In liver, phosphatase converts glucose 6 phosphate to glucose.

Related Pearl: Glycogenolysis

questions.text: A 60-year-old female presented with acute loss of vision and metamorphopsia. There is a history of positive scotoma. Fundal changes are given below. Probable diagnosis is _______
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the fundal image depicting focal fundal detachment is suggestive of central serous retinopathy.

Central serous retinopathy

  • Refers to the spontaneous serous detachment of neurosensory retina in the macular region.
  • Pathogenesis: Recent studies implicate an abnormal choroidal circulation as the cause of CSR. 

Clinical features:

  • Retinal detachment: Sudden painless loss of vision
  • Relative positive scotoma
  • Micropsia
  • Metamorphopsia

Investigations:

  • Ophthalmoscopy 
    • Circular ring reflex present
    •  Foveal reflex absent
  • FFA 
    •  Enlarging inkblot pattern or smoke stack pattern

Treatment: 

  • Treatment not required, usually self-limiting but often recurrent
  • Steroids are contraindicated.

questions.text: In Duke's staging of carcinoma rectum, lymph node involvement is classified as?
questions.solution:
Duke's staging of cancer:

  • A: The growth is limited to the rectal wall (15 per cent): prognosis excellent (90 per cent year survival).
  • B: The growth is extended to the extra rectal tissues, but no metastasis to the regional lymph nodes (35 per cent): prognosis reasonable (70 per cent year survival).
  • C: There are secondary deposits in the regional lymph nodes (50 per cent). These are subdivided into     
    • -C1, in which the local pararectal lymph nodes alone are involved.
    • C2, in which the nodes accompanying the supplying blood vessels are implicated up to the point of division. This does not take into account cases that have metastasis beyond the regional lymph nodes or by way of the venous system: prognosis is poor (40 per cent year survival).

A stage D is often included, which was not described by Dukes. This stage signifies the presence of widespread metastases, usually hepatic.

questions.text: Which of the following CD markers is positive in mastocytosis?
questions.solution:
CD 117, CD25 and CD 2 are expressed on aberrant mast cells. A cell not expressing CD117(KIT) is not a mast cell.

Mastocytosis:The term mastocytosis encompasses a spectrum of rare disorders characterised by increase number of mast cells in skin and in some instances in other organs as well.

  • Most cases of mastocytosis will be cutaneous type in children and systemic indolent type in adults.
  • Etiopathogenesis: 
    • The symptoms of mastocytosis are primarily due to mast cell mediator release.
    • The mast cells accumulate in tissues as a direct consequence of acquiring a gain-of‐function mutation of KIT, which encodes the transmembrane receptor for stem cell factor (KIT). 
  • The age of onset is in the first one year in childhood type and 20–40 years in adult type.
  • There is no gender difference.
  • Clinically,numerous reddish‐brown or pale monomorphic maculopapules, plaques or nodules in a symmetrical distribution can be seen over trunk and thighs. The palms and soles are usually spared.
  • Dariers's sign positive: They characteristically urticate within minutes of gentle rubbing in children causing localized pruritus, redness and wealing, which subside within an hour.
  • Treatment includes avoiding triggers, antihistamines, mast cell stabilisers, topical and oral corticosteroids, PUVA therapy and KIT tyrosine kinase inhibitors.
 

Other options:

  • CD 68: histiocytes(positive in malignant fibrous histiocytosis)
  • CD 99: Ewings sarcoma cells
  • CD 5-is positive in both CLL/SLL and mantle cell lymphoma but CD 23 is positive only in CLL/SLL and not mantle cell lymphoma.

Related Pearl: Immune Cell Antigens Detected by Monoclonal Antibodies

Antigen Designation and their Normal Cellular Distribution 
Primarily T-Cell Associated 
  • CD1 Thymocytes and Langerhans cells 
  • CD3 Thymocytes, mature T cells 
  • CD4 Helper T cells, subset of thymocytes  
  • CD5 T cells and a small subset of B cells  
  • CD8 Cytotoxic T cells, subset of thymocytes, and some NK cells 
Primarily B-Cell Associated 
  • CD10 Pre-B cells and germinal-center B cells 
  • CD19 Pre-B cells and mature B cells, but not plasma cells 
  • CD20 Pre-B cells after CD19 and mature B cells, but not plasma cells 
  • CD21 EBV receptor; mature B cells and follicular dendritic cells
  • CD23 Activated mature B cells 
  • CD79a Marrow pre-B cells and mature B cells 
Primarily Monocyte or Macrophage Associated 
  • CD11c Granulocytes, monocytes, and macrophages; also expressed by hairy cell leukemias 
  • CD13 Immature and mature monocytes and granulocytes 
  • CD14 Monocytes 
  • CD15 Granulocytes; Reed-Sternberg cells and variants
  • CD33 Myeloid progenitors and monocytes  
  • CD64 Mature myeloid cells  
Primarily NK-CellAssociated 
  • CD16 NK cells and granulocytes  
  • CD56 NK cells and a subset of T cells 
Primarily Stem Cell and Progenitor Cell Associated  
  • CD34 Pluripotent hematopoietic stem cells and progenitor cells of many lineages 
Activation Markers 
  • CD30 Activated B cells, T cells, and monocytes; Reed-Sternberg cells and variants 
Present on All Leukocytes 
  • CD45 All leukocytes; also known as leukocyte common antigen (LCA)

questions.text: All are true about cephalohematoma except?
questions.solution:
Cephalohematomas are cranial subperiosteal hematomas that persist for weeks or even months.

These develop from shearing forces during labor and delivery that lacerate the emissary or diploic veins . Fortunately, the densely adhered periosteum impedes rapid enlargement and limits final hematoma size. Hemorrhage can be over one or both parietal bones, but palpable edges can be appreciated as the blood reaches the limits of the periosteum.

These hematomas must be diferentiated from caput succedaneum.

A cephalohematoma may not be apparent until hours after delivery, when bleeding sufficient to raise the periosteum has occurred. After it is identified, it often grows larger and persists for weeks or even months, and bleeding may be sufficient to cause anemia.

By contrast, with caput succedaneum, swelling of the scalp is from soft-tissue edema that overlies the periosteum. The caput is maximal at birth, rapidly grows smaller, and usually disappears within hours or a few days. Occasionally it becomes infected, and an abscess may form.

Characteristic Caput succedaneum Cephalohematoma
Incidence Common Less common
Location Subcutaneous plane Over parietal bones, b/w skull and periosteum (sub periosteal)
Time of presentation Maximum size and firmness at birth Not present at birth. Takes 12-24 hrs to increase in size and then stable.
Time course Softens progressively from birth and resolves within 2-3 days Takes 3-6 weeks to resolve
Characteristic findings Diffuse; crosses suture line Does not cross suture line; has distinct margins
Association None

Linear skull fracture,

hyperbilirubinemia

questions.text:
Components of cryoprecipitate include __________
1. Factor I
2. Factor II
3. Von willebrand factor 
4. Factor VIII
questions.solution:
Cryoprecipitate mainly contains - Fibrinogen (Factor I), Von willebrand factor and Factor VIII. It is ideal for supplying fibrinogen to the volume-sensitive patient.

When factor VIII concentrates are not available, cryoprecipitate may be used because each unit contains approximately 80 units of factor VIII.

Separation of blood components: (shown in the flowchart below)

  • Whole blood is first separated into PRBCs and platelet-rich plasma by slow centrifugation.
  • The platelet-rich plasma is then centrifuged at high speed to yield one unit of random donor (RD) platelets and one unit of FFP.
  • Cryoprecipitate is produced by thawing FFP to precipitate the plasma proteins and then separated by centrifugation.

Related Pearl: Blood components

Component Volume     (1 unit) Content Clinical response, increase in  Storage temperature Shelf-life
Whole blood 450 ml RBCs, platelets, plasma Hb and plasma volume    
Packed red blood cells (PRBCs) 300-350 ml RBCs

Hb by 1 g/dl

Hematocrit by 3%

1° to 6°C

ACD/CPD-21 days, CPD-A-35 days, additive-42 days
Random donor platelets (RDP) 50-70 ml Platelets platelet count by 5000-10,000/µL 20 to 24°C 5 days
Single donor apheretic platelets (SDP*) 200-400 ml Platelets platelet count by 30,000/µL
Fresh frozen plasma (FFP) 200-250 ml Coagulation factors, protein C, protein S, anti thrombin coagulation factors by 2% -40 to -50°C 1 year
Cryoprecipitate 10-15 ml fibrinogen, factor VIII, VWF 80 IU Factor VIII -30 °C 1 year

 

*SDP is obtained by collecting multiple units of platelets from a single donor using apheretic technology. 

1 SDP = 6 RDP

questions.text: A 36-year-old G1P0 woman presents for her first prenatal visit late in her first trimester of pregnancy. She complains of persistent vaginal bleeding, nausea, and pelvic pain. Physical examination is notable for gravid uterus larger than expected for gestational age. Fetal heart sounds are absent. Which of the following is most likely to be true?

choices.text: Ovaries can be cystic from multiple theca lutein cysts
p57 is strongly expressed in the tissues involved
β – HCG levels will be less than normal

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of a molar pregnancy.

Ovaries can be fuller and cystic from multiple theca lutein cysts. It is likely due to ovarian overstimulation by excessive hCG levels. These theca-lutein cysts regress following pregnancy evacuation. Occasionally a larger cyst may undergo torsion, infarction, and hemorrhage.

In a molar pregnancy the β–HCG levels will be higher than normal.

The thyrotropin-like effects of hCG frequently cause serum free thyroxine (T4) levels to be elevated and thyroid-stimulating hormone (TSH) levels to be decreased.

p57 is used for immunohistochemical staining. It is a nuclear protein whose gene is paternally imprinted and maternally expressed. This means that the gene product is produced only in tissues containing a maternal allele. Because complete moles contain only paternal genes, the p57 protein is absent in complete moles, and tissues do not pick up this stain.

questions.text: The most effective drug in the treatment of loa-loa is?
questions.solution:
DEC - Diethylcarbamazine is the drug of choice for the treatment of loiasis, but it is advisable to start with a small initial dose to diminish host reactions that result from the destruction of microfilariae.

Treatment is initiated with test doses of 50 mg (1 mg/kg in children) daily for 2–3 days, escalating to maximally tolerated daily doses of 9 mg/kg in three doses for 2–3 weeks.

Glucocorticoids pretreatment may be administered to ameliorate acute reactions. In rare instances, life-threatening encephalopathy follows the treatment of loiasis, probably due to the inflammatory reaction to dead or dying microfilariae lodged in the cerebral microvasculature.

questions.text: Which of the following can be used to represent quantitative data?
questions.solution:
An ogive, a line diagram and a histogram can be used to represent quantitative data.

The images shown above are:

A – Ogive

B – Bar graph

C – Line diagram

D – Histogram

Quantitative data cannot be represented by a bar graph. It is used mostly for nominal scale or qualitative data.

Related Pearl: Graphical Representation of Data

1. Histogram

  • A histogram, by definition, is a graphical representation of frequency distribution that contains rectangles and shows the underlying frequency of a set of continuous, quantitative data.
  • The X or horizontal axis is called the abscissa which usually has the group scores or class intervals of the variables/data and the Y or vertical axis is called the ordinate which usually shows the frequencies at which these variables appear.
  • The following image shows a histogram.

2. Bar Chart

  • It is also called a bar graph.
  • It is used mainly for nominal or ordinal scale data as they are not quantitative and usually qualitative.
  • The difference between a bar graph and a histogram is that the rectangles are separated by spaces representing data that forms discrete categories instead of continuous groups.
  • Bar graphs can be simple, multiple or component bar graphs.

3. Pie Charts

  • Pie charts are also used for nominal or ordinal data.
  • The categorical data are represented as segments of a circle.

4. Frequency polygons

  • Frequency polygons are used for mainly ratio and interval scale data.
  • In a frequency polygon, the mid-points of each class interval are joined together by straight lines.

5. Ogive

  • A frequency polygon which is drawn to represent cumulative frequency distributions form a typical S-shaped curve which is called an ogive. It referred to as a cumulative frequency diagram.

6. Line chart

  • It is also called a line diagram or line graph.
  • Its best use is to show the trend of events or change over passage of time.

questions.text: What is true regarding the mirrors used at two ends of the instrument given in the image?

choices.text: Plane at one and concave at other end
Plane at one and convex at other end
Convex at one end and concave at other

questions.solution:
The image is of the Priestley-Smith retinoscope. It is a mirror retinoscope and has a plane mirror at one end and concave at other.

It has a central hole of about 2.5mm anteriorly and 4mm posteriorly.

Retinoscopy is also called a skiascopy/ shadow test. It is used to estimate refraction objectively. The instruments used are:

  • Priestley-Smith retinoscope
  • Streak retinoscope: It is self-illuminated and projects a streak rather than a circle of light.

questions.text: Hepatocytes are derived from_________
questions.solution:
Hepatocytes are derived from foregut endoderm.

Development of liver :

  • Endoderm of foregut: Most of the liver including hepatocytes.
  • Septum transversum ( mesenchyme): Ligaments of liver (except ligamentum teres), kupffer cells, hematopoietic cells, sinusoids and fibro alveolar stroma.
  • Ligamentum teres is from left umblical vein.

Other options:

  • The ventral mesentery of the liver becomes the falciform ligament.
  • The dorsal mesentery of the stomach becomes the greater omentum.

questions.text: A lymph node biopsy of a 6-year-old boy shows markedly decreased numbers of lymphocytes in the paracortical areas. Analysis of his peripheral blood leukocytes is likely to show normal to elevated numbers of cells expressing _______
questions.solution:
The paracortex of a lymph node is a T-cell–dependent area. If this area is lacking cellularity, then the patient has a deficiency of T lymphocytes. B lymphocyte numbers could be normal or even elevated. The only B-cell marker on this list is CD19, the marker which is used clinically to enumerate B cells in the body.

In a person with a T-cell deficiency, there would be decreased numbers of cells bearing these markers :

  • CD2, also known as LFA-2, is an adhesion molecule found on T cells, thymocytes, and NK cells.
  • CD4 is found on all helper T lymphocytes.
  • CD8 is found on all cytotoxic T lymphocytes.

questions.text: Barium study in a patient showed the Fleischner sign. The patient may be a case of _______
questions.solution:
The Fleischner sign on barium study is seen in Ileocecal TB. The thickening widely gaping ileaocaecal valve lips resulting in a patulous valve with narrowing of the terminal ileum is called the Fleischner sign. It is also called the inverted umbrella sign.

Signs of Tuberculosis intestine:

  • String sign
  • Gooseneck sign
  • Stierlein sign
  • Fleishner sign
  • Pulled up cecum

Related Pearl: Barium studies in GI tuberculosis

  • Earliest feature is spasm and hypermotility, with edema of the valve.
  • Thickening of the valve lips, with narrowing of the terminal ileum: Fleischner or inverted umbrella sign is characteristic of TB.
  • In advance disease, the characteristic deformity includes symmetric, annular, napkin-ring stenosis and obstruction or shortening and pouch formation.
  • The cecum is shrunken and retracts out of the iliac fossa due to contraction of the mesocolon: Pulled-up cecum
  • Loss of ileocecal angle with dilated terminal ileum: Gooseneck deformity
  • Narrowing of the terminal ileum due to irritability, along with shortened rigid cecum: Sterlein sign
  • Persistent narrow stream of barium in the bowel indicates stenosis: String sign

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement regarding treatment of irritable bowel syndrome (IBS) ?

choices.text: Paroxetine is an SSRI most effective in diarrhoea prominent IBS
Lubipristone is a chloride channel stimulant used in diarrhoea prominent IBS
Linaclotide is a guanylate cyclase agonist used in constipation prominent IBS
Alosetron is a 5HT3 antagonist used in constipation dominant IBS

questions.solution:
Linaclotide is a guanylate cyclase C agonist used in constipation prominent IBS.

Mechanism of action:

  • Linaclotide, a guanylate cyclase C agonist that activates chloride secretion. Linaclotide is a minimally absorbed 14-amino-acid peptide guanylate cyclase-C (GC-C) agonist that binds to and activates GC-C on the luminal surface of intestinal epithelium.
  • Activation of GC-C results in generation of cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP), which triggers secretion of fluid, sodium and bicarbonate.
  • The analgesic action of linaclotide appears to be mediated by cGMP acting on afferent pain fibers innervating the GI tract.
  • Diarrhoea is a significant side effect.
  • The drug has been approved for treatment of constipation in IBS-C patients.

Other options:

  • Option a: Paroxetine is an SSRI effective in treatment of constipation prominent IBS as it accelerates oro-caecal transit.
  • Option b: Lubiprostone acts by stimulating the Cl- channels opening in the intestine, increasing liquid secretion in the gut and thus decreasing the transit time. Lubipristone is approved for chronic idiopathic constipation and constipation predominant irritable bowel syndrome (in females >18 years).
  • Option d: Alosetron, a 5 HT3 receptor antagonist used in the treatment of IBS relieves pain and abdominal discomfort. It causes constipation in IBS patients with diarrhea alternating with constipation.

Drugs used in IBS:

Pain relief Diarrhea dominant Constipation dominant
TCAs: Opioids: 5HT4 agonist:
  • Imipramine
  • Desmipramine
  • Nortryptyline
  • Loperamide
  • Diphenoxylate
  • Tegaserod
  • Prucalopride  
Citalopram (SSRI) Kappa agonist: Fedotozine CCK1 antagonist: Loxiglumide
Anti-cholinergics
  • Dicyclomine
  • Hyoscine

µ agonist & Delta antagonist:

Eluxadoline

Chloride channel stimulant:

Lubipristone
Reserpine analogue: Mebeverine Guanylate Cyclase agonist: Linaclotide
5HT3 antagonist: Alosetron Paroxetine(SSRI)
Others:
  • Clonidine
  • Rifaximin

questions.text:
Laboratory reports of a patient revealed an elevated serum potassium level. What is the classical sequence of ECG changes seen in this patient?
  1. Tall peaked T wave
  2. Loss of P wave
  3. Widened QRS complex
  4. Sine wave pattern
questions.solution:
Elevated serum potassium level is called hyperkalemia. The classical sequence of ECG changes seen with increasing severity of hyperkalemia is option B - 1, 2, 3, 4.

Hyperkalemia is defined by serum K+ > 5.5mM. It usually manifests as a medical emergency with cardiac arrhythmias such as sinus bradycardia, sinus arrest, slow idioventricular rhythms, ventricular tachycardia and ventricular fibrillation.

Note: These changes are particularly insensitive in patients with CKD.

Image showing different sequential changes at increasing levels of potassium.

questions.text: All the following are positive in Pre B Acute leukemias except?
questions.solution:
Surface Ig is expressed in Mature B ALL whereas cytoplasmic Ig is present in Late Pre B ALL.

Immunophenotyping of ALL :

Type of ALL Immunophenotype
Early Pre B ALL TdT, DR, CD19, CD24
Pre B ALL TdT, DR, CD10, CD19, CD20, CD24, Cy Ig
Common ALL CD19+,  CD10+/CALLA+
Mature B  ALL DR, CD19, CD20, CD24, Surface Ig
Pro T ALL  CD3, CD7
Pre T ALL TdT, CD2, CD3, CD4, CD5, CD7, CD8, CD34
Mature T ALL CD2, CD7, Tdt

questions.text: The lab values of a patient reveal a total cholesterol level of  300 mg/dl, TG - 150 mg/dl and HDL - 25 mg/dl . What would be the LDL value?
questions.solution:
The LDL value in the above scenario will be 245 mg/dl.

According to Friedewald’s equation

LDL-C = TC - HDL-C - (TG/5) 

Where

  • HDL-C: High-density lipoprotein cholesterol
  • LDL-C: Low-density lipoprotein cholesterol
  • TG: Triglycerides
  • TC: Total cholesterol

Substituting the values:

LDL-C = 300 - 25 - (150/5) = 300-55 = 245 mg/dl

Note:

VLDL-C(Very low-density lipoprotein cholesterol) = TG/5

questions.text: Which of the following is correctly matched  with regards to methylene blue -3 swab test observation and its interpretation?

choices.text: Upper most swab is stained with dye- Vesicovaginal fistula
Middle swab is stained blue- Ureterovaginal fistula
Lowermost swab gets stained- Urethrovaginal fistula
Swabs don't take up the stain but get soaked with urine -Vesicovaginal fistula

questions.solution:
Lowemost swab gets stained - urethrovaginal fistula is correctly matched.

Methylene blue-3 swab test is done to identify the type of fistula.

Related Pearl: Difference between bladder fistula & ureteric fistula

  Bladder fistula   Ureteric fistula 
Etiology

Obstetric causes:

  • Prolonged obstructed labor
  • Instrumental deliveries
  • Iatrogenic injury during caesarean section or sling operations

Surgical injury during:

  • Abdominal hysterectomy
  • Vaginal hysterectomy
  • Wertheim's hysterectomy
  • Laparoscopic surgeries
  • Caesarean section
Clinical features

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is unable to micturate

Dribbling of urine present from the vagina

The patient is able to micturate
Methylene blue 3-swab test Middle swab stains with methylene blue   Uppermost swab stains with urine, but not with methylene blue
Intravenous pyelography Normal Hydronephrosis and hydroureter present on the affected side

questions.text: A sexually active male presented with warts on his penis as shown below. Which of these strains of HPV is the most common cause of these lesions?
questions.solution:
Human papillomavirus 6 & 11 (6 >11) are the most common cause of anogenital warts (also known as Condyloma Accuminata).

Giant Anogenital warts are known as Buschke Lowenstein Tumor. It is more common in males than in females.

Most common site:

  • In males: Frenulum, corona, glans penis
  • In females: Posterior fourchette

On histology, koilocytes are seen as shown below.

These are squamous epithelial cells that have nuclear enlargement, irregular nuclear membrane, hyperchromasia, and perinuclear halo.

Most of these warts resolve spontaneously. Persistent warts might transform into malignancy most commonly when infected with HPV 16 and 18.

Treatment:

Provider administered:

  1. Podophyllin (25%) - Antimitotic drug
  2. Trichloroacetic acid
  3. Cryotherapy

Both trichloroacetic acid and cryotherapy are safe in pregnancy.

Patient administered:

  1. Purified podophyllin called podophyllotoxin
  2. Imiquimod - Immunomodulator which acts on toll-like receptors 7 and 8

questions.text: A positive Stallworthy sign is seen in
questions.solution:
Stallworthy’s sign: Slowing of fetal heart rate on pressing the head down into the pelvis and prompt recovery on release of pressure is termed Stallworthy’s sign and is suggestive of low-lying placenta, especially posteriorly.

 

Related Pearl: Radiological Signs in Obstetrics

Bagel Sign (USG)

It is seen in unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. It is also known as the tubal ring sign or the blob sign. It refers to the appearance of an anechoic gestational sac in the adnexa surrounded by a hyperechoic ring.

 

Twin Peak Sign/ Lambda Sign (USG)

Chorionicity of the placenta is best diagnosed by ultrasound at 10–13 weeks of gestation. In dichorionic twins, there is a thick triangular projection of placental tissue between the two gestational sacs. This is known as the lambda sign or twin peak sign.

 

T Sign (USG)

The T sign which is seen in monochorionic diamniotic gestation is thin and T-shaped because there is no extension of placental tissue or chorion in between the amniotic membranes.

 

Double Decidual Sac Sign (USG)

It is seen in early intrauterine pregnancy as two concentric echogenic rings surrounding the gestational sac.

 

Lemon Sign (USG)

At the level of the lateral ventricles, there is inward bowing or scalloping of frontal bones giving rise to the lemon sign. It is suggestive of spina bifida. It is also characteristically associated with Chiari II Malformation.

 

Banana Sign (USG)

Anterior curvature of the cerebellum with effacement of the cisterna magna in the posterior fossa is seen as banana sign. 

 

Spalding sign (USG)

It usually appears 7 days after intrauterine death and is caused by liquefaction of the brain matter and softening of the ligamentous structures supporting the vault, leading to irregular overlapping of the cranial bones on one another.

 

Frog Eye Sign (USG)

It is seen in anencephaly. Due to the absence of calvaria, the orbits appear more prominent. This is known as the "frog-eye sign". 

 

Omphalocele (USG)

It is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen  (indicated with an asterisk). The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

 

Double Bubble Sign (USG)

Dilatation of stomach and first part of duodenum due to duodenal atresia.

 

Bunch of grapes sign or Snowstorm appearance (USG) 

The appearance of multiple cystic spaces or lesions in a complete mole.

 

Ball sign (X-ray)

It is due to the crumpled up spine of the fetus seen in case of intrauterine death.

 

Robert’s sign (X-ray)

The presence of gas in the fetal great vessels in case of intrauterine fetal demise is known as Robert's sign.

 

Stuck twin sign (USG)

Smaller twin is held in a fixed position along the uterine wall due to the severe oligohydramnios. It is seen in twin-twin transfusion syndrome.

 

Butterfly sign (USG)

Normal appearance of the choroid plexuses on axial imaging of the fetal brain. An absence of this sign suggests holoprosencephaly.

 

Cloverleaf skull (USG)

Seen in craniosynostosis

 

Empty amnion sign (USG)

Visualization of an amniotic sac without concomitant visualization of an embryo. It is an indicator of pregnancy failure.

Related Pearl: Uterine Signs in Pregnancy

questions.text: Incorrect about the test being performed is _____________

choices.text: Seen in low median nerve injury

questions.solution:
The test shown in the image is Ochsner clasp test, which is seen in high median nerve injury (not low median nerve injury). When the patient is asked to clasp hands, the index finger of affected side fails to flex.

 Median nerve injury at the arm and elbow

  • Mostly seen in supracondylar fracture humerus, dislocation of elbow, pronator teres syndrome due to entrapment between two heads.
  • The prominent features are:
    • Forearm in supine position (pronator teres)
    • Weak wrist flexion (flexors supplied by median nerve)
    • Ulnar deviation on attempted flexion (paralysed FCR, unopposed FCU)
    • Loss of interphalangeal flexion (PIP and DIP)
  • Ochsner's clasping test: Attempt to clasp both hands shows pointing index finger.
  • Benediction hand sign: Due to loss of PIP and DIP flexion, attempt to make a fist gives pointed index and middle finger. 

Benediction hand sign:

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman presents to you with fatigue & palpitations. She gives a history of 4 spontaneous abortions early during pregnancy & provides a lab report showing very high titers of anti- beta2 glycoprotein 1. On cardiac auscultation, you hear a pansystolic murmur.  Which of the following vegetations would you most likely find on Echocardiography?
questions.solution:
The vegetations depicted in "Image D" are most likely to be seen in Echo.

The h/o repeated, early spontaneous abortions & lab report showing high titers of anti beta2 glycoprotein1 are strongly suggestive of Antiphospholipid Syndrome (APS). With this background, the given presentation of fatigue, palpitations, and finding of the pan-systolic murmur (most likely of MR) should raise a strong suspicion for Libman sack’s endocarditis. It is characterized by very small vegetations, on either or both sides of the valve as given in "Image D".

Antiphospholipid syndrome (APS) is an autoantibody-mediated acquired thrombophilia characterized by recurrent arterial or venous thrombosis and/or pregnancy morbidity. It primarily affects females. APS may occur alone (primary) or in association with other autoimmune diseases, mainly systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) (secondary).

Diagnosis:

  • The diagnosis of APS should be seriously considered in cases of thrombosis, cerebral vascular accidents in individuals <55 years of age, or pregnancy morbidity in the presence of livedo reticularis or thrombocytopenia.
  • The presence of at least one clinical and one laboratory criterion is compatible with the diagnosis, in the absence of other thrombophilia causes.
  • Clinical criteria include:
    • Vascular thrombosis defined as one or more clinical episodes of arterial, venous or small vessel thrombosis in any tissue or organ
    • Pregnancy morbidity, defined as:
      • One or more unexplained deaths of a morphologically normal fetus at or beyond the tenth week of gestation
      • One or more premature births of a morphologically normal neonate before the thirty-fourth week of gestation because of eclampsia, severe preeclampsia, or placental insufficiency or
      • Three or more unexplained consecutive spontaneous abortions before the tenth week of gestation

  • Laboratory criteria for APS include high titers of any 1 of the following three antiphospholipid antibodies on two occasions, 12 weeks apart 

    • Lupus anticoagulant (LA) - It is measured indirectly by
      • Diluted Russell's viper venom time assay (most specific) 
      • Kaolin coagulation time(KCT)
      • prolongation of aPTT
    • Anticardiolipin (aCL) antibody assay (most sensitive)
    • Anti-β2GPI (glycoprotein 1) antibodies assay

questions.text: All of the following procedures can be used in FIGO  staging of cervical cancer  as per FIGO revised 2018 report except _____________
questions.solution:
The FIGO Cancer Report 2018 no longer mandates any biochemical investigations or investigative procedures in staging of cervical cancer.

FIGO staging was based mainly on clinical examination with the addition of certain procedures that were allowed by FIGO to change the staging. However, in 2018, this has been revised by the FIGO Gynecologic Oncology Committee to allow imaging and pathological findings, where available, to assign the stage.

Other options:

  • The revised staging permits the use of any of the imaging modalities according to available resources, i.e. ultrasound, CT, MRI, positron emission tomography (PET), to provide information on tumor size, nodal status, and local or systemic spread.
  • In case a surgical specimen is available or where image-guided fine- needle aspiration cytology has been done, the pathologic report is an important source for accurate assessment of the extent of disease.
  • Diagnosis of Stage IA1 and IA2 is made on microscopic examination of a LEEP (loop electrosurgical excision procedure) or cone biopsy specimen.

questions.text: Optic nerve injury following sinus surgery (FESS) is due to removal of which of the following ethmoidal cells?
questions.solution:
Onodi cell is the posterior ethmoidal cell, related superiorly or laterally to the sphenoid sinus. The optic nerve lies in its lateral wall and can be injured while operating in the cells.

Option A: Haller cells are a type of ethmoidal cells that are situated on the roof of the maxillary sinus. Sometimes they may enlarge and block the opening of the maxillary sinus leading to maxillary sinusitis.

Option B: Agger nasi is an elevation just anterior to the attachment of middle turbinates.

Option D: Bulla ethmoidalis is the ethmoidal cell situated behind the uncinate process and forms the posterior boundary of hiatus semilunaris through which the maxillary, frontal and anterior ethmoidal sinuses drain.

questions.text: A 2-month-old infant was brought to the emergency with symptoms of cyanosis, rapid breathing, and failure to thrive. The chest X-ray of the child is given below. Probable diagnosis is ____________
questions.solution:
The image given above shows a snowman or figure of 8 appearance. The probable diagnosis in the above case is Total Anomalous Pulmonary Venous Connection.

TAPVC: Pulmonary veins instead of draining into left atrium drain into right atrium directly or indirectly. Following types are seen:

  • Supracardiac (most common): Common pulmonary vein drains into superior vena cava or the left innominate vein
  • Cardiac: Pulmonary veins drain into right atrium or coronary sinus.
  • Infracardiac (always obstructive and most dangerous): Pulmonary veins drain into hepatic vein or portal vein or inferior vena cava.

Snowman appearance is classically seen in supracardiac variant of TAPVC. The dilated vertical vein on the left, brachiocephalic vein on top, and the superior vena cava on the right form the head of the snowman; the body of the snowman is formed by the enlarged right atrium.

questions.text:
A 7 year old boy was brought to hospital with complaints of day dreaming and a decline in school performance. His EEG was done which showed generalized 3 Hz spike wave activity occurring synchronously over both hemispheres as seen below:
Horizontal calibration : 1 sec
True statement is ___________

choices.text: Associated with head drop during seizure

questions.solution:
The 3 Hz spike and wave pattern given in the image above is characteristic of typical absence seizures. 

Drug of choice for simple childhood absence seizures is ethosuximide.

Absence seizures Atypical absence seizure
  • No change in body tone
  • Change in the tone of head and body
  • Precipitated by hyperventilation
  • Precipitated by drowsiness
  • 3Hz spike and wave pattern on EEG
  • 1-2 Hz spike and slow-wave pattern of EEG
  • Usually not associated with other syndromes
  • Associated with Lennox -Gestaut syndrome  

Lennox-Gastaut syndrome: (Option D)

  • Typically starts between the age of 2 and 10 years.
  • Consists of a triad of
    • Developmental delay
    • Multiple seizure types (includes atypical absences, myoclonic, astatic, and tonic seizures)
    • EEG findings 1-2 Hz spike and slow waves, polyspike bursts in sleep, and a slow background in wakefulness
  • Patients will have long-term cognitive impairment and intractable seizures despite multiple therapies.

questions.text: Psoriatic plaques may be encircled by a clear halo or ring of Woronoff. This is formed due to which of the following changes around the plaque?
questions.solution:
As a result of ultraviolet light and coal tar therapy, a white ring (Woronoff's Ring) may develop in the normal skin adjacent to psoriatic plaques due to decreased PGE2 synthesis.

  • Typical psoriatic lesions are erythematous, scaly, plaques which are sharply delineated from surrounding unaffected skin.
  • The plaques are encircled by a clear peripheral zone of hypopigmentation, usually following phototherapy or coal tar therapy, called the halo or ring of Woronoff.
  • This is possibly formed due to local inability to synthesize PGE2 in response to an ultraviolet light stimulus, resulting from an inhibitor of prostaglandin synthesis.

Woronoff ring:

questions.text: Phenobarbitone is used to treat which of the following hyperbilirubinemia?
questions.solution:
Phenobarbitone is used in the treatment of Crigler-Najjar syndrome type 2.

Crigler-Najjar type 2 patients have a decreased UDP-glucuronyl transferase (UDPGT) activity. Phenobarbitone acts by increasing the activity of UDPGT enzyme. The presence of UDPGT enzyme is crucial for the drug's action. It helps convert unconjugated bilirubin to conjugated form at a faster rate.

However, Crigler-Najjar type 1 syndrome has a complete absence of UDPGT enzyme. Therefore, these patients do not respond to Phenobarbitone.

Crigler Najjar type 1 Crigler Najjar type 2

Autosomal recessive

Autosomal recessive > dominant

Complete absence of UDPG-T activity.

 Decreased UDPG-T activity 
 

Kernicterus in >50% 

Kernicterus is usually not seen. 
Requires exchange transfusion and no effect on treatment with phenobarbitone. Responds to phenobarbitone therapy
  • Gilbert syndrome: Partial deficiency of UDPGT caused by polymorphism.  It is more common, affecting 5–10%. It occurs after puberty. It is not associated with chronic liver disease and no treatment is required. Treatment is usually not warranted.
  • Dubin Johnson syndrome: Absent function of multiple drug-resistant protein 2. Due to an accumulation of epinephrine metabolite, a black liver is seen on biopsy.

questions.text: Brooke's formula for fluid resuscitation in a burns patient  is given by?
questions.solution:
Brooke's formula for fluid resuscitation in a burns patient is correctly given by: 

  • Crystalloids - 1.5ml/ kg per % of burn
  • Colloids - 0.5ml/kg per % of burn
  • Free Water - 2000 ml of glucose in water

Important formulas in resuscitation of burns patient:

Formula Crystalloids Colloids Free water
Parkland 4ml/kg per % burn None None
Brooke 1.5ml/ kg per% burn 0.5ml/kg per% burn 2000ml glucose in water

Galveston*

(Pediatric)

 5000ml/m2 burn + 2000ml/m2 total area None None
Evans (1952) 1ml/kg per % burn 1ml/kg per % burn 2000ml glucose in water

*The Galveston pediatric formula is wrongly given in Sabiston 20th edition.The correct formula is as mentioned above.

Note:

According to latest ATLS guidlines 10th edition 2018, the resuscitation formula for burns in adults is 2ml/kg per % of burn.

Related Pearl: Burns – Formulae for Fluid Calculation(Updated according to ATLS 10th edition 2018 guidelines)

Parkland’s formula gives the total fluid requirement for 24hours. Half of this volume is infused in the first 8 hours, and the remaining half is infused in the next 16 hours.

This formula is recommended for those who have sustained large deep partial-thickness or full-thickness burns that cover more than 20% of the TBSA in adults and more than 10% in children. 

Formulas provide a starting target rate; Subsequently, the amount of fluid provided should be adjusted based on urine output.

Category of burn Age Amount of Ringer’s Lactate given for 24 hours (ml) Target urine output (ml/kg/hour)
2nd/3rd-degree burns Adults  2 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 0.5
<14 years 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1
< 1 year or <30kgs 3 x weight in kgs x % TBSA + 5% dextrose on a maintenance rate 1
4th-degree burns / Electrical burns All ages 4 x weight in kgs x % TBSA 1-1.5 (until urine clears)

Dextrose maintenance:

  • 100 ml/ kg in 24 hours for 10 kg
  • 50 ml/kg for next 10 kg
  • 20 ml/kg for every kg after 20 kg

Evan’s formula is used for normal saline.

For the first 24 hours:

  • Amount of NS administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • Amount of colloid administered = weight in kgs x % TBSA
  • 5% Dextrose administered= 2000 ml

After 24 hours, the amount of NS and colloid administered is half. 2000 ml of dextrose is maintained.

Muir and Barclay’s formula for colloids:

  • 1 portion of colloid = (weight in kgs x % TBSA)/2
  • 6 portions of colloid are administered over 36 hours

questions.text: True for bacterial vaginosis (BV) is all except?

choices.text: Nugent's criteria aids in the diagnosis of BV
Amsel’s criteria is used for the diagnosis of BV

questions.solution:
Bacterial vaginosis is termed vaginosis is associated with alteration in the normal vaginal flora i.e. decrease in the number of lactoba­cilli in the vaginal discharge with 100-fold increase in growth of other anaerobic bacteria namely Haemophilus vaginalis, Gardnerella, Mobiluncus and Myco­plasma hominis.

  • Bacterial vaginosis (BV) is the most common cause of vaginitis.
  • Nugent's criteria is used to quantify or grade bacteria via Gram stain of vaginal samples.
    • In brief, Nugent's criteria evaluate 3 types of bacteria via Gram stain: Lactobacillus, Bacteroides/Gardnerella, and Mobiluncus.
    • They are each graded on a scale of 1-4 (1+ is < 1 cell per field, 2+ is 1-5 cells per field, 3+ is 6-30 cells per field, and 4+ is >30 cells per field).
    • In this system, Lactobacillus and Bacteroides/Gardnerella are given scores between 0-4 but Mobiluncus is only graded from 0-2.
    • Total scores are then calculated and used as follows: 0-3 (Normal), 4-6 (intermediate bacterial count), and 7-10 (bacterial vaginosis).
  • Amsel’s criteria is used for diagnosis of bacterial vaginosis which includes
    • Homogenous vaginal discharge
    • Vaginal pH > 4.5
    • Amine like odour on adding KOH (Whiff test positive)
    • Clue cells (>20% of cells)
  • Atleast 2 of the four criteria should be present to confirm diagnosis.

Related Pearl: Vaginal infections

questions.text: False statement about Employee State Insurance (ESI) act is ___________

choices.text: Employee contributes 0.75% of his daily wage
Employer contributes 3.25% of the employees' daily wage
1/8th medical benefit is provided by the central government
7/8th medical benefit is provided by the ESI corporation

questions.solution:
The state government share of expenditure on medical care is 1/8, the ESI corporation's share of expenditure on medical care is 7/8 of total cost. State and Central government share medical expenditure in the ratio 1:7.

Note:

According to the latest ESI update(w.e.f 01/07/2019) the employer contributes 3.25% and the employee contributes 0.75% of the wages.

Related Pearl: ESI ACT, 1948

Employees State Insurance Act, 1948 (Revised in 2019)

Scope: It is applicable to all factories in India excluding:

  • Defence 
  • Railway  
  • Mines 

Finance Contribution

  • It covers all employees getting income up to Rs.21,000/- per month.
  • Employee – 0.75% of his daily wage.
  • Employer – 3.25% of the employees' daily wage.
  • Medical benefit – 1/8th by the state government and 7/8th by the ESI Corporation.

Benefits

To the Employees

  • Medical Benefit- full medical care is provided free of cost in case of sickness, employment injury, and maternity.
  • Sickness Benefit- is given at 70% of average daily wages for a duration of 91 days in one year. In order to qualify for sickness benefit, the worker is required to contribute for 78 days in a period of 6 months.
    • Extended sickness benefit – 80% of the daily wages for a duration of 2 years, for 34 specified diseases such as TB, leprosy, malignant diseases, diabetes, Parkinson's, myasthenia gravis, glaucoma, coronary artery disease, etc.
    • Enhanced sickness benefit – at full wages for sterilization procedure; for a duration of 7 days post-vasectomy and 14 days post tubectomy. 
    • The total amount payable is double the standard sickness benefit rate, that is, equal to full wages.
  • Maternity Benefit – benefit is payable at full wages for 26 weeks (6.5 months) for pregnancy, 6 weeks following a miscarriage, and 30 days for sickness arising out of pregnancy. It also covers the premature birth of a child born to an insured woman.
  • Dependance Benefit– in case of death, as a result of employment injury, the dependents of an insured person are eligible for periodical payments. Pension at the rate of 90% of the wages is payable, shared by dependants in a fixed ratio, on monthly basis in accordance with the prescribed share. An eligible son or daughter is entitled to the dependant's benefit up to the age of 18; the benefit is withdrawn if the daughter marries earlier.
  • Disablement Benefits–
    • Temporary disability- at 90% daily wages as long as the person is disabled.
    • Permanent disability- lifetime pension. It also covers occupational diseases.
  • Funeral Benefit – a maximum of Rs.15,000/-.
  • Rehabilitation Benefit- on payment of Rs.10, the insured person and his/her family continue to get medical treatment after permanent disablement or retirement.

To the Employers

  • Exemption from Workman Compensation Act.
  • Exemption from Maternity Benefit Act.
  • Income tax rebate on the amount contributed towards the scheme.
  • Exemption from payment of medical allowance to employees and their dependants, or arranging for their medical care.
  • Healthy-work force.

Related Pearl: The Factories act, 1948 and The Maternity Act, 2017

The Factories act,1948

The act defines a factory as an establishment employing 10 or more workers where power is used, and 20 or more workers where power is not used. 

Provisions in the age of employment are:

  • Children <14 years are prohibited from working.
  • Adolescents between 15-18 years:
    • Can be employed only in certain industries.
    • They can work only between 6 AM – 7 PM.
    • They should not be made to work for more than four and a half hours.
    • They are allowed to take leave once every 15 days and have an accumulated leave of up to 40 days.

For adults, the maximum hours of work for an industrial worker should be not more than 48 hours per week, not exceeding 9 hours a day. If working overtime, then it should be no more than 60 hours per week including overtime.

Per capita space availability: For factories established after 1948 – min 500cuft / person

Safety and welfare measures include the provision of the following:

  • > 1000 Workers – Safety officer
  • > 500 Workers – Welfare officer
  • > 250 Workers – Canteen
  • > 50 employees - Crèche

The Maternity Act, 2017 is a landmark law that has enhanced the duration of paid maternity leave:

  • Working mothers - 12-26 weeks
  • Working mothers, with 2 surviving children - 12 weeks
  • Adopting mother and commissioning mothers- 12 weeks from the date on which the child is being handed over to the mother.

According to Indian Maternity Benefit (Amendment) Act, 2017: Effective as of the 1st of July 2017, mandatory crèche (daycare) facilities for every establishment employing 50 or more employees (inclusive of men and women).

questions.text: Transport of ADP in and ATP out of mitochondria is inhibited by _____________
questions.solution:
Atractyloside is an antibiotic which inhibits oxidative phosphorylation by inhibiting the transport of ADP into and ATP out of the mitochondria. It blocks the flow of protons through ATP synthase.

questions.text: A 12-year-old girl has had a history of recurrent bulky stools and abdominal pain since 3 years of age. She has pallor, and her weight and height are below the 3rd percentile. Which of the following is the most appropriate investigation to make a specific diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A small intestinal biopsy can help diagnose documented steatorrhea or chronic diarrhea (>3 weeks). Failure to thrive in the setting of recurrent bulky stools and abdominal pain suggests a diagnosis of chronic malabsorption.

Endoscopy is the preferred method of obtaining histologic material from the proximal small-intestinal mucosa.

The other options are not specific tests used to confirm malabsorption syndromes.

Lesions seen on small-bowel biopsy can be classified into three categories according to their distribution and specificity of findings; diseases in which these lessons are seen and the associated pathologic findings are given below:

Lesions Pathologic Findings
Diffuse, Specific 
Whipple disease Lamina propria includes macrophages containing material positive on periodic acid–Schiff staining
Patchy, Specific 
Crohn disease Noncaseating granulomas
Diffuse, Nonspecific 
Celiac disease Short or absent vill, mononuclear infiltrate, epithelial cell damage,  hypertrophy of crypts
Folate deficiency Short villi, decreased mitosis in crypts, megalocytosis
Zollinger-Ellison syndrome   Mucosal ulceration and erosion from acid

Related Pearl: Investigations in Malabsorption Syndrome

questions.text: Clomiphene  in the uterine tissue is primarily a
questions.solution:
Clomiphene is a pure estrogen antagonist in the uterus, cervix and vagina.

Clomiphene is classified as a Selective Estrogen Receptor Modulator (SERM) as it has two isomers trans-clomiphene, a potent estrogen antagonist and cis-clomiphene, a weak estrogen agonist. SERMs have different actions (agonist/antagonist) in different tissues. 

Clomiphene is primarily used for the treatment of anovulation in the setting of an intact hypothalamic-pituitary axis and adequate estrogen production (e.g., PCOS) or to induce superovulation in women with unexplained infertility.

Clomiphene increases FSH levels and thereby enhances follicular maturation by inhibiting the negative-feedback effects of estrogen at hypothalamic and pituitary levels.

questions.text: True about methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) are all except:

choices.text: It is mediated by mecA gene
Vancomycin is the drug of choice
PV toxin is associated with CA-MRSA (Community acquired MRSA)

questions.solution:
Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded.

  • It alters PBP (penicillin binding protein) present on S.aureus cell membrane to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.
  • PV toxin - Panton Valentine Leukocidin toxin is associated with CA-MRSA (community-acquired MRSA)
  • Vancomycin is the drug of choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • DOC for nasal carriers of MRSA- mupirocin 2% ointment.

questions.text: Bonney's test demonstrates ____________
questions.solution:
Bonney's test is a test for detecting stress incontinence.

Bonney's test is also used to anticipate the clinical effect of a suspension operation in relation to cure urinary incontinence. Using the index and middle fingers, the paraurethral tissue is lifted and the patient is asked for coughing or Valsalva provocation with a full bladder.

questions.text: Which of the following sinus opens into superior meatus ?
questions.solution:
Posterior ethmoidal sinus opens into superior meatus.

Related Pearl: Structures opening into meatuses of nose

  • Inferior meatus: Nasolacrimal duct, guarded by the valve of Hasner
  • Middle meatus: Frontal sinus, maxillary sinus, anterior ethmoidal sinus. All these together form the osteo-meatal complex or Picadle’s circle.
  • Superior meatus: Posterior ethmoidal sinus
  • Sphenoethmoidal recess: Sphenoid sinus

questions.text:
Choose the option with correct matches:
Term Description
1. Puppe's Rule a. Surgical Intervention of a firearm wound leading to an artefact

2. Kennedy Phenomena

 b. Planting a bullet inside a stab wound
3. Rayalseema Phenomenon c. Relationship between trauma and new growth
4. Ewing's Postulates d. Chronological sequence of bullets fired
questions.solution:
The correct match would be as follows:

Term Description
1. Puppe's Rule d.Chronological sequence of bullets fired

2. Kennedy Phenomena

 a. Surgical Intervention of a firearm wound leading to an artefact
3. Rayalseema Phenomenon b.Planting a bullet inside a stab wound 
4. Ewing's Postulates c. Relationship between trauma and new growth

 

Puppe's rule: Helps in determining the sequence of bullets to hit the skull, when there are multiple bullet injuries to skull. The fracture line resulting from the later bullet will typically stop at the previously formed one.

Kennedy's phenomenon: Surgical intervention of a firearm wound leading to an artefact as the evaluation of wound as entry or exit wound becomes difficult.

Rayalaseema phenomenon: Here a person is killed by stab injury, and a bullet is implanted inside to mislead the investigation.

Ewing's postulates: Establishes a relationship between trauma and new growth.

The following postulates should be satisfied before a relationship between trauma and new growth is accepted:

  • Evidence of previous integrity of the injured part.
  • Undeniable and adequate trauma must be proved.
  • There must be a proof of reasonable time interval between injury and appearance of tumour.
  • Disease must develop at the exact site of injury.
  • The nature of the tumour must be proved.

questions.text: A patient presents with carcinoma of the larynx involving the left false cord, left arytenoids and left aryepiglottic folds. The true vocal cords are bilaterally mobile. Treatment of choice is:
questions.solution:
The appropriate treatment for the above patient would be Vertical Hemilaryngectomy.

In this patient:

  • Involvement of unilateral false cord, aryepiglottic folds and arytenoids with mobile cord suggest supraglottic cancer in T2 stage (more than one subsites of supraglottis are involved).
  • For T2 stage best is radiotherapy but not given option. So, will go for voice conserving surgery - vertical hemilaryngectomy.
  • Vertical hemilaryngectomy means excision of one half of larynx, one half of supraglottis, glottis and subglottis.
Types of laryngectomy Parts Removed Indications
Hemilaryngectomy Removal of one vertical half of larynx
  • Subglotic extension <1cm below true vocal cord
  • A mobile affected cord
  • Unilateral involvement
  • No cartilage invasion
  • No extra laryngeal soft tissue involvement
  • For tumours with a T stage of T1,T2 or T3 by pre epiglottic involvement only vocal cords are mobile.
Near total laryngectomy More extended partial laryngectomy procedure in which only one arytenoid is preserved and a tracheosophageal conduit is constructed for speech. This procedure is not offered to patients whose radiation treatments have failed, those with poor pulmonary reserve, or those with tumor invovement below the cricoid ring. Candidates are patients with large T3 and T4 lesions with one uninvolved arytenoid, or with unilateral transglottic tumors with cord fixation.
Total laryngectomy Entire larynx + thyroid + cricoid cartilages are removed along with some upper tracheal rings and hyoid bone, if possible
  • T3 and T4 cancers not amenable to the above partial laryngectomy procedures or organ preservation therapy with chemoradiation, 
  • Extensive involvement of thyroid or cricoid cartilage, 
  • The direct invasion of surrounding soft tissues of the neck, 
  • Tongue base involvement beyond the circumvallate papillae.

questions.text: Which of the following feature is not common to arteritic and non-arteritic anterior ischemic optic neuropathy (AION)?
questions.solution:
Cranial nerve palsies are seen only in the case of arteritic AION.

Features common to both Arteritic AION Non-arteritic AION
Age > 40years >60years 40-60years
Vision loss is sudden, reduced color vision, altitudinal or central field defect Usually severe vision loss Usually moderate vision loss
Usually painless, usually no episodes of prior amaurosis Headache, scalp tenderness, jaw claudication, polymyalgia rheumatica, cranial nerve palsies. Temporal artery biopsy – giant cell granuloma. Associated with hypertension, diabetes, nocturnal hypotension.
 

ESR >40mm in the first hour

Treatment: steroids

ESR 20-40mm in the first hour.

Treatment: carbidopa-levodopa tried, not found to be effective.

questions.text: All of the following are decreased in depression except __________
questions.solution:
Cortisol is increased (not decreased) in depression. Hypercortisolism occurs in depression due to elevated Hypothalamopituitary axis activity.

Hypercortisolemia in depression suggests one or more of the following central disturbances: decreased inhibitory serotonin tone; increased drive from nor­epinephrine, ACh, or corticotropin-releasing hormone (CRH); or decreased feedback inhibition from the hippocampus.

Elevated HPA activity in depression has been documented via excretion ofurinary-free cortisol (UFC), 24-hour (or shorter time segments) intravenous (IV) collections of plasma corti­sol levels, salivary cortisol levels, and tests of the integrity of feedback inhibition.

Monoaminergic neurotransmitters are decreased in depression.

  • Norepinephrine
  • Serotonin
  • Dopamine

questions.text: Causative organism for black piedra is ______
questions.solution:
Piedraia hortae is the causative organism for black piedra. White piedra is caused by Trichosporon beigelii.

Piedra is a fungal infection of the hair characterized by the presence of firm, irregular nodules along the hair shaft. The nodules consist of fungal elements that are cemented together on the hair.

questions.text: The maneuver depicted in the following image is used as first step for a certain condition related to nasal area. The most common site of that condition in children is:

choices.text: Above the level of middle turbinate
Below the level of middle turbinate

questions.solution:
The image shows Trotter’s method in which the patient is made to sit, leaning a little forward over a basin to spit any blood and breathe quietly from the mouth. It is the first step to control epistaxis. Little’s area, situated at the anteroinferior part of the nasal septum, is the most common site of epistaxis in children and young adults.

90% of bleeds arise from Little's area, where the Kiesselbach plexus is situated on the nasal septum. 

Microtrauma due to nose pricking is the most common cause of epistaxis in children. Hypertension is the most common cause of epistaxis in the elderly.

The other sites are:

  • Woodruff’s area - Situated in the lateral nasal wall inferior to the posterior end of the inferior turbinate. Posterior epistaxis may arise from here.
  • Above the level of middle turbinate (superior meatus) - bleeding is from anterior and posterior ethmoidal vessels.
  • Below the level of middle turbinate (middle meatus) - bleeding from branches of sphenopalatine artery.

questions.text: The image given below shows an eyeball with a refractive error. All the following fundal changes can be seen in this condition, except _______.
questions.solution:
The image given above shows parallel rays of light converging at a point in front of the retina. Hence, the refractive error is myopia. All the fundal changes mentioned above can be seen in myopia, except cattle track appearance.

Cattle truck appearance is seen in branch retinal artery occlusion (not myopia).

Pathological/degenerative myopia is characterized by progressive anteroposterior elongation of the scleral envelope associated with secondary ocular changes due to mechanical stretching of the involved tissues.

Clinically patients present with defective vision, floating black opacities (muscae volitantes), and difficulty with night vision. Examination of the fundus reveals the following changes:

  • Optic disc:
    • Temporal myopic crescent
  • Retina and choroid:
    • Lacquer cracks are fine irregular yellow lines crisscrossing at the posterior pole, due to ruptures in the Bruch membrane.
    • Subretinal coin hemorrhages develop from lacquer cracks.
    • Fuchs spot: It is a raised, circular, pigmented lesion at the macula which develops after a subretinal hemorrhage has been absorbed.
    • A pale tessellated (tigroid) appearance of the fundus is seen due to diffuse attenuation of the RPE with large choroidal vessels.
    • Lattice degeneration
  • Vitreous: Posterior vitreous detachment (PVD) appears as Weiss' reflex.
  • Posterior staphyloma.

The image given below shows fundal changes seen in pathological myopia.

Related Pearl: Causes of Myopia

Myopia

Etiology

Axial myopia

(Most common)

Increase in the anteroposterior length of the eyeball.

Curvatural myopia

Increased curvature of the cornea, lens, or both

Positional myopia

Anterior placement of the crystalline lens in the eye

Index myopia

Increase in the refractive index of crystalline lens

Nocturnal myopia

Due to spherical aberration and accomodation

Related Pearl: Grading of Myopia

American Optometric Association (AOA) Grading of Myopia:

  • Low myopia, when the error is < –3D.
  • Moderate myopia, when the error is between -3D to -6D.
  • High myopia, when the error is > –6D.

Photorefractive keratectomy (PRK)

Refractive lens exchange

questions.text: Accommodative esotropia is more common in ______________
questions.solution:
Accommodative esotropia is more common in hypermetropia. But it may also occur in Anisometropia>1D

Accommodative esotropia is inward deviation of the visual axes caused by high hyperopia or a high accommodative convergence-to-accommodation ratio, or both.

Accommodative esotropia has an average age of onset of 2½ years (usual range, 1 −7 years). 

The esotropia usually occurs when the child first becomes interested in viewing near objects. It is frequently first seen by the parents when the child is tired or not feeling well; in fact, the onset may be precipitated by a febrile illness.

As many as half of all children with esotropia either obtain normal ocular alignment or obtain a significant but not complete reduction of the esotropia when wearing an optical correction for hyperopia.

Esotropia begins as intermittent strabismus. When treatment is delayed or not provided, many deviations become constant, and sensory adaptations such as amblyopia, suppression, and anomalous retinal correspondence may develop with loss of binocular vision.

 

Related Pearl: Classification of Strabismus

  • Pseudostrabismus—Apparent squint
    • Pseudo esotropia
    • Pseduo exotropia
  • Heterophoria—Latent squint
    • Esophoria: Convergent
    • Exophoria: Divergent
    • Hyperphoria: Deviation upwards
    • Hypophoria: Deviation downwards
    • Cyclophoria: Rotation around AP axis
  • Heterotropia—Manifest squint
  • Concomitant
    • Amount of deviation remains constant in all directions of gaze.
    • Esotropia: Convergent
      • Infantile
      • Accommodative
      • Sensory
      • Consecutive
    • Exotropia: Divergent
      • Congenital
      • Primary
      • Secondary: Sensory deprived
      • Consecutive
    • Hypertropia: Vertical squint
  • Incomitant
    • Amount of deviation varies in different directions of gaze
      • Paralytic squint
      • Restrictive squint
      • A and V pattern heterotropia

questions.text: A 50 year old smoker presents with pain along the left arm and ptosis. His chest radiograph shows a soft tissue opacity at the left lung apex with destruction of adjacent ribs. This is suggestive of:
questions.solution:
The clinical picture is suggestive of Pancoast tumour (superior sulcus tumour).

Superior sulcus tumour results from local extension of a tumour growing in the apex of the lung with involvement of eighth cervical and 1st and 2nd thoracic nerves, with shoulder pain characteristically radiating along the ulnar distribution of the arm with radiological finding of destruction of 1st and 2nd ribs. Often Horner’s syndrome coexist.

questions.text: A 44-year-old woman has been diagnosed with breast carcinoma. Immunohistochemistry staining of a tissue biopsy specimen of this patient is given below. Which of the following statements is true regarding her condition?

choices.text: It is not associated with tP53 mutations

questions.solution:
The given immunohistochemistry (IHC) staining shows positive ER, PR (brown nucleus), and negative Her-2 (no membrane-bound brown stain) expression, which is suggestive of luminal A molecular subtype. It shows a poor response to paclitaxel.

Hormone receptors (ER, PR) are present in the nucleus. Therefore ER, PR–positive breast cancer cells will stain dark in the nucleus on IHC. Her-2 receptors are membrane-bound receptors, and hence, cells having these receptors are darkly stained on the membranes. 

Luminal A type is more commonly associated with BRCA2 mutations. 

Hormone receptor-positive tumors are responsive to hormonal chemotherapeutic agents like tamoxifen and aromatase inhibitors. In Her-2 negative cases, trastuzumab is not effective as it is a recombinant humanized monoclonal antibody directed against HER-2. 

The following image shows ER/ PR/ Her-2 positivity:

Note: At least 10% of luminal type A breast cancers express tp53 mutations. tP53 mutations are associated with triple-negative tumors as well.

Related Pearl: Molecular classification of breast cancer

*Update: Claudin low-molecular subtype is a triple-negative breast cancer with low expression of E-cadherin, with a poor prognosis. It is frequently associated with lymphocyte infiltration.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text: Which of the following instruments can be used for submucosal resection operation to remove bone or cartilage?
questions.solution:
Image B shows Luc’s forceps, which is used in submucosal resection to remove either bone or cartilage.

Other uses:

  • Caldwell–Luc operation (to remove mucosa)
  • Polypectomy (to grasp and avulse polyp)
  • Take biopsy from the nose or throat.

Other images:

  • Image A:  It shows Mollison’s mastoid retractor used in mastoidectomy to retract soft tissues after incision and elevation of flaps. It is self-retaining and hemostatic.
  • Image C: Image is of Tilley–Lichtwiz trocar and cannula, used for the puncture of the lateral wall of inferior meatus, at a point 1.5–2.0 cm from anterior end of inferior turbinate and near the attachment of concha with lateral wall.
  • Image D: The instrument is Rose’s sinus douching cannula used in irrigation of maxillary sinus, which should already have a nasoantral window due to intranasal antrostomy or Caldwell–Luc operation. Direction of the tip is indicated by the hook outside.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a variable in AIMS65 score:
questions.solution:
Systolic BP is a variable in AIMS65 score.

The AIMS65 scale is a simple and accurate risk assessment score that has been shown in some studies to predict in-hospital mortality, length of hospitalization, and treatment cost in patients with acute upper GI bleeding.
