questions.text: Arbiskov cells are seen in _____
questions.solution:
Arbiskov cells are seen in myeloblastoma or chloroma.

Chloroma

  • Also known as myeloblastoma /granulocytic sarcoma
  • Hematopoietic stem cell Tumor where myeloblasts are located at extramedullary sites
  • Most common site is skin or orbital and periorbital tissues
  • Seen in AML M2 most commonly
  • Other conditions associated are Myelodysplastic and myeloproliferative syndromes
  • Arbiskov cells are monocytes seen in myeloblastoma

questions.text: A patient presents with prominent facial erythema, telangiectasia, scattered papules, and small pustules as shown in the image. Which of the following statement is true about the condition?

choices.text: Most commonly seen in teenagers and young adults
Involvement of chest and back is common
Oral contraceptive pills aggravate this condition
Flushing reaction in response to spicy foods can be seen

questions.solution:
The clinical features in the patient including prominent facial erythema, telangiectasia, scattered papules, and small pustules (without sparing of the nasolabial fold) are suggestive of Acne rosacea, in which a flushing reaction to spicy foods can be seen.

Individuals with rosacea initially demonstrate a pronounced flushing reaction. This may be in response to heat, emotional stimuli, alcohol, hot drinks, or spicy foods.

Other options:

  • Option a: Rosacea is seen almost exclusively in adults, only rarely affecting  patients <30 years old. Acne vulgaris is most commonly seen in young adults and teenagers.
  • Option b: Rosacea rarely involves chest or back. Seen in facial convexities.
  • Option c: Oral contraceptive pills, lithium, isoniazid, androgenic steroids aggravate the pre-existing condition of acne vulgaris.

Acne Rosacea:

There are 4 subtypes:

  • Subtype 1: Erythematotelangiectatic rosacea (ETTR)
  • Subtype 2: Papulopustular rosacea (PPR)
  • Subtype 3: Phymatous rosacea (PR)
  • Subtype 4: Ocular rosacea (OR)

These subtypes are not equivalent to stages of progression.

Pathophysiology:

  • The pathophysiology of rosacea is unknown. It could be due to multiple factors.
  • The role of ultraviolet light in the causation of rosacea has been repeatedly suggested and is supported by the facial distribution (mainly on the convexities) and its occurrence on the bald (exposed) scalp of male patients.
  • The innate immune response in rosacea appears to be altered. There is increased Toll‐like receptor 2 (TLR2) activity, increased protease activity and cathelicidin production (LL‐37).
  • Demodex mite proliferation in the pilosebaceous follicles of the face has also been suggested as a possible aetiological factor in the cutaneous and ocular inflammation.
  • The pathogenesis of Ocular Rosacea seems to be closely associated with meibomian gland dysfunction.

Treatment:

  • Erythematotelangiectatic rosacea
    • Sun avoidance and protection
    • Non‐scented, colour‐free moisturizer
    • Soap‐free cleansers
    • Avoid factors that provoke flushing
    • Topical α‐receptor agonists such as brimonidine or oxymetazoline
  • Papulopustular rosacea
    • Sun avoidance, sun protection, moisturizing and cosmetic cover as for ETTR
    • Topical metronidazole, azelaic acid, ivermectin or sodium sulfacetamide and sulphur for active inflammatory lesions
    • Topical α‐receptor agonists such as brimonidine and oxymetazoline for perilesional erythema
  • Phymatous rosacea
    • As for PPR for accompanying inflammatory lesions
    • Topical skin‐peeling agent if there are large occluded follicles
    • Electrocautery or laser for telangiectases
  • Ocular rosacea
    • Daily lid hygiene
    • Oily tear‐substitute lubricating eye drops or aqueous gels

questions.text: What is the most common type of breech presentation?
questions.solution: Frank breech is the most common type of breech.

questions.text: A patient with chronic kidney disease started receiving dialysis. Which of his neurological complications can be reversed?
questions.solution:
Uremic encephalopathy in chronic kidney disease is reversible by dialysis.

Uremic encephalopathy occurs due to the aggregation of uremic toxins which in turn damages the neurons. It is seen in chronic kidney disease.

Symptoms begin with difficulty in concentrating and can progress to lethargy, confusion, seizure, cognitive impairment, and coma. Physical findings may include altered mental status, weakness, and asterixis. These findings improve with dialysis.

Electroencephalogram in uremic encephalopathy shows triphasic waves. 

Neurologic complications, which can manifest with advanced CKD and do not improve with dialysis therapy include -

  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Erectile dysfunction
  • Autonomic dysfunction
  • Restless leg syndrome (15-20%)

questions.text: Which of the following index and its component is correctly matched?

choices.text: Physical quality of life index: Literacy rate
Human development index: Life expectancy at age 1
Physical quality of life index: Life expectancy at birth

questions.solution:
The literacy rate is a component of the Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI).

The three components of PQLI are:

  1. Infant mortality rate
  2. Literacy rate
  3. Life expectancy at age 1

In the PQLI, each component is given a score of 0 to 100, where 0 is the worst performance and 100 is the best. The average of all three is taken, and then the PQLI is scored between 0 and 100. In India, PQLI is 65.

Related Pearl: HDI vs. PQLI

A decent standard of living (Real GNI per capita in PPP US$)

Knowledge (mean years of schooling and expected years of schooling)

Life expectancy at 1 year of age 

Infant Mortality rate

Literacy rate
Range 0 to +1 0 to 100

questions.text: A patient who has been under treatment for chronic lymphocytic leukemia is noted to have a rapidly progressing mass involving the spleen. Histopathology of the mass shows large cell lymphocytes with a diffuse pattern of growth. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The history of a rapidly progressing tumor involving the spleen in a patient with chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL) and showing large cell lymphocytes on histopathology suggests a likely diagnosis of Richter syndrome.

Richter syndrome refers to the transformation of CLL into a diffuse large B-cell lymphoma (DLBCL). There is a development of rapidly enlarging mass that involves a lymph node or spleen. It is an aggressive tumor and most patients with the syndrome survive less than a year.

DLBCL is the most common type of non-Hodgkin lymphoma and is characteristically of large cell type and shows a diffuse pattern of growth. The most frequent pathological abnormality seen is dysregulation of BCL6.

Mature B-cell tumors express CD19 and CD20 markers. Special subtypes of DLBCL include immunodeficiency-assosciated large B-cell lymphoma and primary effusion lymphoma.

 

Other options:

Option A: Kostmann syndrome is a form of congenital neutropenia caused by genetic mutation that leads to impaired granulocytic differentiation. 

Option B: Mantle cell lymphoma is a non-hodgkin lymphoma that presents at fifth or sixth decade and has male predominance. Clinically, there is painless lymphadenopathy and can involve spleen and gut. Morphologically, there is proliferation of small lymphocytes with irregular nuclear contours.

Option D: Burkitt lymphoma can include endemic, sporadic, and lymphoma asssociated with HIV. Almost all endemic Burkitt lymphomas are latently infected with EBV. Clinically, it presents as a mass involving the mandible or abdominal viscera. Histopathologically, the tumor has high mitotic index and contains multiple apoptotic cells. The nucelar remnants are phagocytosed by benign macrophages which give a characteristic starry sky appearance.

questions.text: In Breslau's first life test, the organ tested is :
questions.solution:
In Breslau’s first life test (also known as Hydrostatic test/ Floatation test / Raygat’s test) the organ tested is the lung. In Breslau's second life test, stomach and intestine are tested.

Breslau's second life test: It is based on the air entering stomach and intestine during respiration in a live-born foetus. The stomach and intestine are removed by tying double ligatures at each end and placed in water.

Interpretation:

  • A positive test proves live birth even in the absence of a positive hydrostatic lung test. This may happen if there had been some obstruction in the respiratory passages.
  • A negative test does not mean stillbirth since air does not necessarily enter the stomach in adequate amounts during the breathing act.
  • Putrefaction invalidates the result.

Other tests for live birth:

  • Wreden’s test – Based on changes in the middle ear after birth.
  • Fodere’s test – Based on the increase in the weight of lung due to increased blood flow after birth. The weight of unrespired lung is 30 – 40g whereas the weight of respired lung is 60 – 66g.
  • Ploucquet’s test – Based on the ratio of the weight of the lung to the weight of the body in unrespired and respired lungs.
    • Unrespired lungs - weight of lungs : weight of the body = 1:70
    • Respired lungs - weight of lungs : weight of the body = 1:35

Related Pearl: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test

It is based on the lung changes in a fetus after respiration.

Principle: Respired air remains in the lungs as residual air which cannot be removed after death. Hence lung floats in water.

False-negative test in:

  • Atelectasis
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Pneumonia
  • Congenital syphilis
  • Air absorbed from air passages if circulation continued for long time after cessation of respiration
  • More air exhaled from the lungs compared to air entering during inspiration
  • Obstruction by alveolar duct membrane

False-positive test in:

  • Putrefied foetus
  • Artificial inflation

Hydrostatic test is not required when:

  • Fetus is monstrous
  • Fetus is macerated or mummified
  • Fetus is born before 180 days of gestation
  • Stomach contains milk
  • Umbilical cord has separated and scar has been formed

questions.text: In a given population, total births in a year are 5100. 100 babies were still born and 250 neonates died within 28 days of life. What is the neonatal mortality rate in this population?
questions.solution:
• Neonatal mortality rate = Number of deaths of children under 28 days of age in a year x 1000/Total live births in the same year
  • The total live births in this scenario is 5100 – 100 = 5000 live births
  • NMR = 250 x 1000/5000 = 50

Related Pearl: Neonatal Mortality Rate

  • Neonatal deaths are those that occur during the neonatal period, commencing at birth and ending at 28 completed days after birth.
  • NMR = Number of deaths of children under 28 days of age in a year x 1000/Total live births in the same year
  • Main causes of neonatal death are prematurity (leading cause), birth asphyxia, intrapartum-related complications, sepsis, pneumonia, congenital anomalies, tetanus, diarrhea, etc.
  • India’s NMR  is 20 per 1000 live births (SRS 2020)

questions.text: Fixation at phallic phase of psychosexual development can be seen in ___________
questions.solution:
Fixation at the phallic phase of psychosexual development can be seen in hysteria. The phallic/Oedipus complex is the primary cause of hysteria and other neurotic symptoms.

The psychosexual theory was proposed by Sigmund Freud.

Phase of sexual development Disorders resulting from fixation of regression to this phase
Oral phase (birth- 1.5 years)

Alcohol dependence or drug dependence

Schizophrenia

Severe mood disorders
Anal phase (1.5-3 years) OCD
Phallic/Oedipal phase (3-5 years) Oedipus complex is the primary cause of hysteria.
Latency phase (5-12 years) Neurotic disorder
Genital phase (>12 years) Neurotic disorder

questions.text: Dent's disease is  characterized by all except ______________
questions.solution:
Dent’s disease is characterised by all except hyperphosphatemia.

  • Dent's disease is an X-linked recessive disorder caused by inactivating mutation in CLN5, a chloride transpoter expressed in endosomes of the proximal tubule (Dent disease 1) or OCRL gene mutation (Dent disease 2).
  • Features include nephrocalcinosis, hypercalciuria, hypophosphatemia and recurrent kidney stones and additional symptoms of mild intellectual disability, hypotonia and clouding of lens of eyes in dents disease 2.
  • The clinical diagnosis of Dent's disease is based on the presence of all three of the following criteria:
    • LMW proteinuria (elevation of urinary excretion of β2-microglobulin, Clara cell protein and/or RBP by at least 5-fold above the upper limit of normality)
    • Hypercalciuria (> 4 mg/kg in a 24 h-hour collection or > 0.25 mg Ca2+ per mg creatinine on a spot sample)
    • At least one of the following: nephrocalcinosis, kidney stones, hematuria, hypophosphataemia, or renal insufficiency.
  • The clinical diagnosis is supported by a history of X-linked inheritance of renal Fanconi syndrome and/or nephrolithiasis.
  • The identification of mutation in either CLCN5 or OCRL1 confirms the diagnosis.

questions.text: An HIV patient presents with dry, non-productive cough and dyspnea. Chest X-ray shows bilateral interstitial pneumonia starting along with pneumatocele. Microscopy with Gomori’s methamine silver staining showed the following. The most probable causative organism is ________
questions.solution:
The causative organism is Pneumocystis jirovecii causing pneumocystis pneumonia (PCP). On Gomori’s methamine silver staining, the cysts of P. jirovecii resemble black-coloured crushed ping pong balls against the green background.

Patients with PCP generally present with fever and a cough that is usually non-productive or productive of only scant amounts of white sputum.

The most common finding on chest x-ray is either a normal film if the disease is suspected early, or a faint bilateral interstitial infiltrates. The classic finding of a dense perihilar infiltrate is unusual in patients with AIDS.

The standard treatment for PCP or disseminated pneumocystosis is trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole.

questions.text: You are asked by senior resident to start ringers lactate in a 6 month old baby suffering from burns. You will start ringers lactate at the rate of ________
questions.solution:
In case of burns in a less than a 1-year-old child, ringers lactate should be started at 3ml/kg/%TSA.

This balances a higher resuscitation volume requirement due to the larger surface area per unit body mass with the smaller paediatric intravascular volume, increasing the risk for volume overload. Very small children (i.e., <30 kg), should receive maintenance fluids of D5-LR (5% dextrose in Lactated Ringers), in addition to the burn resuscitation fluid.

Burn resuscitation fluid rates and target urine output by burn type and age:

Category of burn Age and weight Adjusted fluid rates Urine output  
Flame or scald Adults and older children (>/= 14 years old 2ml RL/kg/%TSBA 0.5ml/kg/hr 30-50ml/hr  
  Children (< 14 years old) 3ml RL/kg/%TSBA    1ml/kg/hr  
  Infants and young children (</=30 kg) 3ml RL/Kg/%TSBA Plus a sugar-containing solution at a maintenance rate  1ml/kg/hr  
Electrical injury All ages 4ml/kg/%TSBA until urine clears  1-1.5ml/kg/hr until urine clears

questions.text: The given image is a histological section of which of the following organ?
questions.solution:
The above image shows a histological section of the epithelium of the urinary bladder also known as transitional epithelium (urothelium).

Urothelium has 4 -6 layers of thickness of cells extending from the collecting duct of the kidney to the ejaculatory duct in males and to the urogenital membrane in females. It is named transitional epithelium as it apparently changed from a stratified cuboidal epithelium to stratified squamous epithelium. It has 3 distinctive layers as follows:

  • Basal layer made of cuboidal cells which can regenerate.
  • Intermediate layer made of polygonal cells responsible for the stretch of the organ by flattening of cells.
  • Superficial layer made of umbrella-shaped multinucleated cells which are protective and impermeable.

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: Interstitial fluid volume can be calculated by using
questions.solution:
Interstitial fluid volume = ECF volume - Plasma volume

  • ECF is measured by radiolabelled sodium
  • Plasma volume is measured by radiolabelled albumin

So, radiolabelled sodium and radiolabelled albumin are used to measure the interstitial fluid volume.

  Volume Indicators
Total body water
  • 3H2O
  • 2H2O
  • antipyrine
ECF
  • 22Na
  • 125I-iothalamate
  • thiosulfate
  • inulin
ICF (Calculated as total body water − extracellular fluid volume)
Plasma volume
  • 125I-albumin
  • Evans blue dye (T-1824)
Blood volume

51Cr-labeled red blood cells

or calculated as

blood volume = plasma volume/(1 −hematocrit)
Interstitial fluid (Calculated as extracellular fluid volume − plasma volume)

questions.text: Drug efflux forms the primary mode of resistance formation in which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Efflux pumping of the drug is the primary mode of resistance for Chloroquine. It is mediated by an ABC transporter encoded by P. falciparum multidrug resistance gene 1 (Pfmdr1).

Ciprofloxacin and indinavir develop resistant mainly by reduced affinity to the altered target. 

Resistance to tetracyclines and glycylcyclines occurs by 3 mechanisms:

  • Decreased accumulation or antibiotic efflux
  • Ribosomal protection protein that displaces the drug from its target
  • Enzymatic inactivation of the drug

questions.text: All are true about Koro’s syndrome except _____________
questions.solution:
Koro’s syndrome is not specific for men. It can also be seen in women.

  • Koro is a culture-bound syndrome seen in Asia (including India). The affected male has the belief that his penis is shrinking and may disappear into his abdominal wall and he may then die.
  • Females are also affected infrequently, with a corresponding belief that their breast (and/or vulva) are shrinking.
  • It is classified under "Other Specified Obsessive-Compulsive and Related Disorder" in DSM-5.
  • Koro spreads rapidly to the other members of the community and is usually based on the culturally elaborated fears regarding nocturnal emission and masturbation (particularly in men).

  • Other culture bound syndromes:

    • Dhat syndrome is a seen in the Indian subcontinent. It is characterized by:
      • Complaint of the passage of dhat (whitish discharge: semen) in urine, multiple somatic symptoms, physical/mental exhaustion, sexual dysfunction.
      • It is based on the belief that semen is precious and loss of semen leads to exhaustion and weakness.
    • Latah (Startle Reaction) is a syndrome seen in the South-East Asia and Japan. Occurring more often in women, latah is typically characterized by the presence of automatic obedience, echolalia, and echopraxia. It is often precipitated by a sudden stimulus, such as loud sound.

questions.text: During the pre-anaesthetic evaluation of a patient, the oral cavity examined is depicted in the image given below. The image shows which class of the Mallampati score?
questions.solution:
The image of the oral cavity shows the soft palate and the base of the uvula, and is thus graded as Mallampati class III.

Mallampati classification is an important component of airway examination. It is used to assess the visibility of the faucial pillars, uvula, and soft palate in an upright position with the patient's head neutral, mouth open, tongue protruded, and no phonation. 

Higher scores indicate poor visibility of these structures due to the presence of a large tongue. Thus, Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati classes III and IV are considered features of difficult airway.

Related Pearl: Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification

Samsoon & Young's Modified Mallampati Classification is used to predict the ease of endotracheal intubation.

• Class I: The entire palatal arch, including the bilateral faucial pillars, is visible down to the bases of the pillars.
• Class II: The upper part of the faucial pillars and most of the uvula are visible.
• Class III: Only the soft and hard palates are visible.
• Class IV: Only the hard palate is visible.

Initially, the Mallampatti scoring system (1985) had only 3 classes. This was modified by Samsoon and Young to include class 4. Later class 0 was also added.

Related Pearl: Predictors of Difficult Airway

Risk factors:

  1. Obstructive sleep apnea
  2. History of snoring
  3. Obesity
  4. Facial and neck deformities from previous surgery
  5. Previous head and neck radiation
  6. Head and neck trauma
  7. Congenital abnormalities of the head and neck
  8. Rheumatoid arthritis
  9. Down syndrome
  10. Scleroderma
  11. Cervical spine disease or previous cervical spine surgery

Specific tests for assessment:

  1. Mallampati scores (III and IV)
  2. Thyromental distance less than 6 cm
  3. Sterno-mental distance <12.5 cm with head in maximum extension
  4. Increased neck circumference >17 inches in men or >16 inches in women
  5. Upper lip bite test: Inability to protrude the mandible or lower teeth in front of the upper teeth
  6. Cormack and Lehane (laryngoscopic view) - Grade III and IV

Although the presence of these risk factors may not be sensitive in detecting difficult intubation, the absence of these findings indicates ease with intubation.

questions.text: Which among the following is false about Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis?

choices.text: White nodule on the anterior surface of iris

questions.solution:
Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis is a chronic condition (not acute).

  • Fuch's heterochromic iridocyclitis consists of chronic, low-grade iritis with posterior subcapsular cataract and secondary glaucoma.
  • It is rare, unilateral in 90% of cases, occurs between the third and fourth decades of life and is associated with a change in color of the iris.
  • Anterior vitreous opacities and occasionally small white nodules may be present on the anterior surface of the iris. Secondary glaucoma has been reported in 15% of patients at presentation. Vision decreases as the cataract progresses.
  • Treatment is directed towards the management of complications of the condition, including cataract, glaucoma and occasionally, visually significant vitreous opacities. The prognosis for eyes with FHI is good, with almost all eyes achieving visual acuity of 20/40 or better.

questions.text: A 13-year-old child who weighs 70 kg weight and is a known case of hypothyroidism presents with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of hip. There is tenderness in Scarpa's triangle. On flexing the hip, the limb is externally rotated. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 13 year old obese child with hypothyroidism with limitation of abduction and internal rotation of hip and tenderness in Scarpa's triangle points towards a diagnosis of slipped femoral capital epiphysis (SCFE).

SCFE occurs during the period of rapid growth, usually during the age of 10-15 years. Risk factors include obesity, hypothyroidism, growth hormone excess, and chronic renal failure are all-important associations of SCFE.

Clinical features:

  • Pain in the thigh, groin, or knee.
  • On examination, the affected limb is shortened and externally rotated.
  • There is a limitation in abduction, flexion, and internal rotation on the affected side.
  • Flexion of the hip might lead to obligate external rotation and abduction - positive Drehmann’s sign.
  • Patients may have an antalgic or Trendelenburg gait.

Investigations:

  • Trethowan's sign is seen in the X-ray. When Klein's line does not intersect the lateral part of the superior femoral epiphysis on an AP radiograph of the pelvis, it is known as Trethowan’s sign. Klein's line is a line along the superior aspect of the femoral neck that normally is intersected by the epiphysis.
  • MRI is the investigation of choice.

Treatment consists of in-situ pinning of the epiphysis to the femoral neck.

 

Other options-

Option A: Perthes disease, also known as Legg-Calve-Perthes disease, is the avascular necrosis of the proximal femoral epiphysis. It is most commonly seen in the age group of 4-8 years. Risk factors include low birth weight, passive smoking, family history, low socioeconomic status, and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder. Perthes disease is associated with thrombophilia, protein C and S deficiencies.

Option C: Developmental dysplasia of the hip is usually diagnosed in the neonatal period. The hip will be in extension and adduction with limited abduction movement. In children of walking age, a waddling or Trendelenberg gait can be seen. 

Option D: Fracture neck of the femur is an intracapsular fracture. It is commonly seen in elderly women following a trivial fall. Osteoporosis is thought to be a major contributing factor at this age. Other risk factors include comorbidities (diabetes, chronic kidney, and liver disease), and medications (corticosteroids, proton pump inhibitors).

questions.text: A 2 years old male child is brought with pellagra like symptoms and cutaneous photosensitivity. Elder sister has similar symptoms. Two siblings are normal. The child most likely has__________

choices.text: Branched chain alpha keto acid dehydrogenase deficiency

questions.solution:
The above clinical history of pellagra like symptoms, photosensitivity in a 2 year old child with autosomal inheritance is suggestive of Hartnup disease. Hartnup disease (pellagra like dermatosis) is an autosomal recessive condition caused due to a single defect in renal and intestinal transport of tryptophan and other monoamino monocarboxylic amino acids (neutral amino acids). This results in decreased availability of tryptophan for niacin synthesis. Thus, manifesting as pellagra like symptoms.

Clinical features:

  • Most of the children are asymptomatic
  • However, major clinical manifestation in the rare symptomatic patient is, cutaneous photosensitivity
  • The skin becomes rough and red after moderate exposure to the sun and with greater exposure, a pellagra-like rash may develop. The rash maybe pruritic and chronic eczema may also appear.
  • Some patients may also have an intermittent ataxia, manifested as an unsteady wide based gait, which usually lasts for few days, and recovers spontaneously.

Diagnosis:

  • Urine testing for amino acids.
  • Diagnosis of Hartnup disease is made by showing the characteristic amino acid excretion pattern in urine. Indoles and other tryptophan degradation products in urine provide supplementary evidence of the disease.

Treatment:

  • Niacin or niacinamide supplements
  • Nicotinamide for attacks

questions.text: Which among the following IV anaesthetics does not cause myocardial depression?
questions.solution:
Etomidate, a short-acting I.V. anesthetic agent doesn’t cause myocardial depression.

Etomidate is the most cardiac stable intravenous agent due to its lack of effect on the sympathetic nervous system and on the function of the baroreceptor. Hence, etomidate is the I.V. agent of choice in patients with coronary artery disease, cardiomyopathy, and cerebral vascular disease.

Side effects of Etomidate:

  • The highest incidence of nausea and vomiting among inducing agents
  • Superficial thrombophlebitis and pain on injection
  • Adrenocortical suppression

Note: Although Ketamine has an indirect sympathetic stimulatory effect, it possesses a direct negative inotropic effect on the myocardium. Hence, ketamine has to be used cautiously in critically ill patients with shock, as they are prone to have a depletion of endogenous catecholamines. Ketamine infusion in such patients can unmask its direct negative inotropic effects and further decrease the blood pressure and cardiac output.

Hence, for this MCQ, Etomidate is the best answer.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a feature of Klippel Trenauny syndrome?

choices.text: Dilated venous system of lower limb

questions.solution:
In Kippel trenauny syndrome absence of deep venous system is a feature.

Klippel trenauny syndrome is characterized by:

  • Varicose veins , due to absence of deep venous system.
  • Hypertrophy of involved limb due to congenital AV fistulas.
  • Presence of cutaneous hemangiomas.

questions.text: Positive quadruple test for Down's syndrome will show all of the following results except _________
questions.solution:
Positive quadruple test for down syndrome will show decreased MSAFP (not increased).

Quadruple test is the second trimester measurement of maternal serum alpha fetoprotein (MSAFP), unconjugated estriol, hCG and inhibin-A. It is done between 15-20 weeks.

The abnormalities seen on quadruple screen are tabulated below:

 

Trisomy 21

(Down's syndrome)

 Trisomy 18

Neural tube defect or Abdominal wall defect
MSAFP Low Low High
β hCG High Low Normal
Unconjugated estriol Low Low Normal
Inhibin A High Low Normal

Dual Test is done in the first trimester while triple and quadruple tests are done in the second trimester.

Changes seen in Down's syndrome are:

Dual test Triple test Quadruple test
Beta HCG increased Beta HCG increased Beta HCG increased
PAPPA decreased Unconjugated estriol decreased Unconjugated estriol decreased
  MSAFP decreased MSAFP decreased
    Serum inhibin increased

questions.text: Acrodynia is seen in poisoning with which of the following metals?
questions.solution:
Acrodynia, or pink disease, is seen in chronic mercury poisoning.

Acrodynia is the dermatological manifestation of mercury poisoning. Children are usually affected by this hypersensitivity reaction. It is characterized by sweating and skin rash, with hands and feet becoming puffy, pinkish, and painful. Associated paresthesia and skin peeling are also seen.

Features of chronic mercury poisoning include:

  • Hydrargyrism - These patients have Danbury tremors, which are coarse, intentional tremors. The advanced condition is called Hatter's shakes/ Glass blower's shakes
  • Acrodynia (pink disease)
  • Minimata disease - caused by the eating of fish poisoned by mercury
  • Erethism - these are psychological symptoms due to mercury toxicity seen in mirror manufacturing firms. It is characterised by shyness, timidity, irritability, loss of confidence, mental depression, loss of memory, and insomnia
  • Mercuria lentis - peculiar eye changes due to exposure to mercury vapor.

Related Pearl: Mercury Poisoning

Mercury

Elemental - Respiratory tract (negligible through GI unless the mucosa is damaged)

binds to sulhydryl groups of enzymes and affects

  • glutathione metabolism

  • Mercuria lentis
  • Membranous colitis 
  • Minimata disease
  • Membranous glomerulopathy

E-Erethism (personality disturbance, insomnia, and loss of memory)

A-Acrodynia (Pink disease)

Diagnosis Blood and/or 24 hour urine mercury level
Treatment BAL; succimer(DMSA)

questions.text: False about Wilm's tumor is?

choices.text: WAGR & Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome are associated with chromosome 11p defect
Most common finding is asymptomatic abdominal mass
Most common renal neoplasm of childhood

questions.solution:
90% of Wilms tumors are due to somatic mutations and are not inherited. The 10% that is inherited shows an autosomal dominant pattern. It is the most common renal neoplasm of childhood.

Clinical feature: Most common clinical finding is asymptomatic abdominal mass. Hematuria, hypertension, fever, weight loss, tumor rupture causing acute abdomen are other presentations of the disease. The most common site of metastasis of Wilm's tumor is lungs.

Microscopy: The classic triphasic combination of blastemal (small, round blue cells), stromal, and epithelial cell types is observed in most lesions, although the percentage of each component is variable.

Nephrogenic rests are precursor lesions of Wilms tumors.

  • Wilm's tumor is associated with WAGR syndrome - Wilms tumor, aniridia, genital anomalies, and mental retardation. Individuals with WAGR syndrome have constitutional (germline) deletions of 11p13.
  • Wilms tumor is associated with Beckwith- Wiedemann syndrome (BWS), characterized by neonatal hypoglycemia, macrosomia, macroglossia, hemihyperplasia, omphalocele, embryonal tumors such as Wilms tumor, visceromegaly, adrenocortical cytomegaly, renal abnormalities, and ear creases/pits. BWS is an example of a disorder of genomic imprinting. The genetic locus that is involved in these patients is in band p15.5 of chromosome 11 distal to the WT1 locus.
  • Denys-Drash syndrome (DDS), have an even higher risk (approximately 90%) of Wilms tumor.
  • WAGR syndrome and DDS are associated with WT1 inactivation, whereas Beckwith-Wiedemann arises through imprinting abnormalities at the WT2 locus.

questions.text: A 11 year old child presented with pain in left knee.  X ray of knee joint is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is chondroblastoma.

Chondroblastoma:

  • It is a benign tumour of childhood. It is mostly seen in teenagers. 
  • It is most commonly seen at the epiphyses, usually at the ends of long bones.
  • They appear as a round or oval lytic lesion ranging in size from 1 to 7 cm on X-ray. They appear within the epiphysis or apophysis and can cross the physis.
  • They typically present with pain and can occasionally cause a joint effusion or stiffness.

Other options:

  • Osteosarcoma: X-RAY findings
  • Irregular destruction in the metaphysis overshadowed by the formation of new bone.
  • There is lifting of the periosteum due to the formation of new bone inciting a periosteal reaction.
  • Bone formation along the blood vessels within the tumour centrifugally gives rise to sunray appearance on radiograph.
  • Giant cell tumour: There are four characteristic radiographic features when a GCT is located in a long bone:
    • Occurs only with a closed growth plate (fused epiphysis)
    • Abuts articular surface: 84-99% come within 1 cm of the articular surface
    • Well defined with non-sclerotic margin (though < 5% may show some sclerosis)
    • Eccentric
  • Aneurysmal Bone Cyst: Radiographs demonstrate sharply defined, expansile osteolytic lesions, with thin sclerotic margins.

questions.text: Bilateral posterior iliac horns shown below are characteristic of:
questions.solution:
Bilateral posterior iliac horns ("Fong prongs")  are characteristic of nail-patella syndrome. They are seen due to exostoses arising from the posterior aspect of the iliac bones.

Nail-patella syndrome: Also known as Fong disease or osteo-onychodysostosis. It may also be referred to as Österreicher-Turner syndrome or Turner-Kieser syndrome.

It is a rare autosomal dominant condition which results from symmetrical mesodermal and ectodermal abnormalities. The key feature is absent/hypoplastic nails from birth. Individuals may have flexion contractures and recurrent knee dislocations.

Diagnostic radiographic findings include:

  • Absent/hypoplastic patellae (with a tendency of recurrent dislocation)
  • Hypoplasia of the radial head or capitulum (leading to subluxation/dislocation)
  • Bilateral posterior iliac horns ("Fong prongs")
  • Protuberant anterior iliac spines

questions.text: The number of ATPs generated due to the action of glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate dehydrogenase in the glycolytic pathway is ___________
questions.solution:
During glycolysis, each glucose molecule gives two molecules of Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate. Glyceraldehyde -3- phosphate dehydrogenase converts each glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate to bisphosphoglycerate, yielding 1 NADH and hence 2.5 ATPs (1 NADH = 2.5 ATP). Therefore,  Glyceraldehyde -3- phosphate dehydrogenase acts on 2 molecules of Glyceraldehyde-3-phosphate to yield 5 ATPs.

Steps of ATP production in glycolysis:

Reaction Enzyme Method of ATP produced Net ATP produced per glucose mol
Glyceraldehyde-3 phosphate to 1,3 bisphosphoglycerate Glyceraldehyde 3 phosphate dehydrogenase From 2 molecules of NADH via respiratory chain oxidation 5 ATP (2*2.5 per NADH)
1,3 bisphosphoglycerate to 3 phosphoglycerate Phosphoglycerate kinase Substrate level phosphorylation 2 ATP
Phosphoenolpyruvate to pyruvate Pyruvate kinase Substrate level phosphorylation 2 ATP
      Total = 9 ATP

2 molecules of ATP get utilized in the previous steps of glycolysis, catalyzed by the enzymes Hexokinase and PFK-1. Hence, net ATP generation in aerobic glycolysis is 9-2 = 7 ATP.

questions.text: When NaCl is injected in the internal carotid artery it causes release of ADH from ______________
questions.solution:
When NaCl is injected in the internal carotid artery it causes release of ADH from supraoptic nucleus.

On injecting NaCl, there is increase in the osmolality. Osmoreceptors have stimulatory action on thirst centre and ADH secreting supraoptic nucleus. Increased effective osmotic pressure of plasma thus increases sectretion of ADH (vasopressin).

These osmoreceptors located in the anterior hypothalamus (Supraoptic nucleus), are outside the blood-brain barrier and appear to be located in the circumventricular organs, primarily the organum vasculosum of the lamina terminalis (OVLT).

Related Pearl: Summary of Stimuli affecting Vasopressin Secretion

Increased vasopressin secretion

Decreased vasopressin secretion

Increased effective osmotic pressure of the plasma

Decreased ECF volume

Pain, emotions, stress, exercise

Nausea and vomiting

Standing

Angiotensin II

Clofibrate, carbamazepine

Decreased effective osmotic pressure of the plasma

Increased ECF volume

Alcohol

questions.text: Rapamycin is commonly used in all of the following except?
questions.solution:
Rapamycin is not used in multiple myeloma.

Rapamycin (sirolimus) is a fungal fermentation product that inhibits the proper functioning of a serine/threonine protein kinase in mammalian cells eponymously named mammalian target of rapamycin, or mTOR, an effector PI3 kinase signaling.

Rapamycin and its congeners, temsirolimus and everolimus, are well-established first-line drugs in post- transplant immunosuppression. More recently, mTOR inhibitors have found important applications in oncology for treatment of renal and hepatocellular cancer and mantle cell lymphomas.

questions.text: Aggregates of α-synuclein are characteristically seen in _________
questions.solution:
Aggregates of α-synuclein form Lewy bodies (eosinophilic cytoplasmic inclusion) which are characteristically seen in Parkinson's disease, Dementia with Lewy bodies & Multiple System Atrophy (Synucleinopathies).

Neural plaques (Aβ- amyloid aggregates) & Neurofibrillary tangles (aggregates of microtubules bound by tau proteins)  are characteristic of Alzheimer's disease.

Pick bodies (cytoplasmic inclusions of hyperphosphorylated tau proteins) &/or ubiquitinated TDP-43 are seen in Frontotemporal dementia. 

Prions (PrPc → PrPsc sheet [β-pleated sheet resistant to proteases]) are characteristic of Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

Related Pearl: Differential diagnosis of dementia

Condition Features
Alzheimer’s disease
  • Insidious onset
  • Short-term memory loss
  • Language deficits and spatial disorientation
  • Later, personality changes
Vascular Dementia
  • Stepwise decline
  • Early executive dysfunction
  • Cerebral infarction &/or deep white matter changes on neuroimaging
Frontotemporal dementia
(Pick’s disease)
  • Early personality changes
  • Apathy, disinhibition & compulsive behaviors
  • Frontotemporal atrophy on neuroimaging
Dementia with Lewy bodies
  • Visual Hallucination
  • Spontaneous parkinsonism
  • Fluctuating cognition
Normal-pressure hydrocephalus
  • Gait abnormalities 
  • Urinary Incontinence
  • Dementia
  • Dilated ventricles on neuroimaging
Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
(Prion disease)
  • Behavioral changes
  • Rapidly progressive
  • Myoclonus and/or seizures

questions.text: As compared to binding capacity of oxygen, how many times more is the binding capacity of carbon monoxide with Hb ?
questions.solution:
CO binds to Hb, 250 times more as compared to Oxygen.

CO combines with Hb at same point as O2. It displaces O2 and thus decreases O2 carrying capacity. It has 250 times tenacity as compared to O2.

Its curve is identical to O2- Hb dissociation curve, except that CO partial pressure at level 1/250th of those of O2 dissociation curve. Because of such low partial pressure even low concentration of CO in atmosphere is lethal.

The O2 content of blood is reduced because oxygen attached to Hb is compromised but Po2 of blood remains normal. Sincee Po2 is normal, no regulatory mechanism is activated.

Treatment by pure oxygen helps, as high alveolar pressure helps in displacing the CO- Hb. Also CO2 along with O2 helps in stimulation of respiratory centre.

questions.text: Which of the following is not an approach to health education?
questions.solution:
Health awareness approach is not an approach to health education.

Four approaches to health education:

  • Regulatory approach:Govermental intervention ,direct or indirect,designed to alter human behaviour.It may range from prohibition to imprisonment.
  • Service approach:Providing all health services needed by people at thier doorstep on the assumption that people would use them to improve their own health.
  • Health education approach:People must be educated through planned learning experiences what to do,and be informed ,educated and encouraged to make their own choice for a healthy life.
  • Primary health care approach:Full participation and active involvement in planning and delivery of health services based on principals of primary health care viz community involvement and intersectoral coordination.

Health Education vs. Propaganda

 

  Health education  Health propaganda
Knowledge Actively acquired Instilled in the mind
Skills Actively acquired Instilled
Primitive desires Disciplined Aroused
Action Reflective behaviour; trained to use judgement before acting Reflexive behaviour;Aims at impulsive action 
Emotion  Does not appeal to emotion but appeals to reason Appeals to emotion
Behaviour Process is behaviour centered  Process is information centered

questions.text: In renal trauma, if  kidney is not visualised in IVP, the next best option is:
questions.solution:
Absence of renal perfusion in a trauma patient is an indication for renal artery arteriography, which helps in framing operative strategy.

In renal trauma, major causes for non visualisation of kidney in a excretory urogram are arterial thrombosis, avulsion of the renal pedicle, vascular spasam due to severe contusion or absence of kidney (congenital or previous nephrectomy). Renal artery arteriography is the next best investigation in such patients.

Treatment of renal trauma:

  • Surgical exploration is necessary in less than 10 per cent of closed injuries; it is indicated if there is progressive blood loss or there is an expanding loin mass
  • When the kidney is irretrievably ruptured or avulsed from its pedicle, nephrectomy is the only course.
  • When a solitary kidney is sufficiently damaged to need exploration, it must be repaired. Failing this, the wound is packed firmly with gauze to stop the bleeding in the hope that some renal function may be retained when the ruptured kidney heals.

 

Related Pearl: American Association for the Surgery of Trauma (AAST) Kidney Injury Scale

GRADE  

 INJURY DESCRIPTION
I

Contusion

Microscopic or gross hematuria, urologic studies normal
  Hematoma

Subcapsular, nonexpanding, without parenchymal laceration
II

Hematoma

Nonexpanding perirenal hematoma confined to renal retroperitoneum
  Laceration

 <1 cm parenchymal depth of renal cortex without urinary extravasation
III

Laceration 

>1 cm depth of renal cortex, without collecting system rupture or urinary extravasation
IV Laceration

Parenchymal laceration extending through the renal cortex, medulla, and collecting system
  Vascular

Main renal artery or vein injury, with contained hemorrhage
V Laceration Completely shattered kidney
  Laceration   Avulsion of renal hilum, which devascularizes kidney

questions.text: The part marked "x" in the image given below consists of all, except ______.
questions.solution:
The part marked "x" in the image does not contain myosin.

Myosin forms the thick filament, while actin, troponin, and tropomyosin form the thin filament.

Thin Filaments in Sarcomere:

  • The thin filaments are polymers made up of two chains of actin that form a long double helix.
  • Tropomyosin molecules are long filaments located in the groove between the two chains in the actin. Each thin filament contains 300–400 actin molecules and 40–60 tropomyosin molecules.
  • Troponin molecules are small globular units located at intervals along with the tropomyosin molecules. Each of the three troponin subunits has a unique function:
    • Troponin T binds the troponin components to tropomyosin.
    • Troponin I inhibits the interaction of myosin with actin.
    • Troponin C contains the binding sites for the Ca 2+ that helps to initiate contraction.

Related Pearl: Microanatomy of Muscle Fibres

  • Each muscle consists of numerous muscle fibres.
  • Each skeletal muscle fibre is multi nucleated, bonded by sarcolemma, enclosing sarcoplasm, smooth muscle and cardiac muscles are uninucleated. 
  • Within the sarcoplasm, there are several hundreds of nuclei arranged in the periphery just beneath the sarcolemma.
  • The sarcoplasm also consists of evenly distributed, longitudinal threads called myofibrils.
  • Each myofibril consists of thick (myosin) and thin (actin) filaments overlapping each other.
  • The portion of myofibril which consists of thick filaments is known as A band or dark band, and the portion of a myofibril between two A bands consisting of only thin filaments is known I band or Light band.
  • Thus the A band consists of both thick and thin filaments, where as I band consists of only thin filaments.
  • In the middle of ‘A’ band, there are only thick filaments with no overlapping thin filaments. This zone is known as ‘H’ zone. In the middle of H zone, there is a dark band known as ‘M’ band.
  • In the middle of I band, there is a dark ‘Z’ disc or Krause's membrane.
  • The segment of the myofibril between two Z discs is known as the sarcomere.

questions.text: A screening test is used in the same way in two similar populations. But, the proportion of false-positive results among those who test positive in population A is higher than that among those who test positive in population B. What is the likely explanation for this finding?

choices.text: The specificity of the test is lower in population A.
The prevalence of the disease is lower in population A.
The prevalence of the disease is higher in population A.
The specificity of the test is higher in population A.

questions.solution:
The prevalence of the disease is lower in population A.

The contingency table for a test is given as:

  Disease present Disease absent
Test positive a (True Positive) b (False Positive)
Test negative c (False Negative) d (True Negative)

Since, positive predictive value (PPV) = (a/a+b) x 100

Hence, PPV is inversely related to a false-positive rate.

In the above case scenario, the false-positive rate is higher in population A, so the PPV in population A will be lower. Now, since PPV is directly proportional to prevalence, this means prevalence will be lower in population A.

 

Note: Sensitivity and specificity are the properties of a test, and they do not vary with the population.

Related Pearl: Validity of a Screening Test

  • Validity/ accuracy of a screening test depends upon the sensitivity, specificity, and predictive accuracy of the test.
  • It represents the closeness to a true value/ actual value.
  • These are the inherent properties of a screening test.
  • PPV and NPV are dependent on the Prevalence of disease.
  • Sensitivity & Specificity are independent of prevalence of disease.
Formulae 
Sensitivity      TP    
TP + FN
Specificity      TN    
FP + TN
Predictive value of a positive test (PPV)      TP    
TP + FP
Predictive value of a negative test (NPV)      TN     
TN + FN
Percentage of false positives      FP     
FP + TN
Percentage of false negatives      FN     
TP + FN
  • PPV varies directly with prevalence
  • NPV varies inversely with prevalence

questions.text: In India, dying declaration is accepted under
questions.solution:
In India, dying declaration is accepted under IEA section 32.

Other options:

  • IEA section 139: cross examination of a witness
  • IEA section 114 A: Doctrine of Adverse Inference: When a rape victim states that she did not consent, the presumption is usually in her favour.
  • IEA section 45: Expert witness

questions.text: A middle-aged woman complains of increased anxiety and repetitive thoughts of her hands being contaminated. She washes her hands repeatedly. Her thoughts are distressing but she is not able to overcome them. If she tries to hold herself from washing, it further aggravates her anxiety. The treatment of choice for this condition is:
questions.solution:
Repetitive thoughts of contamination of hand and repeated hand washing is suggestive of obsessive-compulsive disorder (OCD). Treatment of choice in OCD is cognitive behaviour therapy.

The most common form of obsessive-compulsive disorder is contamination where they have repeated thoughts of their hands being contaminated and want to wash their hands repeatedly. The patients are aware of this, but if they try to resist, it leads to anxiety.

Note: Both SSRIs and psychological therapy (CBT) are first-line treatment modalities of OCD. However, the NICE guideline mentions that psychological therapy is more effective than pharmacological therapy and should be used as first-line where possible.

questions.text: A 20 year old boy was brought to casualty with a history of RTA and head trauma. His eye opens to verbal command, he responds with inappropriate words and right hand flexes to painful stimuli and localizes pain on the left hand and both legs in extended posture. Calculate his Glasgow Coma Score (GCS).
questions.solution:
The GCS scale of this patient is E3 V3 M5, which comes to a total score of 11.

  • E3 - Eye opens to loud voice
  • M5 - Localize to pain(the score represents the best performance elicited, so a patient flexing in response to a painful stimulus on the right and localising pain on the left scores ‘M5’.)
  • V3 - Inappropraiate words.

Related Pearl: Glasgow Coma Scale (GCS)

GCS Score

  • 13-15 represent mild injury
  • 9-12 represent moderate injury
  • Scores ≤8 represent severe injury 

Head Injury Severity: Clinical classification 

Eyes Opening

 Score
Spontaneously 4
To verbal command 3
To painful stimulus 2
Do not open 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Verbal response Score
Normal-oriented conversation 5
Confused 4
Inappropriate words only 3
Sounds only 2
No sounds 1

Non-testable

 NT

 

Motor Response Score
Obeys commands 6
Localizes to pain 5
Withdrawal response to pain 4
Abnormal flexion/ Decorticate posturing  3
Abnormal extension/ Decerebrate posturing  2
No motor response 1

Non-testable

 NT

Minimum value: 3

Maximum value: 15

  • GCS, in particular, the motor score, is the best predictor of neurological outcome.
  • If an area cannot be assessed, no numerical score is given for that region, and it is considered “non-testable." (NT)
  • In case of endotracheal intubation or tracheostomy, the verbal component of the score is denoted as NT.
  • A score of  ‘1’ is not recorded in missing components, instead, NT is used
  • when a component is Not Testable, a total score is not recorded because the score will be low and this could be confusing to medical colleagues. This may also imply that the patient is more unwell than they actually are.

 

NOTE: 

A new parameter, "pupil reactivity score" has been added to GCS, and now, it is referred to as GCS-P.

P stands for "Pupils unreactive to light"

Pupils unreactive to light Score
Both pupils 2
One pupil 1 
Neither  0

The pupillary score is subtracted from the GCS score to give the final value. Therefore, the range of GCS-P is 1–15.

Note: The minimum frequency of observations for patients with GCS equal to 15 should be as follows, starting after the initial assessment in the emergency department:

  • Half-hourly for 2 hours,
  • Then 1-hourly for 4 hours,
  • 2-hourly thereafter.

Should the patient with GCS equal to 15 deteriorate at any time after the initial 2-hour period, observations should revert to half-hourly and follow the original frequency schedule.

questions.text: False about carotid body tumor is:

choices.text: Arises from chemoreceptor cells on medial side of carotid bulb
Histologically it is a chromaffin paraganglioma

questions.solution:
Histologicallly carotid body tumour is a non chromaffin paraganglioma.

A paraganglion is a group of non-neuronal cells derived of the neural crest. They are named for being generally in close proximity to sympathetic ganglia.

They are essentially of two types of paragangliomas:

  • Chromaffin or sympathetic paraganglia made of chromaffin cells. They are connected with the ganglia of the sympathetic trunk and the ganglia of the celiac, renal, adrenal, aortic and hypogastric plexuses. They are concentrated near the adrenal glands and essentially function the same way as the adrenal medulla. They are neuroendocrine cells with primary endocrine functions.
  • Nonchromaffin or parasympathetic ganglia made of glomus cells. They include carotid bodies and aortic bodies, some are distributed in the ear, along the vagus nerve, in the larynx and at various other places. They have primary chemoreceptor functions.

Chromaffin paragangliomas are issued from chromaffin cells, and are known as pheochromocytomas.

Nonchromaffin paragangliomas are issued from glomus cells, also known as glomus tumors. They are usually benign. They are generally present at the head and neck, most often at carotid body or jugulo-tympanic.

Carotid body tumour(CBT) (also called chemodectoma or potato tumour):

  • Usually unilateral, usually benign, with 10% family history.
  • Rare tumour that has a higher incidence high altitude areas because of chronic hypoxia leading to carotid body hyperplasia.
  • Arises from the chemoreceptor cells on the medial side of the carotid bulb and at this point, the tumour is adherent to the carotid wall.
  • Slowly enlarging painless mass at carotid bifurcation which is firm, rubbery, pulsatile.
  • CECT or carotid angiogram is the investigation of choice.
  • Biopsy or FNAC is contraindicated.
  • The treatment of choice is surgical excision. If highly vascularized pre operative embolization is an advantage to minimize operative blood loss, as overall growth rate is slow, the need for surgery must be weighed with potential complications of surgery.

CBTs are also seen as part of syndromes, including:

  • Carney’s triad (GastroIntestinal Stromal Tumor, pulmonary chondroma, paraganglioma)
  • von Hippel-Lindau’s disease (pheochromocytoma, spinal hemangioblastoma, paraganglioma),
  • Neurofibromatosis type 1
  • Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia type 2 
  • Paraganglioma-pheochromocytoma syndrome

questions.text: Polymorphism of which of the following is responsible for variability in warfarin response?
questions.solution:
Polymorphisms in two genes, CYP2C9 and VKORC1 (vitamin K epoxide reductase complex, subunit 1) account for most of the genetic contribution to the variability in warfarin response.

CYP2C9 variants affect warfarin pharmacokinetics, whereas VKORC1 variants affect warfarin pharmacodynamics.

questions.text: Which of the following Leopold’s maneuvers is done to assess the lie of the fetus ?
questions.solution:
Leopold’s 1 i.e. fundal grip is used to assess fetal lie.

Fetal pole, lie, presenting part, engagement, and attitude of the fetal head are assessed by Leopold's maneuvers.

Leopold’s maneuvers are done by four obstetric grips:

  1. Leopold’s 1 (Fundal grip): It assesses the uterine fundus. It helps the identification of fetal lie and fetal presentation. The breech gives the sensation of a large, nodular mass, whereas the head feels hard and round and is more mobile.
  2. Leopold’s 2 (Lateral grip): It assesses the presenting part's position. The second maneuver is accomplished as the palms are placed on either side of the maternal abdomen, and gentle but deep pressure is exerted. On one side, a hard, resistant structure is felt-the back. On the other, numerous small, irregular, mobile parts are felt-the fetal extremities
  3. Leopold’s 3 (Pawlik's grip): It helps in the confirmation of fetal presentation. The thumb and fingers of one hand grasp the lower portion of the maternal abdomen just above the symphysis pubis. If the presenting part is not engaged, a movable mass, usually the head, will be felt.
  4. Leopold’s 4 (Pelvic grip): It assesses the engagement and attitude of the fetal head. The examiner faces the mother's feet, and the fingertips of both hands are positioned on either side of the presenting part. They exert inward pressure and then slide along the axis of the pelvic inlet.

questions.text: A 25-year-old male prefers to be detached, does not mingle with people, and often remains alone. He does not experience pleasure and is rather preoccupied with himself and his own fantasy world. This personality type will show__________
questions.solution:
A young male who is a loner by choice and emotionally cold comes under schizoid personality. Individuals with schizoid personality have low novelty seeking.

Novelty seeking (NS) is a temperament trait in the Cloninger’s model of personality and refers to the tendency to be intensely exhilarated or excited in response to novel stimuli.

High novelty seeking:

  • Individuals high in novelty seeking are quick-tempered, curious, easily bored, impulsive, extravagant, and disorderly.
  • High novelty seeking is related to addiction, ADHD and impulsivity.
  • Cluster B personality disorders like borderline, histrionic, narcissistic and antisocial have high novelty seeking behavior.

Low novelty seeking:

  • Persons low in novelty seeking are slow tempered, uninquiring, stoical, reflective, frugal, reserved, tolerant of monotony, and orderly.
  • Individual with schizoid personality is a markedly detached person who stays alone in introspection and lives in his own world of fantasy. This is associated with having a cold attitude.

Other options:

  • Magical thinking – Schizotypal personality
  • Grandiosity - Narcissistic personality
  • Impulsivity – Borderline personality, Antisocial personality

Related Pearl: Personality Disorders

Key features of Personality disorders

Cluster A (Odd, Weird, Eccentric)
Paranoid
Suspicious, distrustful, hypervigilant
Schizoid
Prefers to be loner, detached, unemotional
Schizotypal
Eccentric & odd thoughts, perceptions & behavior, magical thinking and beliefs

Cluster B (Dramatic, Emotional and Erratic)
Antisocial
Disregard for and violation of rights of others, illegal activities
Borderline
Chaotic relationships, sensitivity to abandonment, labile mood, impulsivity, inner emptiness, self-harm
Histrionic
Dramatic, superficial, attention-seeking
Narcissistic
Grandiosity, lack of empathy

Cluster C (Anxious, Fearful, Introvert)
Avoidant
Avoidance due to fears of criticism and rejection
Dependent
Submissive, clingy, needs to be taken care of
Obsessive-compulsive/
Anankastic
 
Rigid, controlling, perfectionist

questions.text: A sanitation worker presents with high-grade fever and red eyes. On examination, there is icterus, neck rigidity, the sign demonstrated below. Investigations show azotemia and elevated liver enzymes. What is the most appropriate drug to be prescribed in this case?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of patient with fever, conjunctival suffusion (red-eye), jaundice, along with image showing kernig's sign positive and other meningeal signs i.e. neck rigidity is suggestive of a diagnosis of leptospirosis. This along with azotemia and elevated liver enzymes are features of severe leptospirosis- Weil's disease. Intravenous penicillin is most appropriate drug in severe leptospirosis.

Leptospirosis is a zoonosis caused by spirochetes of the genus Leptospira. Patients with mild disease may present with flu-like symptoms of sudden onset, fever with chills, headache, abdominal pain, conjunctival suffusion, and myalgia. The muscle pain usually affects the calves, abdomen, and back. Severe cases of leptospirosis, which can progress rapidly and have a high fatality rate, are associated with Weil's syndrome, characterized by triad of:

  • Hemorrhage
  • Jaundice
  • Acute kidney injury

Jaundice, when present, can be profound, and physical examination may reveal an enlarged, tender liver. Temperature-pulse dissociation or relative bradycardia may also be observed. The bacteria is spread by the urine of infected animals and humans, thus making sanitary workers a high-risk population due to poor working conditions.  

The image below shows icterus and conjunctival suffusion in a patient with leptospirosis:

Leptospira are actively motile organisms and are best seen using a dark-field microscope. They are thin, tightly coiled, and flexible spirochetes with one end forming a hook. Diagnosis is by microscopic agglutination test. 

Treatment for leptospirosis is based on the severity of the disease. In mild cases, oral doxycycline, ampicillin, or amoxicillin is preferred and in severe cases, intravenous penicillin, ampicillin, or ceftriaxone is commonly used.

questions.text: A 70 year old male presents with neck nodes. Examination of left ear reveals a dull tympanic membrane, deafness and tinnitus. On tympanogram, a Type B curve is obtained. Most probable diagnosis is?
questions.solution:
The most probable diagnosis is nasopharyngeal carcinoma.

The given scenario of neck nodes (cervical lymphadenopathy) in a 70-year-old male (5th -7th decade) with unilateral serous otitis media (dull tympanic membrane and Type B tympanogram) are all suggestive of a nasopharyngeal growth, probably carcinoma.

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma is a malignant tumor of the nasopharynx. The theories for etiology include genetics, infection with Epstein-Barr virus, air pollution, and smoking. It commonly occurs in males in the 5th to 7th decade. The most common site of origin of nasopharyngeal carcinoma is the fossa of Rosenmuller. From here, it can spread extensively in any direction locally. It also can spread lymphatically to the cervical, retropharyngeal, or parapharyngeal lymph nodes. 

Nasopharyngeal carcinoma presents with the following symptoms:

  • Nasal - obstruction, discharge, rhinolalia clausa, epistaxis
  • Ear - eustachian tube obstruction leading to conductive hearing loss or recurrent otitis media. 
  • Ophthalmoneurologic - all the cranial nerves (CN) may be involved. 
    • CN VI - squint and diplopia
    • CN III, IV, VI, - ophthalmoplegia
    • CN V - reduced corneal reflex 
    • CN II - exophthalmos 
    • CN IX, X, XI - jugular foramen syndrome
    • Horner’s syndrome
  • Cervical lymph node metastasis
  • Distant metastasis to the bone, liver, and lung. 

Examination of the ear shows a dull tympanic membrane and audiometry shows a Type B curve due to the presence of fluid in the middle ear. The presence of unilateral serous otitis media in an adult suggests nasopharyngeal growth.

Trotter's triad consists of ipsilateral conductive hearing loss (eustachian tube blockage), trigeminal neuralgia of the mandibular division, and palatal asymmetry due to the involvement of the CN X may be seen. This triad occurs in malignant tumors of the lateral nasopharyngeal wall due to extensive invasion. 

Other options:

Option A: Chronic suppurative otitis media presents with ear discharge and perforation will be seen on examination.

Option B: On otoscopy, a red reflex is seen through the intact tympanic membrane in the glomus tumor. Tumor arising from the floor of the middle ear gives a rising sun appearance.

Option D: The dull tympanic membrane on examination and Type B tympanogram suggest the presence of fluid in the middle ear as the cause for deafness and not sensorineural hearing loss.

Related Pearl: Types of curves in tympanogram

questions.text: A 15-year old child has a mental age of 5 years. He is suffering from ________
questions.solution:
The above child with an IQ between 20 to 35 is suffering from a severe intellectual disability.

So here IQ = (5/15) x 100 = 33.33

A child with IQ of 33.33 will have severe mental retardation.

questions.text: Sievert is an SI unit for ________
questions.solution:
Sievert is an SI unit for dose equivalent.

Dose equivalent (H) in sieverts is equal to the absorbed dose (D, in grays) multiplied by a quality factor (Q) which depends upon the density of ionization produced in the tissue by radiation, i.e., H = DQ.

The factor Q for X-rays, Y-rays and electrons is equal to 1 and that for an alpha particle is 20.

Related Pearl: Important SI units for radiation

Quantity measured Old unit New Unit Conversion Description
Radioactivity Curie Becquerel 1 curie = 3.7 x 1010 becquerel  
Radiation exposure Roentgen Coulumb/kg 1 roentgen = 2.58 × 10-4 C/Kg Amount of radiation absorbed in air.  
Absorbed dose Rad Gray (Gy) 100 rad = 1 gray (or, 1 rad = 0.01 gray)  Amount of radioactive energy absorbed per unit gram of tissue or material.
Dose equivalent Rem Sievert (Sv) 100 rem = 1 sievert  Indicates potential danger to health.

questions.text: What does the area between the dotted lines in this graph indicate?
questions.solution:
The area between the dotted lines in the graph shows the therapeutic window. It is the range of steady-state concentrations of a drug that provides therapeutic efficacy with minimal toxicity.

The therapeutic index (TI) describes a relationship between the doses of a drug that causes lethal or toxic effects with the dose that causes therapeutic effects. It is also called the therapeutic ratio.

Mathematically, you can calculate TI by following way:

Therapeutic Index = LD50/ED50 (or) Therapeutic Index = TD50/ED50

Where,

  • LD50 (Median Lethal dose) is the minimum amount of drug that causes adverse effects in 50% of the population. LD50 could also be replaced with Toxic dose (TD50).
  • ED50 (Median Effective dose) is the quantity of a drug that can produce desired therapeutic effects in 50% of the population.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about erysipelas?

choices.text: Rarely extend to deeper soft tissue
Occurs most commonly on the trunk

questions.solution:
Erysipelas occurs more commonly on face and extremities, rather than the trunk.

Erysipelas:

  • Sharply demarcated infection of superficial lymphatic vessels with Streptococcus pyogenes, which is abrupt in onset with fiery red swelling. 
  • Indurated, well defined margins, usually along nasolabial fold, with rapid progression and intense pain.
  • Rarely extend to deeper soft tissue.

questions.text: Large bulky friable vegetations are characteristic of
questions.solution:
Large bulky friable vegetations are characteristic of sub-acute bacterial endocarditis.

Infective endocarditis is characterized by the presence of large, friable, irregular vegetations on heart valves, that may extend onto the chordae. Aortic and mitral valves are more commonly affected.

Vegetations may be single or multiple and may involve one or more valves. They are potentially destructive lesions and contain fibrin, inflammatory cells, bacteria or other organisms. They can erode into the underlying myocardium and form a ring abscess. Embolization often occurs and may lead to septic infarcts or mycotic aneurysms at the site of lodgement due to the presence of virulent organisms in the emboli. Vegetations in sub-acute endocarditis are less destructive to the heart valves than in acute type. Microscopy shows granulation tissues at the bases which are suggestive of healing in sub-acute endocarditis. 

The gross appearance of infective endocarditis vegetations is shown below

Related Pearl: Modified Duke's criteria for diagnosis of infective endocarditis

Diagnosis of Infective endocarditis is by Duke's Criteria, which requires either:

  1. Pathologic criteria
  2. Clinical criteria

If clinical criteria are used, definitive endocarditis is defined by the presence of 2 major or 1 major + 3 minor or 5 minor criteria.

The presence of single pathological criteria is definitive of infective endocarditis.

Note: The diagnosis of endocarditis is rejected if an alternative diagnosis is established either when:

  • Symptoms resolve and do not recur with <4 days of antibiotic therapy OR
  • If surgery or autopsy yields no pathologic or macroscopic evidence of endocarditis in <4 days of antimicrobial therapy.

questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presented with a lower abdominal mass and lower abdominal discomfort. On examination, the uterus appears uniformly enlarged and adnexa is free. MRI shows the presence of a myometrial cyst. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Multiparous women >40yrs, presenting with abdominal mass (free from adnexa) and myometrial cysts on MRI, point towards a diagnosis of adenomyosis.

Adenomyosis refers to the growth of the endometrium (both stromal and glandular components) directly into the myometrium. It is predominantly seen in multiparous women above the age of 40 years. Patients generally present with menorrhagia, dysmenorrhea, and sometimes dyspareunia. On examination, there is a gross symmetrical enlargement of the uterus corresponding to 12-14 weeks size. The uterus is soft and tender on bimanual examination. 

Transvaginal ultrasonography (TVS) reveals a salt-and-pepper appearance of the myometrium and the presence of sub-endometrial striations producing the Venetian blind appearance. MRI can also be done for diagnosis. However, the only definitive mode of diagnosis is histopathological examination.

Since most women affected by the condition are past the childbearing age, total hysterectomy is the treatment of choice. Localized excision/Levonorgestrel containing IUCD can be tried in younger women.

Other options:

Option A: Endometriosis refers to the presence of endometrial tissue outside the endometrial lining (uterus). They usually present as dysmenorrhea and lower dull abdominal pain. Vaginal examination reveals a tender fixed retroverted uterus. They can be managed medically (oral contraceptives, aromatase inhibitors, etc)  and surgically (if failed medical management). Abdominal hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy is performed in advanced cases.

Option C: Leiomyoma (fibroid) is the commonest benign tumor arising from the uterus. They present as abnormal uterine bleeding, infertility, and abdominal pain. On bimanual examination, the uterus is enlarged and the mass moves with the cervix. It can be managed medically (mifepristone or newer progesterone) and surgically. A myomectomy is performed for large fibroids with significant symptoms.

Option D: Endometrial hyperplasia can be simple, glandular, or atypical. They are seen in women with estrogen excess states like obesity, PCOD, or on tamoxifen therapy. They usually present as abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB).

questions.text: The clinical test demonstrated as shown below, indicates

choices.text: McMurray's test for Anterior Cruciate Ligament (ACL) stability
Anterior Drawer test for ACL stability
McMurray's test for Lateral Meniscus stability

questions.solution:
The given demonstration shows the Lachman test being performed on the knee joint to detect anterior cruciate ligament instability.

Lachman's Test:

The patient’s knee is flexed 20-30 degrees, with one hand grasping the lower thigh and the other the upper part of the leg. The joint surfaces are shifted backward and forwards upon each other.

Abnormal movement suggests an anterior cruciate ligament (ACL) injury. If the knee is stable, there should be no gliding.

Drawer Test : With both knees flexed 90 degrees and the feet resting on the couch, the foot is anchored by the examiner sitting on it (provided this is not painful), then, using both hands, the upper end of the tibia is grasped firmly and rocked backwards and forwards to see if there is any anteroposterior glide (the ‘drawer test’).

  • Excessive anterior movement (a positive anterior drawer sign) denotes anterior cruciate laxity.
  • Excessive posterior movement (a positive posterior drawer sign) signifies posterior cruciate laxity.

McMurray's test: It is used to test for a torn meniscus. The test is based on the fact that the loose meniscal tag can sometimes be trapped between the articular surfaces and then induced to snap free with a palpable and audible click. The knee is flexed as far as possible, one hand steadies the joint and the other rotates the leg medially and laterally while the knee is slowly extended. The test is repeated several times, with the knee stressed in valgus or varus, feeling and listening for the click.

questions.text: All the following are features of Wilson’s disease except___________.

choices.text: Copper in blood is of no diagnostic use
Increased urine excretion of copper is most specific screening test

questions.solution:
Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to mutations in the ATP7B gene. There is a copper overload that primarily affects the liver (leading to cirrhosis) and the brain (leading to neurologic and psychiatric symptoms). 

Clinical features of Wilson's disease include: 

  • Hepatic features include jaundice, hepatomegaly, and ascites. The patient might develop cirrhosis and acute decompensation of liver function. Massive release of copper into the circulation from the liver can lead to hemolytic anemia.
  • Neurologic features include dysarthria, dystonia, rigidity, tremors, and choreiform movements. These occur due to copper deposition in the basal ganglia.
  • Psychiatric features include personality changes (irritability, anger) depression, and anxiety.
  • Ocular features include Kayser-Fleischer ring and sunflower cataract. 
  • Other manifestations include renal tubular acidosis, delayed puberty, and osteoarthritis. 

Reduced serum ceruloplasmin (option A) and elevated urinary copper excretion (option D) point to a diagnosis of Wilson's disease. Measurement of serum copper is of no diagnostic use (option C) since it may be low, normal, or elevated depending on the stage of evolution of the disease. Percutaneous liver biopsy for measuring hepatic copper content is the gold standard investigation for establishing the diagnosis.

Copper chelation in patients with Wilson's disease is done using penicillamine. Pyridoxine is prescribed with penicillamine to counteract the deficiency that may develop with the treatment. In patients with predominant neurological manifestations, trientine is used as the chelating agent because penicillamine can worsen neurological symptoms. Tetrathiomolybdate is under trial for the treatment of Wilson's disease. Zinc is used for maintenance therapy in patients after the initial chelation is complete.

Mutation in ATP7A gene causes impaired copper absorption and transport, leading to Menkes disease. This is characterized by brittle and kinky hair.

questions.text: A woman with HIV was brought in to the emergency ward after an episode of generalized tonic-clonic seizures. An MRI  revealed multiple enhancing lesions. A stereotactic biopsy of the lesion was done and the image is given below. Which of the following test can be used for the diagnosis of the organism?
questions.solution:
The above image (showing lymphocytes, macrophages, and eosinophils surrounding the toxoplasmosis bradyzoites encased in cysts with a cyst wall) and the case scenario suggest that the most likely diagnosis is cerebral toxoplasmosis. Sabin Feldman dye test is a serological test done for the detection of antibodies against Toxoplasma.

Cerebral toxoplasmosis is an opportunistic infection commonly found in the setting of HIV-associated immunosuppression and usually occurs in patients with CD4+ T cell counts <200/μL. Toxoplasmosis of the CNS produces brain abscesses, which are found most often in the cerebral cortex (near the grey-white junction) and deep grey nuclei.

  • Acute lesions exhibit central necrosis, petechial hemorrhages surrounded by acute and chronic inflammation, macrophage infiltration, and vascular proliferation. Both free tachyzoites and encysted bradyzoites may be found at the periphery of the necrotic foci.
  • Chronic lesions consist of small cystic spaces containing scattered lipid and hemosiderin-laden macrophages that are surrounded by the gliotic brain.

Sabin Feldman dye test is a serological test done for the detection of antibodies against Toxoplasma. IIF, IHA, and CFT (component fixation test) are also used for the diagnosis of toxoplasmosis. The dye test remains positive throughout life, while CFT becomes negative soon after acute infection. ELISA is most commonly used and IgM and IgG antibodies are estimated separately.

Standard treatment is sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine & leucovorin for a minimum of 4–6 weeks.

Primary Prophylaxis:

  • Prior toxoplasmic encephalitis and CD4+ T cell count <200/μL: Sulfadiazine/pyrimethamine and leucovorin
  • TOXO IgG antibody positive and CD4+ T cell count <100/μL : Trimethoprim/sulfamethoxazole (TMP/SMX)
  • The drug of choice for toxoplasmosis in pregnancy is spiramycin.

Other options:

Option A: Casoni’s test is used for Hydatid cysts.

Option B: Bachman test is used for Trichinellosis.

Option D: Montenegro test is used for Leishmaniasis.

questions.text: Identify the bacteria that causes the phenomenon shown in the image.
questions.solution:
The given picture shows swarming, which is exhibited by Proteus.

Proteus species move very actively by means of peritrichous flagella, resulting in “swarming” on solid media. It can be suppressed by

  • Phenylethyl alcohol
  • Cystine-lactose-electrolyte-deficient (CLED) medium

Other organisms that show swarming include:

  • Clostridium tetani
  • Vibrio parahaemolyticus
  • Serratia
