questions.text: "System of lines on the human skin which the linear naevi and dermatoses follow" are called ________
questions.solution:
Blaschko’s lines are described as a ‘system of lines on the human skin which the linear naevi and dermatoses follow’.

Many naevoid skin lesions display an arrangement following these lines. The lines do not correspond to any known nervous, vascular or lymphatic structures, but represent developmental growth pattern within the skin

Other options:

  • Langer's lines/Langer lines of skin tension/cleavage lines: 
    • They are topological lines drawn on a map of the human body.
    • They correspond to the natural orientation of collagen fibers in the dermis and are generally parallel to the orientation of the underlying muscle fibers.
    • They have importance in cosmetic surgery.
  • Kraissl's lines are a set of anatomical skin lines. They differ from Langer's lines in that unlike Langer's lines, which are defined in term of collagen orientation, Kraissl's lines are the lines of maximum skin tension. Langer's lines were defined in cadavers, Kraissl's lines have been defined in living individuals.
  • Dermatomes: Sensory innervation follows well‐defined dermatomes, with some overlap between adjacent dermatomes.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about medullary thyroid carcinoma?
questions.solution:
Medullary thyroid carcinoma (MTC) does not take up radioactive iodine as MTC is TSH-independent.

Medullary thyroid carcinoma is a tumor of parafollicular (C cells) derived from the neural crest. Histological analysis shows characteristic amyloid stroma. High levels of calcitonin and carcinoembryonic antigen are produced by many medullary tumors. It also secretes 5-hydroxytryptamine (serotonin) or prostaglandin which may be a reason for diarrhea in 30% of cases. 20% are familial (multicentric and bilateral) and seen in younger ages. 80% sporadic (originate in one lobe) and is seen in the 6th decade. It is diagnosed by FNAC.

Treatment includes total thyroidectomy plus elective dissection of the central neck nodes plus or minus ipsilateral modified radical neck dissection (if neck node positive). If nodal metastasis cure is unlikely, the gross disease should be removed.

Related Pearl: Secretion of medullary thyroid tumors

Medullary thyroid tumor secrete the following:

  • Calcitonin
  • Carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA)
  • Calcitonin gene–related peptide
  • Histaminadases
  • Prostaglandins E 2 and F 2 α
  • Serotonin

Calcitonin and serotonins are responsible for diarrhea in MTC.

questions.text: Test used for the diagnosis of trichinosis is _______
questions.solution:
Bachman test is used for the diagnosis of trichinosis.

Bachman Intradermal Test:

  • It is done in the diagnosis of Trichinosis.
  • The test uses a 1:5,000 or 1:10,000 dilution of the Trichinella larval antigen, which is injected intradermally.
  • An erythematous wheal appears in positive cases within 15-20 minutes.
  • The test remains positive for years after infection.

The following are some important tests used in the diagnosis of various parasitic infections.

Test Disease
Casoni’s test Hydatid disease
Montenegro test Kala-azar
Frenkel’s test Toxoplasmosis
Fairley’s test Schistosomiasis
Bachman test Trichinosis

questions.text: Correct pairing of drug and its mechanism of action among the following is?
questions.solution:
Rituximab is an anti CD20 monoclonal antibody.

  • Rituximab is a chimeric monoclonal antibody that targets the CD20 B-cell antigen. CD20 is found on cells from the pre–B cell stage through its terminal differentiation to plasma cells and is expressed on 90% of B-cell neoplasms.
  • Monoclonal antibody binding to CD20 generates transmembrane signals that produce autophosphorylation and activation of serine/tyrosine protein kinases, induction of c-Myc oncogene expression, and expression of major histocompatibility complex class II molecules.
  • Rituximab is approved as a single agent for relapsed indolent lymphomas and significantly enhances response and survival in combination with chemotherapy for the initial treatment of diffuse large B-cell lymphoma(DLBCL).
  • It remains effective in patients who relapse after initial treatment with rituximab-based combinations.
  • Rituximab improves response rates when added to combination chemotherapy for other indolent B-cell non-Hodgkin’s lymphomas (NHLs), including CLL, mantle cell lymphoma, Waldenström macroglobulinemia, and marginal zone lymphomas.

The EGFR belongs to the ErbB family of transmembrane receptor tyrosine kinases also known as ErbB1 or HER1 (human EGFR 1). EGFR is essential for the growth and differentiation of epithelial cells.

Two separate classes of drugs that target the EGFR pathway are important in the therapy of solid tumors:

  1. Monoclonal antibodies recognize the extracellular domain of the EGFR, inhibit ligand-induced signaling, and can elicit an immune response. Cetuximab is a recombinant, chimeric human/mouse IgG1 antibody that binds to EGFR and prevents ligand-dependent signaling and receptor dimerization, thereby blocking cell growth and survival signals. It is used to treat patients with metastatic colon cancers and Head and neck squamous cell carcinoma(HNSCC).
  2. Protein tyrosine kinase inhibitors bind to the intracellular kinase domain and inhibit the enzymatic function of an EGFR. Erlotinib is a reversible EGFR tyrosine kinase inhibitor used for advanced non-small cell lung cancer(NSCLC) with mutant EGFR and advanced pancreatic cancer in combination with gemcitabine.

Trastuzumab is a humanized IgG1 monoclonal antibody of HER2-human epidermal growth factor receptor 2, inhibiting hetero- and homodimerization and signal transduction. It is approved for HER2-overexpressing breast and gastric cancer.

questions.text: As per criteria recommended by WHO, presence of which of the following  in children between 6 months to 6 years should be considered as evidence of xerophthalmia problem in community:
questions.solution:
Xerophthalmia is considered a public health problem if the prevalence rate of corneal xerosis among children between 6 months to 6 years (high risk category) is more than 0.01%.

Prevalence Criteria For Determining The Xerophthalmia Problem in community:

Criteria Prevalence in population at risk (6 months to 6 years)
Night blindness >1%
Bitot’s spots  >0.5%
Corneal xerosis /Keratomalacia >0.01%
Corneal ulcer >0.05%
Serum retinol (<10mcg/dl) >5%

questions.text: Alzheimer type II astrocytes are seen in?
questions.solution:
Alzheimer type II astrocytes are seen in Wilson's disease.

Alzheimer's type II astrocytes have a large nucleus, pale­ stained central chromatin, an intranuclear glycogen droplet, and a prominent nuclear membrane and nucleolus. This type of change is mainly seen in individuals with long­standing hyperammonemia due to chronic liver disease, Wilson disease, or hereditary metabolic disorders of the urea cycle.

Alzheimer's type I astrocytes are seen in progressive multifocal encephalopathy and are enlarged multinucleated astrocytes.

Rosenthal fibers are seen in Pilocytic astrocytoma.

questions.text: Penile scrapings from an immunocompromised patient show multinucleate giant cells with Lipschultz bodies. If he develops encephalitis, which of the following lobes is most commonly involved?
questions.solution:
Lipschultz bodies are intranuclear inclusion bodies seen in the multinucleated giant cells (Tzanck cells) in case of herpes simplex infection (HSV-1 & HSV-2). Tzanck preparation (Wright & Giemsa staining) of the tissue scrapings reveals these findings. Herpes simplex can cause encephalitis and temporal lobe is most commonly involved.

MRI showing prominent swelling, increase T2 signal involving the left temporal lobe and insular cortex.

Herpes simplex usually spreads by sexual contact or vertical transmission from the pregnant mother to the fetus. Clinical manifestations range from oral-cutaneous lesions to disseminated disease-causing encephalitis, pneumonitis, and hepatitis.

Safe sexual practice and the use of antivirals like acyclovir remain the mainstay of treatment.

RNA polymerase III synthesizes tRNA and 5s rRNA.

questions.text: Which among the following is not a function of pneumotaxic centre ?

choices.text: Increase in the rate of breathing

questions.solution:
Respiratory rhythm generation is a function of dorsal respiratory group of neurons (and not pneumotaxic center).

Pneumotaxic center:

  • It is located dorsally in the nucleus parabrachialis of the upper pons and it transmits signals to the inspiratory area.
  • Primary effect of this center is to control the switch­off point of the inspiratory ramp, thus controlling the duration of the filing phase of the lung cycle.
  • Function of the pneumotaxic center is primarily to limit inspiration, which has a secondary effect of increasing the rate of breathing, because limitation of inspiration also shortens expiration and the entire period of each respiration.

The pneumotaxic and apneustic centers were proposed by Lumsden, based on sectioning at different levels of the brain stem of cats.

Related Pearl: Respiratory Centres

questions.text: Which of the following immunoglobulin levels are decreased in Wiskott–Aldrich syndrome?
questions.solution:
Serum IgM levels are decreased in Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome. However, IgG is usually normal and paradoxically IgA and IgE are often elevated.

Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome (WAS) is an X-linked recessive immunodeficiency disorder. It is caused by mutations in the Wiskott-Aldrich syndrome protein (WASp) that primarily affects the T lymphocytes. Normally, WASp regulates the actin cytoskeleton and thus helps in cell adhesion, migration, and the formation of synapses between antigen-presenting and target cells. In WAS, there is a progressive loss of T lymphocytes in the peripheral blood resulting in defects in cellular immunity. 

The clinical features of WAS are recurrent bacterial infections, eczema, and bleeding due to thrombocytopenia. Diagnosis is based on intracellular immunofluorescence analysis of WAS protein (WASp) expression in blood cells. IgM levels in the serum are low, but levels of IgG are usually normal. Ig A and Ig E levels are high. Reduced-sized platelet is a typical feature of WAS. 

The image given below shows eczema seen in WAS.

questions.text: The image below shows a gunshot wound on the skull. Identify the type of wound and its features.

choices.text: Exit wound - bevelling of outer table and punched out hole on inner table
Entry wound - bevelling of inner table and punched out hole on outer table
Entry wound - bevelling of outer table and punched out hole on inner table
Exit wound - bevelling of inner table and punched out hole on outer table

questions.solution:
The given image shows bevelling of the outer table and a punched-out hole on the inner table. Hence, it is an exit wound.

Entry wound: The initial contact of the missile punches a clean hole through the outer table of the skull. Where the bullet emerges internally, the inner table is then unsupported and a cone-shaped plug is detached, forming a crater that is appreciably larger than the external hole.

  • Bevelling: inner table
  • Punched out hole: outer table

Exit wound: If the bullet traverses the cranium and penetrates the opposite side, then the same pattern occurs, but this time with the small hole on the inner table and the crater on the outside.

  • Bevelling: outer table
  • Punched out hole: inner table

questions.text: Reye syndrome is caused by all except ______
questions.solution:
Reye’s syndrome is caused by all of the above except RSV.

  • Reyes syndrome is an encephalopathy which is associated with pathologic features characterized by:
    • Fatty degeneration of the viscera (microvesicular steatosis)
    • Mitochondrial abnormalities
    • Biochemical features consistent with a disturbance of mitochondrial metabolism.
  •  It is precipitated in a genetically susceptible person by the interaction of a viral infection in influenza, varicella and herpes and salicylate and or antiemetic use.
  • Clinically, it is characterized by a preceding viral illness that appears to be resolving and the acute onset of vomiting and encephalopathy. Neurologic symptoms can rapidly progress to seizures, coma, and death. Liver dysfunction is invariably present.

Related Pearl: Microvesicular Steatosis vs. Macrovesicular Steatosis

Microvesicular Steatosis

  Macrovesicular Steatosis
  • Acute fatty liver of pregnancy
  • Reye's syndrome
  • Alcoholic foamy degeneration
  • Drug- and toxin-induced injury (valproic acid, salicylates, parenteral tetracycline, hypoglycin A)
  • Congenital metabolic conditions
    • Urea cycle disorders,
    • Defects in fatty acid metabolism,
    • Deficiencies in lysosomal acid lipases

Centrilobular predominant (zone III)

  • Obesity, Nonalcoholic steatohepatitis (NASH)
  • Late alcoholic liver disease
  • Diabetes mellitus

Periportal predominant (zone I)

  • Total parenteral nutrition (TPN)
  • Aquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS)
  • Phosphorus poisoning
  • Exogenous steroids
  • Starvation
  • Chronic hepatitis C

questions.text: A girl presented with itching and oozing from an earlobe lesion after wearing nickel earrings. What test will you do to confirm the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This is a case of allergic contact dermatitis and the diagnosis is made by a patch test.

Allergic contact dermatitis is a reaction to a substance (allergen) that causes an eruption only in those individuals previously sensitized by the same molecule. It is a delayed-type of hypersensitivity (Type IV) reaction. It presents as pruritis and an eczematous eruption in sites where contact has taken place with the etiological agent/allergen.

Nickel is the most frequent contact allergen. Most of its salts, for example, nickel chloride and nickel sulfate, are readily soluble in water and sweat and have strong sensitizing properties. Jewelry and metal components of clothing are the usual sources of nickel in prolonged contact with the skin. 

Patch tests are used to identify the etiologic agent(s) of allergic contact dermatitis. Patches are usually applied to the back and removed 48 hours after application. The skin where the patch was applied is examined with readings taken 1 hour after removal and again 48 hours later.

The image below shows a picture of a skin patch allergy test:

 

Treatment of includes

  • Avoidance of the allergen (for example, further use of nickel‐plated objects should be avoided in this case)
  • A topical clioquinol–steroid combination can be considered as a treatment (clioquinol is known to chelate nickel)

questions.text: Which of the following fixative is used in karyotyping?
questions.solution:
Carnoy's fixative is the fixative used in Karyotyping. Carnoy's solution is a fixative composed of 60% ethanol, 30% choloform and 10% glacial acetic acid, 1gm of ferric chloride. Carnoy's solution is a fixation composed of ethanol and glacial acetic acid (6:1).

Other options:

  • 95% ethanol is used as a fixative in Pap smears
  • Zenker's fluid in bone marrow biopsies
  • Bouin's fuid in gastro intestinal biopsies.

questions.text: All of the following are true about post partum hemorrhage (PPH) except?

choices.text: Uterine atony is the most common cause of PPH
Secondary PPH occurs 24 hours after delivery
Uterus shows intermittent tonicity in PPH due to genital tract trauma
B-lynch sutures are helpful in atonic uterus only

questions.solution:
In case of PPH due to genital tract trauma uterus is continuosly contracting (tonic), not intermittent.

According to the American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists , postpartum hemorrhage is defined as cumulative blood loss > 1000 mL accompanied by signs and symptoms of hypovolemia.

Uterine atony is the most common cause of postpartum hemorrhage.

Seconday pospartum hemorrhage is deined as bleeding 24 hours to 12 weeks after delivery. 

Such bleeding most often is the result of:

  • Abnormal involution of the placental site
  • Retention of a placental fragment 
  • Uterine artery pseudoaneurysm
  • Placental poyp : Usually, retained products undergo necrosis with fibrin deposition and may eventually form a polyp. As the eschar of the polyp detaches from the myometrium, hemorrhage may be brisk.
  • May also be caused by von Willebrand disease or other inherited coagulopathies.

questions.text:
The clearance of a drug which follows first-order kinetics (in one compartment model) is 0.2 L/min and volume of distribution is 40 L. What is the t1/2 of that drug?

t1/2: half-life
questions.solution:
The t1/2 of the drug would be 140 minutes.

Plasma half-life (t1/2) is the time required for the plasma concentration or the amount of a drug in the body to be reduced by 50%. It depends on its clearance and volume of distribution. 

t1/2 = 0.693 x Vd/CL

where, 

  • Vd - volume of distribution
  • CL - clearance.

In the given question, drug clearance (CL) = 0.2 L/min and Vd = 40 L

We can take 0.693 approximately as 0.7

Substituting,

t1/2 = 0.7 x 40 /0.2

t1/2 = 0.7 x 200

t1/2 = 140 minutes

Clinical implications: Half-life determines the duration of the drug effect. It also indicates whether the accumulation of the drug will occur under multiple dosage regimens, thereby making it is essential to decide on the appropriate dosing interval.

questions.text: A man who regularly uses contact lenses comes with complaints of blurred vision and ocular pain. Examination shows radial keratoneuritis as seen below. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above presentation of blurred vision and pain, along with the findings of a radial keratoneuritis and ring lesion (seen in the image), suggests a probable diagnosis of acanthamoeba keratitis. 

It is caused by Acanthamoeba spp which are free-living protozoa found in soil, freshwater, and the upper respiratory tract. Contact lens wearers are the most prone to this infection.

Patients complain of blurring of vision and pain is often disproportionate to examination. There are characteristic perineural infiltrates, otherwise known as radial keratoneuritis, are pathognomonic and can be seen during early infection. As the infiltrates grow, they gradually coalesce to form the typical ring abscess.

Staining of the corneal scraping using periodic acid-Schiff or calcofluor white as well as culture is done to diagnose the disease. 

Management includes topical amoebecides, analgesics for pain, as well as debridement of the involved epithelium. Therapeutic keratoplasty is done for resistant cases. 

 The below image shows a hypopyon and typical ring abscess of amebic keratitis.

 

Other options:

Option A: Staphylococcal keratitis usually presents as photophobia, blurred vision, mucopurulent discharge and focal and well-defined white/yellowish-white infiltrate. There are features of anterior uveitis with hypopyon and keratic precipitates.

Option B: Candidal keratitis would present as a typical yellow-white densely suppurative infiltrate. Features of anterior uveitis can also be seen here. 

Option C: Herpes simplex keratitis presents as ocular discomfort, photophobia, and decreased visual acuity. HSV can cause characteristic epithelial (dendritic/geographic) keratitis or disciform keratitis. 

Related Pearl: Clinical differential diagnosis of corneal ulcer

  Bacterial Fungal Viral Parasitic
Risk factors

Contact lens wear

Trauma

Chronic steroid use

Anesthetic cornea

Dry eyes

Exposure keratopathy

 Trauma with vegetative matter

Low immunity

Recurrent attacks

Contact lens wear

Exposure to contaminated water (acanthamoeba)

 
Clinical features

Hypopyon is fluid and mobile

Pseudomonas aeruginosa is likely to have a rapid course, with deep corneal necrosis.

Less pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Tend to be indolent but progressive

Hypopyon is thick, immobile.

Relatively more pain and watering compared to the extent of vision loss and signs. 

Recurrences are characteristic.

Disproportionately severe pain is a characteristic feature.

Indolent course and in initial stages, often mistaken to be viral/ fungal infection, leading to a delay in diagnosis

questions.text: True statement regarding hemochromatosis is __________

choices.text: Hypogonadism in hemochromatosis is due to iron deposition in testis
Vibrio vulnificus has least propensity to infect patients with hemochromatosis
Hereditary hemochromatosis predominantly produces dilated cardiomyopathy
Removal of excess iron effectively improves arthropathy and hypogonadism

questions.solution:
Dilated Cardiomyopathy (DCM) is the most common manifestation of hemochromatosis. Hemochromatosis can also produce Restrictive cardiomyopathy but its less common as compared to DCM.

Hemochromatosis: It is tightly linked to the HLA-A locus on chromosome 6p.

Hemochromatosis is an autosomal recessive disease caused due to mutation in the HFE gene on chromosome 6. The HFE protein is thought to play an important role in the process by which duodenal crypt cells sense body iron stores, leading in turn to increased iron absorption from the duodenum. A decrease in the synthesis or expression of hepcidin, the principal iron regulatory hormone, is also a key pathogenic factor. This excessive absoprtion of Iron is primarily deposited in parenchymal organs such as the liver, pancreas and also heart, joints and endocrine organs.

It is associated with increased risk of Hepato cellular carcinoma.

Hemochromatosis can also be acquired from iron overload due to hemolytic anemia and transfusions.

Other options:

  • Option A: Hypogonadism in hemochromatosis is not due to deposition of iron in testis; it is due to secondary derrangement in the hypothalamo-pituitary axis  which results in decreased gonadotrophins and testosterone levels.
  • Option B: Vibrio vulnificus has a propensity to infect patients with hemochromatosis. The organism's virulence is considerably increased under conditions of iron overload. Thus, primary sepsis most often develops in patients with hemochromatosis/cirrhosis.
  • Option D: In hemochromatosis, removal of excess iron has little effect on arthropathy and hypogonadism. With repeated phlebotomy, following changes occur:
    • Liver decreases in size
    • Liver function improves
    • Hepatic fibrosis may decrease, but established cirrhosis is irreversible
    • Pigmentation of skin decreases
    • Cardiac failure may be reversed
    • Diabetes also improves in about 40% of patients

questions.text: The component of CHOP in the R-CHOP regimen are:
questions.solution:
CHOP is the acronym for a chemotherapy regimen used in the treatment of non-Hodgkin lymphoma. CHOP consists of:

  • (C)yclophosphamide, an alkylating agent which damages DNA by binding to it and causing the formation of cross-links
  • (H)ydroxydaunorubicin (also called doxorubicin or adriamycin), an intercalating agent which damages DNA by inserting itself between DNA bases
  • (O)ncovin (vincristine), which prevents cells from duplicating by binding to the protein tubulin
  • (P)rednisone or (P)rednisolone, which are corticosteroids.

Sometimes the chimeric anti-CD20 monoclonal antibody, rituximab, is added to this treatment regimen if the lymphoma is of B cell origin to form the R-CHOP regimen.

questions.text: The cell shown in the image given below is seen in which of the following Hodgkin lymphoma variants?
questions.solution:
The image shows the L and H variant of Reed Sternberg cell (popcorn cell) which is seen in the lymphocyte-predominant type of Hodgkin’s lymphoma.

Lymphocyte-predominant Hodgkin lymphoma:

  • Uncommon (<5%)
  • Young males <35 years
  • Cervical and axillary lymphadenopathy
  • Non-Classical type
  • Not associated with EBV
  • L&H variant of RS cell that has multilobed nucleus resembling a popcorn kernel (“popcorn cell”)
  • This L&H variant is CD15-, CD30- but is CD20 +and BCL6+
  • Excellent prognosis

Related Pearl: Important Features of the Different Types of Hodgkin's Lymphoma (HL)

Classic subtypes

  • Nodular sclerosis 
  • Mixed cellularity 
  • Lymphocyte-rich
  • Lymphocyte depletion

Non-Classical subtype

  • Lymphocyte predominant

Note: Mixed cellularity is most commonly associated with HIV due to its high incidence.

questions.text: Which of the following study designs is the best to prove causation?
questions.solution:
Randomized controlled trials (RCT) are the strongest and best study design to prove causation. They are the gold standard of clinical research.

Case-control and cohort studies have a moderate ability to provide evidence for causality. Ecological studies or correlational studies are considered as the weakest study design in this aspect.

The difference between analytical studies and randomised controlled trials is that in the former there is no randomisation because it requires the participants to be divided into diseased and non-diseased. This can lead to a number of biases that are avoided in RCTs.

Related Pearl: Randomized Controlled Trials

Randomized controlled trials are a type of experimental studies.

Types

  • Clinical trials
  • Preventive trials
  • Risk factor trials
  • Cessation experiments
  • Trial of etiological agents
  • Evaluation of health services

General Design of an RCT

Steps of an RCT

  • Drawing up a protocol
  • Selecting reference and experimental population
  • Randomization
  • Manipulation or intervention
  • Follow-up
  • Assessment of outcome.

questions.text: Recommended Dietary Allowance (RDA) of which of the following is dependent on carbohydrate intake?
questions.solution:
The RDA of thiamine is dependent on carbohydrate intake. Thiamine has a biochemical function as thiamine pyrophosphate (TPP) in the metabolism of carbohydrate.

The RDA for adults is 1.8 mg/day for men and 1.7 mg/day for women.

Similarly, since pyridoxal phosphate acts as a coenzyme for many enzymes involved in amino acid metabolism, the RDA of pyridoxine is dependent on protein intake.

questions.text: Ciliary muscles are embryologically derived from?
questions.solution:
Ciliary muscles are embryologically derived from the neural crest.

questions.text: Type of odor seen in multiple carboxylase deficiency  is:
questions.solution:
Tomcat urine odour is seen in multiple carboxylase deficiency.

Multiple carboxylase deficiencies leads to defects in utilisation of biotin. In neonatal form of the disease, clinically, the affected infants seem normal at birth, but develop breathing difficulties shortly after birth with feeding problems, vomiting, and hypotonia. If untreated, generalized erythematous rash, exfoliation, alopecia, failure to thrive, seizures and even coma may occur. Affected infants should be treated with biotin.

questions.text: Arias stella reaction is not seen in ________
questions.solution:
Arias stella reaction is not seen in salpingitis isthmica nodosa.

Arias-Stella reaction is seen in:

  • Uterine and ectopic pregnancy
  • Endometriosis
  • Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD)

Arias Stella reaction:

  • There is presence of typical adenomatous change of endometrial glands
  • There is intra luminal budding
  • Cell changes include loss of polarity of cells, pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, vacuolated cytoplasm and occasional mitosis.
  • This is due to the influence of progesterone.

questions.text: Three days after being initiated on a certain enzyme inhibiting drug, a patient developed sharply demarcated skin lesions with necrosis and slow-healing eschar formation, as shown in the image given below. Which of the following drugs was likely started for this patient?
questions.solution:
A patient developing skin necrosis a few days after starting a new drug is likely to be suffering from warfarin-induced skin necrosis.

Warfarin is an anti-coagulant which acts by competitive inhibition of the enzyme vitamin K epoxide reductase thereby preventing the activation of coagulation factors II, VII, IX, X and proteins C and S. Adverse effects of warfarin are bleeding, skin necrosis, purple toe syndrome, and fetal warfarin syndrome (hypoplasia of the nose, eye socket, hand bones, and growth retardation). Skin necrosis is a rare, potentially life-threatening side-effect of warfarin use that usually begins 2-5 days after initiation of therapy.

Individuals with Protein C & S deficiency are, particularly at risk for developing warfarin-induced skin necrosis. This is because these proteins, which are anti-thrombotic, have a shorter half-life as compared to the clotting factors inhibited by warfarin. Initiation of warfarin caused a sudden drop in the levels of protein C and S before they inhibit the clotting factors, due to which there is hypercoagulability and consequent thrombosis of microvasculature which leads to necrosis. The toes, thighs, buttocks and breasts are commonly involved.

This adverse effect can be prevented by co-administration of warfarin with a parenteral anticoagulant such as heparin in the initial few days, until the therapeutic INR range is achieved, before continuing with warfarin alone.

Treatment of this condition is by immediately discontinuing warfarin. Vitamin K can be administered for reversal of the drug effect. Patients are started on an alternative anticoagulant such as heparin or LMWH.

Other Options:

Option B: Aspirin acts by irreversibly inhibiting the enzymes cyclo-oxygenase and thromboxane. It is an antiplatelet drug and the most important side effects include bleeding tendencies. 

Option C: Atorvastatin is a statin drug which inhibits the enzyme HMG CoA reductase. Important side effects inclue myositis and hepatotoxicity.

Option D: Levofloxacin is a fluoroquinolone which inhibits the enzyme DNA gyrase. Important side effects include cartilage damage in children and Achilles tendon rupture in adults.

Related Pearl: Specific reversal agents for anticoagulants

  • Heparin: protamine sulfate
  • Warfarin: vitamin K
  • Rivaroxaban and other oral Xa inhibitors: andexanet alfa
  • Dabigatran: idarucizumab

Related Pearl: Classification of Anticoagulants

Classification of anticoagulants
1) Vitamin K antagonist Warfarin
2) Direct thrombin inhibitors (DTI)   

Parenteral: Monovalent DTI- Argatroban

Bivalent DTI- Lepirudin, Desirudin, Bivalirudin

Oral: Dabigatran 
3) Indirect thrombin inhibitors 

Unfractionated heparin

Low molecular weight heparins: Enoxaparin, Dalteparin, Tinzaparin, Nadroparin
4) Indirect factor Xa inhibitors Fondaparinux
5) Oral Direct factor Xa inhibitors Rivaroxaban,Apixaban, Edoxaban,Betrixaban

questions.text: A 35-year-old female presented with an adnexal mass. CA-125 was slightly raised and LDH was elevated. Microscopy after tumor resection is as given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical history of a 35-year-old woman presenting with adnexal mass with raised CA 125 and LDH and the given microscopy, suggests a diagnosis of dysgerminoma.

Microscopically, there is a monotonous proliferation of large, rounded, polyhedral clear cells that are rich in cytoplasmic glycogen and contain uniform central nuclei with one or a few prominent nucleoli. The tumor cells are histologically identical to the seminoma of the testis. The counterpart of seminoma in females is dysgerminoma.

Dysgerminoma is the most common malignant germ cell tumor diagnosed during pregnancy. Beta hCG levels are raised only in 5% of women due to intermittent syncytiotrophoblast. However, serum LDH, placental alkaline phosphatase are used in monitoring individuals for disease recurrence. Dysgerminomas are the only germ cell malignancy with a significant rate of bilateral ovarian involvement.

Treatment involves fertility-sparing surgery with unilateral salpingo-oophorectomy. It is highly radiosensitive and has a good prognosis.

Related Pearl: Markers of Ovarian Neoplasm

Ovarian tumor Tumor marker Pathognomonic finding

Epithelial ovarian tumors

 CA-125,  CA-19-9, CEA Psammoma bodies (Serous epithelial tumor)
Endodermal sinus tumor AFP Schiller-Duval bodies
Dysgerminoma LDH, PLAP Lymphocytic infiltration
Embryonal carcinoma AFP, HCG -
Mature teratoma AFP Rokitansky protruberance
Granulosa cell tumor Inhibin Call–Exner bodies
Hilus cell tumor - Reinke's crystal
Brenner tumor - Walthard cell nest
Krukenberg tumor - Signet-ring cell
Clear cell tumor - Hobnail cell

Dysgerminoma (Mnemonic: DPL= Delhi Premier League)

  • D: Dysgerminoma
  • P: PLAP (placental alkaline phosphatase)
  • L: LDH (lactate dehydrogenase)

questions.text:
Vaccines included under Intensified mission Indradhanush scheme are:
a. JE
b. Rota virus
c. Typhoid
questions.solution:
Japanese encephalitis and rota virus vaccines are included under Intensified mission Indradhanush scheme.

The Intensified Mission Indradhanush has been introduced to ensure full immunization (more than 90%) by December 2018. It now includes 12 vaccine preventable diseases (updated from the 7 VPDs that Mission Indradhanush focussed on). 4 rounds of immunisation are proposed to be held for 7 days each month (from the 7th- 13th of each month). The diseases are:

  • TB
  • Polio
  • Hep B
  • Diphtheria
  • Pertussis
  • Tetanus
  • Measles

And included recently:

  • Rotavirus diarrhoea
  • Rubella (as MR vaccine)
  • H. influenzae B diseases (as part of the pentavalent vaccine)
  • Pneumococcal meningitis
  • Japanese Encephalitis

questions.text: The following image shows the superior view of the first cervical vertebra. The part of the bone marked as number 7 gives attachment to ______.
questions.solution:
The given image shows the Atlas bone. The part marked as number 7 is the posterior arch, and its inferior border gives attachment to ligamentum flavum.

 

Atlas (C1): Bony features include no body and spinous processes. It has 2 lateral masses - with upper and lower articular facets, anterior and posterior arches, and 2 transverse processes with lateral transverse foramen through which the vertebral vessels pass.

The anterior arch provides attachment to the anterior longitudinal ligament anteriorly and articulates with the facet of dens posteriorly.

The superior border of the posterior arch is attached to the atlantooccipital membrane and its inferior border is attached to the ligamentum flavum.

Articulation of the atlas:

  • The atlantooccipital joint allows the head to nod up and down (like showing yes).
  • The atlantoaxial joint allows the head to turn side to side (like showing no).

Axis (C2): Bony features include a cylindrical body, transverse process with transverse foramen, and a bifid spine. The dens (odontoid process) projects up to the space left due to the missing body of C1.

The given image shows the articulation of the atlas and the axis:

 

The stability of the vertebral column is maintained mainly by 4 ligaments - the anterior longitudinal, posterior longitudinal, ligamentum flavum, and the interspinous ligament.

C1 compression fracture at multiple sites is called Jefferson fracture. C2 hyperextension fracture is also called hangman fracture.

questions.text: Serum levels of different hormones as estimated on the day of ovulation will be _______________

choices.text: Increased FSH, LH, estrogen and progesterone
Increased FSH, LH, estrogen & Decreased progesterone
Increased FSH, LH & Decreased estrogen, progesterone
Increased FSH, LH, progesterone & Decreased estrogen

questions.solution:
Both FSH and LH levels are high during midcycle at the time of ovulation Mid cycle LH surge causes positive feedback mechanism which causes ovulation.

Follicular phase (days 0–14)

  • A primordial follicle develops to the Graafian stage, with atresia of neighboring follicles.
  • LH and FSH receptors are up-regulated in theca and granulosa cells.
  • Estradiol levels increase and cause proliferation of the uterus.
  • FSH and LH levels are suppressed by the negative feedback effect of estradiol on the anterior pituitary.
  • Progesterone levels are low.

Ovulation (day 14)

  • Occurs 14 days before menses, regardless of cycle length. Thus, in a 28-day cycle, ovulation occurs on day 14; in a 35-day cycle, ovulation occurs on day 22.
  • A burst of estradiol synthesis at the end of the follicular phase has a positive feedback effect on the secretion of FSH and LH (LH surge).
  • Ovulation occurs as a result of the estrogen-induced LH surge.
  • Estrogen levels decrease just after ovulation (but rise again during the luteal phase).
  • Cervical mucus increases in quantity; it becomes less viscous and more penetrable by sperm.

Luteal phase (days 14–28)

  • The corpus luteum begins to develop, and it synthesizes estrogen and progesterone. Vascularity and secretory activity of the endometrium increase to prepare for receipt of a fertilized egg.
  • Basal body temperature increases because of the effect of progesterone on the hypothalamic thermoregulatory center.
  • If fertilization does not occur, the corpus luteum regresses at the end of the luteal phase. As a result, estradiol and progesterone levels decrease abruptly.

Menses (days 0–4)

  • The endometrium is sloughed because of the abrupt withdrawal of estradiol and progesterone.

questions.text: Which of the following condition is not a contraindication for hepatic resection in metastatic disease?

choices.text: Involvement of the main bile duct
Tumour thrombus in main portal vein

questions.solution:
Extraductal obstructive jaundice is not a contraindication for hepatic resection in metastatic disease.

Hepatic resection is gold standard and treatment of choice in primary liver cancers and hepatic metastasis.

  • Right hepatectomy – segments  5, 6 , 7 , 8.
  • Left hepatectomy - segments is 2, 3, 4.
  • Right trisectionectomy or extended right hepatectomy – segments 4, 5, 6, 7, 8
  • Left trisectionectomy or extended left hepatectomy – segments 2, 3, 4, 5, 8.

Contraindications for hepatic resection in metastatic disease:

  • Total hepatic or bilobar tumour involvement
  • Advanced cirrhosis
  • Locoregional recurrence
  • Retroperitoneal, mediastinal or portal nodal involvement
  • Distant metastasis
  • Tumour thrombus in the main portal vein /vena cava

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about the given virus?

choices.text: Incubation period is less than 24 hours
Patients are susceptible to reinfection even after complete cure
It is eliminated from semen within 2 weeks

questions.solution:
The above image is of the Ebola virus showing the bowl of spaghetti appearance. Patients with Ebola virus disease are susceptible to reinfection even after complete cure.

Ebola virus:

  • It is the cause of an emerging disease called Ebola virus disease and is widespread in Africa.
  • It belongs to the Filoviridae family.
  • Incubation period: 2 to 21 days.
  • Transmission is through contact with infectious bodily fluids or organs of animals like chimpanzees and monkeys.
  • Human to human transmission is through blood or body fluids of an infected symptomatic person.
  • It can remain in semen for up to 3 months, although sexual transmission has not been reported yet.
  • Symptoms include fever; intense weakness; vomiting; diarrhea; rashes; and, in extreme cases, internal and external bleeding.
  • Current treatment is mainly supportive.
  • Patients are susceptible to reinfection even after complete cure.

questions.text: The marked part "x" in the given image is ______________
questions.solution:
The marked part in the given image is the bulb of vestibule.

Bulbs of the Vestibule are a paired mass of erectile tissue on each side of the vaginal orifice and are the homologues of the bulb of the penis of the corpus spongiosum.

Other options:

Option A: Ischiocavernosus: In males covers crus of penis, helps in maintaining penile erection. In females, it covers crus of clitoris and helps in maintaining pressure in clitoris.

Option B: Crus of clitoris: The clitoral crura are two erectile tissue structures, which together form a V-shape. Each of the V converges on the clitoral body. At each divergent point is a corpus cavernosum of clitoris. The crura are attached to the pubic arch, and are adjacent to the vestibular bulbs.

Option C: Bulbospongiosus: In males, it lies in midline anterior to perineal body, has two symmetrical parts which unite with a median raphe. In females it is separate and covers superficial part of vestibular bulb and glands. In males, it helps to empty the urethra of urine after the bladder has emptied. It may assist in the final stage of erection by compressing the deep dorsal vein of the penis. In females, it constricts the vaginal orifice and express the secretions of the greater vestibular glands.

questions.text: Pilon fracture is:
questions.solution: Pilon fracture is an intra-articular fracture of the distal tibia. A pilon fracture is a descriptive term suggesting that the talus acts as a hammer, or pestle, that impacts and injures the tibial plafond.

questions.text: What is the type of hypersensitivity involved in multiple sclerosis?
questions.solution:
Multiple sclerosis is a Type 4 hypersensitivity reaction with specificity of pathogenic T cells to antigens in myelin (e.g.myelin basic protein).

Principal Mechanisms of Tissue Injury:

  • Inflammation mediated by TH1 and TH17 cytokines
  • Myelin destruction by activated macrophages

Clinicopathologic manifestations is due to demyelination in CNS with perivascular inflammation.

  • Lepromin test
  • Multiple sclerosis

  • Contact dermatitis
  • Sarcoidosis
  • Primary biliary cirrhosis
  • Type I lepra reaction
  • Crohn’s disease
  • Psoriasis

questions.text: Gastric lavage can be performed in case of poisoning by:
questions.solution:
Gastric lavage can be performed in case of carbolic poisoning.

In carbolic acid poisoning, if the patient survives for 48 hrs, there will be carboluria followed by anuria. The victim will pass dark, smoky urine which soon turns olive green on standing due to oxidation of hydroquinone and pyrocatechol. 

It is a corrosive acid, however, it hardens the GI mucosa producing a leather bottle stomach and anesthetizes the nerve endings. This allows for gastric lavage. 

Contraindications of gastric lavage:

  • Corrosives poisoning (except carbolic acid)
  • Convulsants/CNS stimulants
  • Comatose patients
  • Volatile poison
  • Upper GI pathology (eg. esophageal varices)
  • Hypothermic patient
  • Severe heart disease
  • Advanced pregnancy

Sulphuric acid and kerosene are corrosives and strychnine is a convulsant. Hence gastric lavage is not done in these poisonings.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of action of corrosives

Corrosive Mechanism of Action Type of necrosis
Strong acids Hydrogen ions penetrate tissues and lead to cell death and eschar formation. This prevents further hydrogen ion penetration and protects against deeper injury. Coagulation necrosis
Carbolic acid Same as other strong acids, but also hardens the GI mucosa. Produces a leather bottle stomach and anesthetizes the nerve endings. This allows for gastric lavage. Coagulation necrosis 
Oxalic acid Same as other strong acids, but also scavenges calcium ions, leading to hypocalcemia and Calcium oxalate renal stones.  Coagulation necrosis
Hydrofluoric acid Fluoride ions scavenge intracellular cations, such as calcium and magnesium and inhibit Na/K ATPase, disrupting cell membranes. This leads to hypocalcemia and hypomagnesemia. Liquefactive necrosis
Strong alkalis Hydroxide ions easily penetrate tissues, leading to the dissolution of cell membranes. It is associated with deep tissue injury. Liquefactive necrosis

questions.text: Pontogeniculooccipital spike is characteristic of the _____ phase of sleep?
questions.solution:
Pontogeniculo-occipital spike (PGO) is characteristic of REM sleep. There is an occurrence of large phasic potentials arising from cholinergic neurons in pons, which pass rapidly to the lateral geniculate body and then to the occipital cortex.

Related Pearl: Stages of Arousal and Sleep

  • Fatigued and tired
  • The head droops, momentary lapses of attention
  • Sleepy but not asleep

Decrease in alpha-wave amplitude and frequency

NREM 1 (N1) (5%)
  • Light sleep-easily aroused by moderate stimuli or even by muscle jerks
  • Continuous lack of awareness
  • Mixed frequency waves  (predominantly 2-7 Hz).
  • Gap in alpha rhythm is filled with theta (4–8 Hz) and delta (slower than 4 Hz) activity
  • Vertex waves

NREM 2 (N2) (50-60%)

Further lack of sensitivity to activation and arousal
  • Predominant theta activity (4-7 Hz)
  • K-complex and sleep spindles occur periodically

NREM 3 and 4 (N3) (15-20%)
  • Deep sleep
  • Arousal only with vigorous stimuli
  • Sleep-arousal most difficult

Delta>theta activity

REM (paradoxical) sleep (20-25%)
  • 50–90 min after sleep onset, episodes repeated every 60–90 min, each episode lasting about 10 min
  • Dreaming occurs, rapid eye movements, increase in brain O2 consumption
  • EEG resembles that of alert awake state.
  • Saw tooth waves

Note: According to the new classification, stage 3 and 4 of NREM are grouped together as N3. So as per recent staging NREM has 3 stages (N1, N2, N3)

questions.text: All are true about first trimester abortion except

choices.text: Mifepristone 200 mg oral given on day 1
Suction evacuation is done at around 7-12 weeks
Medical outpatient abortion is effective upto 9 weeks

questions.solution:
Dinoprostone 20 mg vaginal suppository is given for second trimester abortion and not first trimester abortion.

Dinoprostone gel (PGE2 analog) was used for cervical ripening and resulted in a shorter induction abortion interval which is much beneficial in seconfd trimester than the first trimester. Also, it is quite expensive and needs refrigeration.

Misoprostol, a synthetic analogue of PGE1 being much cheaper, safe and capable of being easily stored at room temperature has been tried by both oral and vaginal routes.

Suction evacuation is done at around 7-12 weeks. For suction abortion done at <6 weeks gestation, a distinct drawback is that the pregnancy may be small and missed by the curette. To identiy placenta, the aspirated contents are rinsed in a strainer to remove blood, and then placed in a clear plastic container with saline and examined with back lighting. Placental tissue macroscopically appears soft, fluffy, and feathery.

Outpatient medical abortion is an acceptable option for pregnancies with a menstrual age < 63 days (9weeks)

First trimester 

Mifepristone/Misoprostol Combined Regimen (Recommended): 200 mg of oral Mifepristone followed 1-2 days later by 800 mcg of buccal, vaginal or sublingual Misoprostol


Misoprostol only regimen (Alternative): 800 μg misoprostol administered vaginally, sublingually or buccally.

 

Methotrexate/Misoprostol

(d) Methotrexate, 50 mg/m2 body surface area intramuscularly or orally; followed in 3-7 days by:

(e) Misoprostol, 800 mcg vaginally. Repeat if needed 1 week after methotrexate initially given
Second Trimester

Mifepristone/Misoprostol Combined Regimen (Recommended) : 200 mg of oral Mifepristone followed 1-2 days later by 400 mcg of buccal, vaginal or sublingual Misoprostol every 3 hours

Misoprostol Alone(Alternative): 400 mcg of buccal, vaginal or sublingual Misoprostol every 3 hours

Dinoprostone

20 mg vaginal suppository every 4 hr

Concentrated Oxytocin

50 units oxytocin in 500 mL of normal saline infused during 3 hr; then 1-hr diuresis (no oxytocin); then escalate sequentially in a similar fashion through 150, 200, 250, and finally 300 units oxytocin each in 500 mL normal saline

questions.text: Most common cause of non obstructive hydrocephalus is
questions.solution:
Most common cause of non obstructive hydrocephalus is subarachnoid haemorrhage.

  • Most common cause of obstructive hydrocephalus is aqueductal stenosis.
  • Most common cause of acquired hydrocephalus is postinflammatory obstruction.

questions.text: False statement about primary myelofibrosis is _____________

choices.text: Only potentially curative treatment is allogenic stem cell transplantation
Hepatomegaly is the most common manifestation
Myeloblasts may be seen in peripheral blood

questions.solution:
In primary myelofibrosis, mild hepatomegaly may accompany the splenomegaly but is unusual in the absence of splenic enlargement.

Primary myelofibrosis (myelofibrosis with myeloid metaplasia/ agnogenic myeloid metaplasia) is a myeloproliferative disorder characterized by fibrosis of the bone marrow, splenomegaly, and a leukoerythroblastic peripheral blood picture (Myeloblasts may be seen in peripheral blood) with teardrop poikilocytosis.

Myelofibrosis can also occur as a secondary process following the other myeloproliferative disorders (eg, polycythemia vera, essential thrombocytosis).

Fibrosis occurs in response to increased secretion of platelet -derived growth factor (PDGF) and other cytokines. In response to bone marrow fibrosis, extramedullary hematopoiesis takes place in the liver, spleen, and lymph nodes. In these sites, mesenchymal cells responsible for fetal hematopoiesis can be reactivated. Abnormalities of ]AK2 and MPL may be involved in the pathogenesis.

Treatment:

  • Anemic patients are supported with transfusion. Anemia can also be controlled with androgens, prednisone, thalidomide, or lenalidomide.
  • First-line therapy for myelofibrosis-associated splenomegaly is hydroxyurea, which is effective in reducing spleen size.
  • Ruxolitinib, the first JAK2 inhibitor to be FDA approved, results in reduction of spleen size, improvement of constitutional symptoms, and an overall survival benefit. However, ruxolitinib can exacerbate cytopenias.
  • Splenectomy is not routinely performed but is indicated for medication refractory splenic enlargement.
  • The only potentially curative option for this disease is allogeneic stem cell transplantation in selected patients.

questions.text: Route of administration of Clevidipine is usually _________.
questions.solution:
Clevidipine is a novel dihydropyridine L-type Ca2+ channel blocker. Clevidipine is formulated as a lipid emulsion and administered intravenously that has a very rapid (t1/2 ~2 minutes) onset and offset of action. It is metabolized by esterases in blood, similar to the fate of esmolol.

Clevidipine preferentially affects arterial smooth muscle compared to targeting veins or the heart.

It may be useful in controlling blood pressure in severe or perioperative hypertension when oral therapy is not possible or desirable. Infusions are typically started at a rate of 1-2 μg/kg/min and titrated to the desired effect on blood pressure.

questions.text: Most common site of classic Kaposi sarcoma is?
questions.solution:
Most common site of Kaposi sarcoma is lower limbs.

Kaposi sarcoma (KS) is vascular neoplasm caused by human herpesvirus 8 (HHV8) that is highly associated with acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS).

The lesions of KS are characterized by the proliferation of spindle-shaped cells that express markers of both endothelial cells (vascular or lymphatic) and smooth muscle cells. The lesions may arise from primitive mesenchymal precursors of vascular channels.

Many of the features of KS suggest that it is not a malignant tumor (despite its ominous name). Spindle cells in many KS lesions are polyclonal or oligoclonal, although more advanced lesions occasionally show monoclonality.

Related Pearl: Classification of Kaposi sarcoma

Classic

  • Older men of eastern European and Meditteranean origin
  • Not associated with HIV
  • Skin plaques and nodules

Endemic African

  • Seen in HIV seronegative individuals
  • Predominant lymph node and visceral involvement

Transplant associated

  • Solid organ transplant recipients
  • Involves lymph nodes, mucosa, and viscera
  • Cutaneous lesions may be absent

AIDS-associated epidemic KS

  • HIV infected individuals
  • Involves lymph nodes

questions.text: A primi with 37 weeks has the following findings on ANC check up: Breech presentation, placenta not low lying, pelvis adequate. Next step of management is _________
questions.solution:
In any case of breech, we first try external cephalic version followed by vaginal delivery.

The American College of Obstetricians and Gynecologists recommends that version be offered and attempted whenever possible. Its success rate averages about 60 percent.

Pre–requisites for ECV:

  • More than 36 weeks
  • Liquor should be adequate
  • Membrane should be intact
  • No C/I for vaginal delivery
  • Single fetal pregnancy

Primigravida with breech plus any C/I for ECV = Caesarian section.

Multigravida with breech plus any C/I for ECV = Assisted breech vaginal delivery.

questions.text: IUCD having the longest life span is _____________
questions.solution:
CuT 380 A has the highest life span of 10 years.

Copper T-380A (Paraguard): It is named so for the 380 mm2 of copper surface area. A higher surface area of copper results in higher contraceptive efficacy. Hence the Copper T-380A has been able to achieve superior contraception while maintaining a similar side-effect profile

The Copper T-380A has a plastic T-shaped core with copper placed around the vertical stem and horizontal arms. A silver core within the copper sheath is included to prevent fragmentation of the copper, extending the life span of the Copper T-380A.

The frame of the Copper T-380A is connected to a monofilament thread that protrudes through the cervical canal into the upper vagina. This facilitates easy removal and allows the user to ensure that the IUD remains in the uterus.

IUCD Life span
Cu T 380A 10 years
CuT 200 3 years
Multi loaded Cu 250  3 years
LNG IUS /Mirena

5 years
Progestasert 1 year
Nova-T 5 years

questions.text: The lower part of the vagina is derived from
questions.solution:
The lower part of the vagina is derived from urogenital sinus.

The upper part is derived from paramesonephric duct or Mullerian duct.

Uterus develops from two paramesonephric duct on either side which unites to form a single uterus.

questions.text: A 6-year-old boy presents with features mimicking appendicitis. Upon removal, the appendix is found to be grossly and histologically normal. A stool examination revealed motile gram-negative rods with a safety pin appearance. What is the etiology of this infection?
questions.solution:
It is a case of pseudo-appendicitis (appendicitis-like syndrome), caused by Yersinia enterocolitica. The picture showing bipolar staining or safety pin appearance is suggestive of Yersinia species on Wayson stain.

Yersinia enterocolitica is a gram-negative bacillus with a safety pin appearance. It causes gastroenteritis or mesenteric lymphadenitis after ingestion of contaminated food or water. 

In young children, it causes a self-limiting diarrheal illness. Patients with HLA-B27 who were infected with Y. enterocolitica develop arthralgia, arthritis, and erythema nodosum. 

Yersinia can be recovered from the stool of infected patients using selective media called CIN (Cefsulodin-Irgasan-Novobiocin) agar incubated at room temperature. Their colonies have a bull's eye appearance with a red center on CIN agar. Yersinia enterocolitica is motile at 25 °C, which differentiates it from Y. pestis which is non-motile.

Treatment for gastroenteritis caused by Y. enterocolitica consists of ciprofloxacin or a third-generation cephalosporin.

Other options : 

Option A: Clostridium difficile is a long slender gram-positive bacillus. It has large spores which are oval and subterminal. It is an opportunistic organism that rarely causes disease and does so only when normal flora is lost. It causes acute colitis with bloody or watery diarrhea and pseudomembranous colitis. 

Option B: Salmonella typhi are gram-negative rods that are motile with peritrichous flagella. It causes enteric fever or typhoid fever. 

Option C: Vibrio parahaemolyticus resembles V. cholera in its morphology except that it is capsulated shows bipolar staining and has a tendency to pleomorphism. Strains isolated from humans are hemolytic on Wagatsuma agar (special high salt blood agar). This is known as the Kanagawa phenomenon. It causes food poisoning associated with marine food intake. Abdominal pain, vomiting diarrhea, and fever are the usual signs.

questions.text: Pseudo-Darier's sign is seen in which of the following conditions?
questions.solution:
Pseudo-Darier's sign is the temporarily increased induration or piloerection on firm stroking of a lesion, seen in smooth muscle hamartoma.

Darier's sign is the development of urticarial halo and erythema around the reddish-brown macules after mild trauma, including scratching or rubbing of the lesion. It is caused by the release of histamine due to degranulation of the mast cells. It is seen in cutaneous mastocytosis, most common among them is urticaria pigmentosa. In rare cases, it may be seen in juvenile xanthogranuloma and acute lymphoblastic leukemia of neonates.

Darier's sign:

Note: Darier disease is a dermatosis characterized by a chronic eruption of keratotic papules, which shows acantholysis and dyskeratosis. Darier sign and pseudo-Darier sign are not related to Darier disease.

questions.text: A new drug called Lumoxiti is effective for curing Hairy cell leukemia. Which of the following is true about the prevalence and incidence of the disease?

choices.text: No change in incidence and increase in prevalence
No change in incidence but decrease in prevalence

questions.solution:
In this case, the new drug is effective for the treatment of that disease, so the duration of the disease is decreased thereby decreasing the prevalence of the disease. There is no change in the incidence of the disease.

Prevalence depends on two factors, the incidence, and duration of illness. If the population is stable and incidence and duration are unchanging, the relationship between incidence and prevalence can be expressed as:

P = I X D

(I - Incidence and D - Mean duration)

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: Which statement about Vi antigen of Salmonella is false?
questions.solution:
Vi antigen of Salmonella is heat labile.

Salmonella possesses the following antigens based on which they are classified and identified:

  1. Flagellar antigen H
  2. Somatic antigen O
  3. Surface antigen Vi
  • Vi antigen is a capsular antigen which is polysaccharide in nature.
  • It is heat labile and alcohol stable.
  • It is least antigenic and is present only in S.typhi, S.paratyphi C, and S.dublin.

questions.text: The number of ASHA visits after home delivery is ______
questions.solution:
ASHA home visits:

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (no visit on day 1)
  • 5 visits to those born in a facility through LSCS (no visits on day 1 and day 3)

The total incentive received by ASHA for HBNC (Home-based newborn care) is Rs.250.

Related Pearl: ASHA

ASHA stands for Accredited Social Health Activist.

General norms with respect to ASHA workers:

  • Must be a woman in the age group of 25-45 years - married/divorced/widow
  • Must be a resident of that village
  • Formal education of up to 10th standard 
    • If no candidates are available, the requirement can be relaxed to the 8th standard
  • At least 1 ASHA for a population of 1000 
    • In tribal, hilly, and desert areas, the norm can be relaxed to 1 ASHA per habitation

States can relax the norms on population and educational qualifications on a case-to-case basis, depending on the local conditions. However, these are exceptions and not the general norm.

Responsibilities of ASHA:

    • Health education and awareness
    • Reproductive and child health and family planning
    • Facilitate the access to health services
    • Promotion of sanitation and household toilet construction
    • Provision of primary medical care for minor ailments
    • Provider of DOTS
    • Depot holder of essentials like ORS, iron and folic acid tablets, condoms, disposable delivery kits, etc.
    • Dispersal of health information on her community to higher centres
    • Some responsibilities are integrated with Anganwadi workers and Auxiliary Nurse Midwife

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based Newborn care (HBNC) 

  • 7 visits after home delivery (on days 1, 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42)
  • 6 visits after institutional delivery (on days 3, 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42) in case of a vaginal delivery; and 5 visits in cases of Caesarean section delivery, where the mother returns home after 5-6 days, i.e, on days - 7, 14, 21, 28 and 42.

Home visits by ASHA under Home-based care of young child (HBYC)

  • A total of 5 visits are scheduled after 42 days under the Home-Based Care of the Young Child(HBYC).
  • ASHA will provide quarterly home visits on the 3rd, 6th, 9th, 12th and 15th months

questions.text: A female constable of a police station accused the sub-inspector in charge of seducing her to have intercourse with her. He should be charged under I.P.C _________
questions.solution:
The sub inspector should be charged under IPC section 376 C since it is a case of rape by a person with authority.

The latest Supreme Court guidelines on rape:

  • Minimum Punishment for Rape has been increased from 7 years (earlier) to 10 years (updated). The maximum punishment remains the same, i.e. life imprisonment.
  • A new sub - section (3) has been added to Section 376, which prescribes the minimum punishment of 20 years for rape of a woman under 16 years of age.
  • A new Section 376AB has been inserted which prescribes the minimum punishment of 20 years rigorous imprisonment to a person committing rape on a woman less than 12 years of age.
  • New sections namely 376DA and 376DB prescribe minimum punishment of life imprisonment for persons involved in gang rape of woman aged less than 16 years and 12 years respectively.
  • Death penalty has been prescribed for gang rape on woman below 12 years of age.

Related Pearl: Sexual Offences

65(1) Persons committing the offence of rape on a woman under16 years of age Rigorous imprisonment of not less than 20 years which may extend to imprisonment for life. 376
66 The person committing an offense of rape and inflicting injury which causes death or causes the woman to be in a persistent vegetative state. Rigorous imprisonment of not less than 20 years may extend to imprisonment for life or with death. 376A
65(2) The person committing an offense of rape on a woman under 12 years of age Rigorous imprisonment of not less than 20 years but which may extend to imprisonment for life with fine or with death 376AB
67 Sexual intercourse by the husband upon his wife during separation, without her consent Imprisonment for not less than 2 years but which may extend to 7 years and with a fine. 376B
68 Sexual intercourse by a person in authority (police officer, public servant, member of armed forces, management or staff of a jail, remand home or other places of custody and management or staff of a hospital) who induces or seduces any female inmate of such jail, remand home, place, or institution to have sexual intercourse with him, such sexual intercourse not amounting to the offense of rape. Rigorous imprisonment for not less than 5 years but which may extend to 10 years and with a fine. 376C
70(1) Gang Rape Rigorous imprisonment for not less than 20 years which may extend to imprisonment for life with fine 376D
70(2) Gang rape on a woman under 18 years of age Rigorous imprisonment for life and with fine 376DA
71 Repeat offenders Imprisonment for life or with death 376E
74 Assault or use of criminal force to woman with intent to outrage her modesty Imprisonment for not less than one year, extending up to five years and with fine. 354

 

As per the The Gazette of India, from the Ministry of Law and Justice, Bharatiya Nyaya Sanhita Document 2023

questions.text: All of the following statements about Na+/K+ - ATPase pump are true except ___________

choices.text: It is an electrogenic pump with a coupling ratio of 3:2
Intracellular site of alpha subunit binds ouabain
Beta subunit contains 3 extracellular glycosylation site
It plays a minor role in maintenance of RMP

questions.solution:
The extracellular site of alpha subunit binds ouabain and 2K+ ions.

Na+/K+ - ATPase Pump:

  • The most common pump, present in all parts of the body.
  • It is a heterodimer made up of an α and a β subunit.
  • ICF side of αlpha subunit binds ATP and 3 Na+ ions. It also has a phosphorylation site.
  • ECF side of αlpha subunit has binding sites for 2 K+ ions and ouabain.
  • The beta subunit contains 3 ECF glycosylation sites
  • It is an electrogenic pump with a coupling ratio of 3:2
  • It regulates cell volume, pressure and also maintains RMP of a cell (5-10%)
  • The pump is stimulated by thyroid hormones, insulin, aldosterone, whereas it is inhibited by ouabain and related digitalis glycosides.

questions.text: Given below is the Direct immunofluorescence image of a patient with transient blisters over skin in seborrheic regions without involving the mucosa. What is the pattern seen in this case?

choices.text: Fish net pattern in Pemphigus Vulgaris
Dilapidated bricks in Hailey Hailey disease
Intercellular space staining pattern in Pemphigus foliaceous

questions.solution:
The intercellular space staining in Direct Immunofluorescence causes fishnet appearance in both pemphigus vulgaris and foliaceous. However, transient blisters in seborrheic regions (scalp, face, chest and upper back) without the involvement of mucosa points towards Pemphigus foliaceous.

  • Pemphigus foliaceous (PF) is a more superficial acantholytic blistering (Subcorneal blisters) disease when compared to Pemphigus vulgaris. (Pemphigus vulgaris is characterized by intraepidermal acantholytic blisters).
  • The mucosa is spared in PF while it is involved in PV.
  • PF patients exhibit shallow erosions associated with erythema, scale, and crust formation while PV patients have intact blisters. In fact, mild cases of PF resemble severe seborrheic dermatitis.
  • Severe PF may cause extensive exfoliation. Sun exposure (ultraviolet irradiation) may be an aggravating factor.
  • PF has immunopathologic features in common with PV.
  • Direct immunofluorescence microscopy of perilesional skin demonstrates IgG on the surface of keratinocytes.
  • Similarly, patients with PF have circulating IgG autoantibodies directed against the surface of keratinocytes. In PF, autoantibodies are directed against Dsg-1 only. (In PV, autoantibodies are directed against Dsg-3 & Dsg-1).

Related Pearl: Vesiculobullous Disorders

Disease Clinical Manifestations Histology Immuno-pathology Autoantigens
Pemphigus vulgaris       Flaccid blisters, denuded skin,oro-mucosal lesions Acantholytic blister formed in suprabasal layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG on keratinocytes- fish net pattern Dsg3, Dsg1 in patients with skin involvement
Pemphigus foliaceus       Crusts and shallow erosions on the scalp, central face, upper chest, and back Acantholytic blister formed in superficial layer of epidermis  Cell surface deposits of IgG onkeratinocytes Dsg1
Bullous pemphigoid     Large tense blisters on flexor surfaces and trunk  Subepidermal blister with eosinophil-rich infiltrate Linear band of IgG and/or C3 in epidermal BMZ  BPAG1, BPAG2
Dermatitis herpetiformis      Extremely pruritic small papules and vesicles on elbows, knees, buttocks, and posterior neck Subepidermal blister with neutrophils in dermal papillae  Granular deposits of IgA at the tips of dermal papillae Epidermal trans-glutaminase
Linear IgA disease     Pruritic small papules on extensor surfaces; occasionally larger, arciform blisters  Subepidermal blister with neutrophil-rich infiltrate  Linear band of IgA in epidermalBMZ BPAG2
Epidermo-lysis bullosa acquisita Tense bullae and erosions  Subepidermal blister  IgG and C3 DEJ – Continous and linear  Type VII collagen

 The images below shows clinical pictures of pemphigus patients.

  • Image B - heavily clotted and crusted lesions around the mouth in a patient with paraneoplastic pemphigus
  • Image C - skin lesions found on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus vulgaris
  • Image D - skin lesions on the trunk in a patient with pemphigus foliaceus

questions.text: All the following statements about knee joint region are true except:

choices.text: Lateral meniscus covers a larger area of the tibial articular surface than the medial meniscus
Movements of lateral meniscus are restricted compared to medial meniscus
Peripheral tears of menisci have the potential to heal satisfactorily with surgical intervention
Suprapatellar bursa is an extension of knee joint cavity

questions.solution:
The lateral meniscus in the knee joint is grooved posterolaterally by the popliteus tendon which separates it from lateral collateral ligament, thus making it more mobile.

Lateral Meniscus:

  • More mobile.
  • Forms approximately 4/5th of a circle, and hence covers a larger area of tibial articular surface than medial meniscus.

Medial meniscus:

  • Relatively fixed and therefore moves much less than lateral meniscus.
  • Semicircular in shape. Covers less area than lateral meniscus.

Option 3:

  • The peripheral zone of menisci are vascularized by capillary loops from the fibrous capsule and synovial membrane, whereas their inner regions are less vascular.
  • Therefore peripheral tears (i.e in the vascularized zone) have the potential to heal satisfactorily, especially with surgical intervention. On the other hand, tears in the less vascular or inner zones seldom heal spontaneously; if surgery is indicated, these menisci are often resected.

Option 4:

  • Suprapatellar bursa is the superior extension of knee joint cavity.
  • It lies between the femur and suprapatellar part of quadriceps femoris.

Clinical Consideration: 

Higer chance of tear - Medial meniscus is attached to the medial collateral ligament and is easily torn because it is not very mobile

questions.text: Features of acute severe attack of asthma include all of the following except?
questions.solution:
In an attack of acute severe asthma, the FEV1 is usually between 33 and 50% of the predicted value.

Features of Acute severe attack of asthma include:

  • Inability to speak a complete sentence in one breath
  • Pulse >120/min
  • Respiratory rate >25/min
  • FEV1 between 33 to 50% of predicted
  • Pulsus paradoxus of >10 mmHg

questions.text:
On chest x-ray PA view, right cardiac border is formed by _______.

1. Superior vena cava
2. Inferior vena cava
3. Right atrium
4. Right ventricle
questions.solution:
On a chest x-ray PA view,

Right cardiac border formed by

  • Superior vena cava (SVC)
  • Right atrium
  • Inferior vena cava (IVC)

Left cardiac border formed by

  • Subclavian artery
  • Aortic knuckle
  • Pulmonary artery segment
  • Left atrial appendage
  • Left ventricle

Posteroanterior view (PA view) is the most commonly done chest x-ray view.

PA view is usually done in full inspiration and standing position.

Ideally, there should be no rotation. If there is no rotation, the distance between the medial end of the clavicle and the spinous process will be equidistant, on both sides. 

In a normal chest x-ray, the left dome of the diaphragm is lower than the right because the heart pushes the left dome down.

questions.text: Triple Sugar Iron (TSI) is a(n)  ________
questions.solution:
TSI (triple sugar iron) is a composite medium which indicates whether bacteria ferments glucose only, or lactose and sucrose. It also indicates with/without gas formation, besides indicating H2S production.

  • Selective medium:  Solid media that allow certain organisms(pathogens) to grow and inhibits others (normal flora). Eg. LJ medium for isolation of M.Tuberculosis, TCBS for vibrio species.
  • Enriched medium: When a basal medium is added with additional nutrients such as blood, serum, or egg, it is called enriched medium. Eg. Blood agar: prepared by adding 5-10% of sheep blood to the molten nutrient agar at 45°C.
  • Enrichment medium (broth): Liquid media that allow certain organisms (pathogens)  to grow and inhibit others (normal flora ). Eg. Selenite F and Tetrathionate broth for salmonella and shigella species.

questions.text: Which of the following tests for M. tuberculosis requires the use of whole blood as clinical sample?
questions.solution:
In IGRA, sensitized T lymphocytes (from whole blood) of suspected individuals, are exposed to highly specific M.tuberculosis antigen such as CFP –10 and ESAT 6 which leads to release of high level of  IFN- gamma.

Interferon gamma release assay is used to diagnose latent tuberculosis infection.

Line probe assay: It is a molecular method which detects drug resistance from sputum samples, but only from smear positive cases. It is less sensitive for smear negative cases because it is based on hybridization techniques.

Gene Expert: It detects growth and resistance to rifampicin. It takes very less time (2hours). It is a cartridge based nucleic acid amplification technique (CB-NAAT). Pleural biopsy is better specimen than pleural fluid for gene expert.

questions.text: Side effects of minoxidil are all except?
questions.solution:
Minoxidil does not cause diuresis.

It can cause: Fluid and salt retention, cardiovascular effects, and hypertrichosis.

Retention of salt and water results from increased proximal renal tubular reabsorption, which is in turn secondary to reduced renal perfusion pressure and to reflex stimulation of renal tubular alpha adrenergic receptors.

Cardiovascular effects are due to baroreceptor mediated activation of sympathetic nervous system. There is an increase in heart rate, myocardial contractility, and myocardial O2 consumption. Thus, myocardial ischemia can be induced by minoxidil in patients with coronary artery disease. The cardiac sympathetic responses are attenuated by concurrent administration of a β adrenergic blocker.

Excess hair growth occurs in patients who receive minoxidil for an extended period and is probably a consequence of K+ channel activation.

questions.text: X linked Sphingolipidosis presenting with telangiectatic skin lesions, kidney failure and acroparesthesia will have ________________
questions.solution:
The only X-linked sphingolipidosis is Fabry disease. It is caused due to deficiency of alpha-galactosidase deficiency.

It presents with telangiectatic skin lesions, kidney failure, corneal opacity, acroparesthesia, and Fabry crisis (agonizing, burning pain in the extremities). Pain is the most debilitating symptom in childhood and adolescence.

There is an accumulation of globosides in the brain, heart, kidneys, and skin. It is treated by recombinant human enzyme replacement therapy.

Other options:

Beta-galactosidase deficiency is found in Krabbe disease.

Beta glucocerebrosidase deficiency is found in Gaucher's disease.

Ceramidase deficiency is found in Farber's disease.
