questions.text:
The ultrasound diagnosis of pneumothorax depends on :
  1. Presence of Quad sign
  2. Absence of Sliding sign
  3. Presence of Seashore sign
  4. Absence of Comet-tail artifacts
  5. Presence of a barcode sign
questions.solution:
The ultrasound diagnosis of pneumothorax depends on the presence of barcode sign, absence of the sliding lung and absence of comet-tail artifacts that are seen in relation to a normal lung–pleural interface.

Normally, lung sliding corresponds to the to-and-fro movement of the visceral pleura on the parietal pleura that occurs with respiration. It is a dynamic sign and can be identified on ultrasound as horizontal movement along the pleural line.

In pneumothorax, the air separates visceral and parietal pleura and prevents visualization of visceral pleura. Hence lung sliding is absent and typical to and fro movement and shimmering of the pleural lines will not be present.

Comet tail artifacts are seen in the normal lungs due to the acoustic impedance differences between water and air, whereas it is absent in pneumothorax. 

The image given below shows a sliding sign seen in a normal lung.  

Option A: The quad sign is seen in pleural effusion. It consists of four lines representing the pleura, rib, fluid, and lung. 

Option C: The motionless portion of the chest above the pleural line creates horizontal ‘waves,’ and the sliding below the pleural line creates a granular pattern, the ‘sand’. The resultant picture is one that resembles waves crashing onto the sand and is therefore called the ‘seashore sign’ and is present in normal lungs.

questions.text: A 2-year-old malnourished child presents with loose stools. The child has symmetrical edema, weight/height <70% of expected and height/age < 85% of expected. Management of this child involves ___________

choices.text: Continue aggressive hydration even after dehydration resolves for the next 2 hours
Use low sodium ORS for rehydration 5ml/kg every 30 min for first 2 hours
Give 5ml/kg of ringer lactate IV if unconscious

questions.solution:
The above child has severe malnutrition. Management should involve the use of low sodium ORS for rehydration 5 ml/kg every 30 min for first 2 hours.

WHO Classification:

Parameter  Moderate malnutrition Severe malnutrition
Symmetrical edema No Yes
Weight/height (wasting) -2 to -3 S.D(70 to 79% of expected) < -3 S.D (<70%)
Height/age(stunting) -2 to -3 S.D(85 to 89%) < -3 S.D (<85%)

Treatment:

  • Do not give IV fluids unless the child is in shock.
  • Give ReSoMal (low-sodium rehydration solution for malnutrition) 5 mL/kg every 30 min for the first 2 hours orally or NG tube.
  • Then give 5-10 mL/kg in alternate hours for up to 10 hour. The amount depends on stool loss and eagerness to drink. Feed-in the other alternate hour.
  • Give ReSoMal after each watery stool as a prevention strategy.

Treatment of hypoglycaemia in malnutrition:

  • If conscious: 10% glucose (50 mL), or a feed or 1 teaspoon sugar under the tongue-whichever is the quickest.
  • If unconscious: Immediately give sterile 10% glucose (5 mL/kg) by IV.

questions.text: A study was conducted in a school to compare the heights of children of different grades. The children from 5th grade to 10th grade, were divided according to their grades, and their heights were measured. The appropriate statistical test of significance that should be used is ______
questions.solution:
Since more than two groups (from 5th class to 10th class) are compared in the above study, ANOVA test should be used.

Analysis of variance or ANOVA is used when more than 2 groups (means) are compared for difference.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups or more than 2 groups .
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember the paired test is mainly used in the comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples. For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: Which of the following Darrow Yannet diagram is suggestive of adrenal insufficiency?
questions.solution:
The Darrow Yannet diagram shown in image 4 depicts adrenal insufficiency. In adrenal insufficiency, there is hypo-osmotic volume contraction.

Darrow Yannet diagrams depict the change in plasma osmolarity and plasma volume in various conditions. The dotted line in the diagram is the change after either addition or removal of fluid.

Adrenal insufficiency is characterized by aldosterone deficiency which leads to increased sodium loss (loss of hyperosmotic fluid). This results in:

  • The osmolarity of extra-cellular fluid (ECF) decreases.
  • ECF volume decreases because of the loss of volume.
  • Water shifts into the intracellular fluid (ICF). As a result, ICF osmolarity decreases until it is equal to ECF osmolarity, and ICF volume increases.
  • So, loss of hypertonic fluid causes hypotonic volume contraction.

The image given below shows Darrow Yannet diagrams of various conditions:

Diagram 1 - The addition of isotonic saline (0.9% normal saline) to ECF does not cause any fluid shift from the ICF. Hence, it only leads to an increase in ECF volume without causing any change in osmolarity.

Diagram 2 - The addition of excess NaCl to ECF pulls the fluid from ICF into the ECF. This results in a decreased volume of ICF, increased volume of ECF, and increased osmolarity in both ECF and ICF.

Diagram 3 - SIADH (syndrome of inappropriate secretion of anti-diuretic hormone) is associated with euvolemic hyponatremia. This leads to a decrease in the osmolarity of the ECF. This causes a fluid shift from the ECF to the ICF until the osmolarity of both compartments becomes equal. The fluid influx also leads to a decrease in the ICF's osmolarity. Therefore, the net effect is an increase in extracellular volume, an increase in intracellular volume, and a fall in osmolarity in both compartments.

Diagram 4 - Adrenal insufficiency is associated with hypo-osmotic volume contraction. Due to a deficiency of aldosterone, there is a decrease in both plasma volume and osmolality.

Related Pearl: Body Fluids Compartments

  • In ECF, a third specialized compartment, called the transcellular compartment (not shown in flow chart), is quantitatively small and includes the cerebrospinal, pleural, peritoneal, pericardial, synovial, intraocular and digestive fluids. Altogether it constitutes about 1-2 L.
  • The ECF volume/intracellular fluid volume ratio is larger in infants and children than it is in adults, but the absolute volume of ECF in children is, of course, smaller than in adults. Therefore, dehydration develops more rapidly and is frequently more severe in children.
  • All solutes and water that enter or leave the body do so via the ECF.
  • The ICF and ECF are in osmotic equilibrium. Water moves between these compartments only when an osmotic pressure gradient exists.
  • Equilibration of ICF and ECF osmolality occurs primarily by shifts in water and not shifts in solutes.

questions.text: Antidepressant approved by FDA for the treatment of female hyposexual desire disorder is ___________
questions.solution:
Flibanserin is a 5-HT1A-agonist/5-HT2-antagonist (antidepressant) that is FDA approved for the treatment of female hyposexual desire disorder.

  • This is the first drug marketed to improve sexual desire in women.
  • The data suggest that compared to placebo, women treated with flibanserin have a somewhat higher number of sexual events.
  • However, the drug interacts with alcohol, causing hypotensive events.
  • Flibanserin is taken 100 mg orally at bedtime to circumvent the side effects of dizziness, sleepiness, and nausea.
  • The drug should be discontinued if there is no improvement in sex drive after 8 weeks.

questions.text: According to JNC, which of the following should not be given in hypertensive non-black population with diabetes?
questions.solution:
According to JNC, beta-blockers are not given in hypertensive non-black population with diabetes.

Eighth Joint National Committee (JNC-8) guideline on managing hypertension in adults.

  • The JNC-8 calls for treatment to lower blood pressure (BP) to 150/90 mm Hg in those age 60 and older, and to 140/90 for adults less than 60.
  • In the population age 18 and older with diabetes, the guidelines recommends initiating drug treatment to a goal of systolic BP<140 mmHg, and a diastolic goals of <90 mmHg. The same applies to patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
  • In the general nonblack population, including those with diabetes, the initial antihypertensive treatment should include either a thiazide, calcium channel blocker (CCB), angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor (ACEI), or angiotensin receptor blocker (ARB).
  • In the general black population, including those with diabetes, initial antihypertensive treatment should include a thiazide-type diuretic or CCB.
  • In adults with CKD, initial (or add-on) antihypertensive treatment should include an ACEI or ARB to improve kidney outcomes. This applies to all CKD patients with hypertension regardless of race or diabetes status.

Note : African Americans have exceptionally high rates of hypertension and hypertension related complications. It is commonly reported that the blood pressure lowering efficacy of renin angiotensin system (RAS) inhibitors like ACEIs and ARBs is attenuated in African Americans due to a greater likelihood of having a low renin profile. Therefore these agents are often not recommended as initial therapy in African Americans with hypertension. However, the high prevalence of comorbid conditions, such as diabetes, cardiovascular and chronic kidney disease makes treatment with RAS inhibitors more compelling.

questions.text: Calculate the compliance of the lung if the tidal volume is 600 ml, intrapleural pressure before inspiration = –5 cm H2O and intrapleural pressure after inspiration = –8 cm H2O.
questions.solution:
Lung compliance will be 200 mL/ cm H2O.

Lung compliance is the change in lung volume (tidal volume) divided by the change in surrounding pressure.

This is stated in the following formula:

Compliance = ΔV/ΔP

Given, Tidal volume = 600 mL

Change in pleural pressure = -5 - (-8) cm H2O =3 cm H2O

Compliance = 600/3 =200 mL/ cm H2O

The preceding calculation simply means that for every 1 cm H2O surrounding pressure changes, 200 mL of air flows in or out of the respiratory system. It flows into the system if surrounding pressure becomes more negative (e.g –5 to –6 cm H2O) or out of the system if surrounding pressure becomes more positive.

questions.text: The Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion incorporates all of the following key action areas except ________
questions.solution:
Build social security system is one of the determinants and new challenge in 21st century for health as per the Jakarta Declaration on Health Promotion.

The Ottawa Charter for Health Promotion’s five key action areas:

  • Build healthy public policy
  • Create supportive environment for health
  • Strengthen community action for health
  • Develop personal skills
  • Reorient health services

questions.text: An eight year old child presented with fullness in left ear. Otoscopy findings are shown in the image given below. Treatment of choice is _________

choices.text: Conservative treatment with antibiotics and analgesics

questions.solution:
The above case is suggestive of serous otitis media for which the treatment of choice is myringotomy with ventilation tube (Grommet).  

The image shows a golden yellow discoloration of the left tympanic membrane which is caused by the clear straw colored effusion filling the middle ear. Because the fluid is clear, one can see the structures of the inner ear quite clearly.

Treatment of choice for serous otitis media is myringotomy with ventilation tube (Grommet).

  • Grommet is a Tymapanostomy or ventilation tube placed in the middle ear to aerate and drain the middle ear into the external ear as a substitute to the blocked Eustachian tube.

Causes of otitis media:

Malfunctioning of eustachian tube:

  • Adenoid hyperplasia in children.
  • Benign and malignant tumours of nasopharynx (should be excluded in unilateral serous otitis media in an adult).

Other causes include:

  • Interference with ET opening like in cleft lip, cleft palate and enlarged tonsils
  • Otitic barotrauma
  • Increased middle ear secretions e.g allergy.
  • Persistent effusion of ASOM due to inadequate treatment dose or duration

Related Pearl: Myringotomy

Indications:
  • Acute suppurative otitis media:
    • Severe earache with the bulging tympanic membrane.
    • Incomplete resolution with opaque drum and persistent conductive deafness.
    • Complications of acute otitis media,e.g.facialparalysis, labyrinthitis or meningitis with the bulging tympanic membrane.
  • Serous otitis media.
  • Aero-otitis media (to drain fluid and “unlock” the eustachian tube).
  • Atelectatic ear (grommet is often inserted for long-term aeration).

Contraindication: Suspected intratympanic glomus tumor.

Incisions: 

  • In acute suppurative otitis media, a circumferential incision is made in the posteroinferior quadrant of the tympanic membrane, midway between the handle of malleus and tympanic annulus, avoiding injury to the incudostapedial joint.
  • In serous otitis media, a small radial incision is given in the anteroinferior quadrant and all the effusion is sucked out.

Complications:

  • Injury to incudostapedial joint or stapes.
  • Injury to jugular bulb with profuse bleeding, if jugular bulb is high and floor of the middle ear dehiscent.
  • Middle ear infection.

questions.text: Positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutinins can be seen in cases of _____
questions.solution:
Positive Weil-Felix test with OX K agglutinins can be seen in cases of scrub typhus.

  • Weil-Felix reaction is an heterophile agglutination reaction wherein the sera are tested for agglutinins to the O antigens of certain non-motile Proteus strains OX 19, OX 2 and OX K.
  • The basis of the test is sharing of an alkali stable carbohydrate antigen by some rickettsiae and some strains of vulgaris OX 19 & OX 2 and Pr. mirabilis OX K.
  • OX K is agglutinated only in Scrub typhus.

questions.text: A 4-week old infant presented to ER with projectile vomiting. Ultrasonography was done which showed Cervix sign and Nipple sign. Probable diagnosis is ______________
questions.solution:
Probable diagnosis is Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric stenosis since cervix sign and nipple sign are signs of Congenital Hypertrophic Pyloric stenosis on USG.

  • Double-layered hypertrophic mucosa protrudes into the stomach, creating the so-called Nipple sign.
  • The sonographic appearance of the hypertrophied pylorus resembles that of the uterine cervix and is sometimes referred to as the cervix sign.

questions.text: In Seligmann's disease, the specific heavy chain of immunoglobulin that is elevated in blood and urine is
questions.solution:
In Seligmann's disease, alpha heavy chain of immunoglobulin is elevated in blood and urine.

The heavy chain diseases are rare lymphoplasmacytic malignancies characterised by production of abnormal, structurally incomplete, immunoglobulin heavy chains without the corresponding light chains.

  • Seligmann's disease is also known as Alpha heavy chain disease, as the alpha heavy chain of immunoglobulin are elevated in blood and urine.This is the most common heavy chain disease.
  • Franklin's disease is also known as Gamma heavy chain disease and is seen in elderly.
  • Mu chain disease is the rarest form of heavy chain disease.

questions.text: I-VITROS in relation to minimal access surgery is?

choices.text: Insufflate, Visualise, Identify, Triangulate, Retract, Operate, Seal
Identify, Visualise, Incise, Triangulate, Repair, Observe, Seal
Insufflate, View, Incise, Triangulate, Retract, Observe, Seal
Identify,  Visualise, Incise, Trinagulate, Repair, Operate, Seal

questions.solution:
I-VITROS refers to the core principles of minimal acces surgery and is summarized as:

  • I - Insufflate
  • V - Visualise
  • I - Identify
  • T - Triangulate
  • R - Retract
  • O - Operate
  • S - Seal

Minimal access surgery is a product of modern technology and surgical innovation that aims to accomplish surgical therapeutic goals with minimum somatic and psychological trauma.

Examples include: Laparoscopy, thoracoscopy, endoluminal endoscopy,  perivisceral endoscopy, arthroscopy and intra articular joint surgery.

Advantages of minimal access surgeries:

  • Decrease in wound size
  • Reduction in wound infection, dehiscence, bleeding
  • herniation and nerve entrapment
  • Decrease in wound pain
  • Improved mobility
  • Decreased wound trauma
  • Decreased heat loss
  • Improved vision

Limitations of minimal access surgery :

  • Reliance on remote vision and operating
  • Loss of tactile feedback
  • Dependence on hand–eye coordination
  • Difficulty with haemostasis
  • Reliance on new techniques
  • Extraction of large specimens

questions.text: Identify the structures A and B in the given image:

choices.text: A: Radial nerve, B: Posterior circumflex humeral artery
A: Radial nerve, B: Profunda Brachii artery
A: Axillary nerve, B: Posterior circumflex humeral artery
A: Axillary nerve, B: Profunda Brachii artery

questions.solution:
The space containg the structures A and B is quadrangular space (foramen of Velpeau).

A: Axillary nerve

B: Posterior circumflex humeral vessels

Clinical Considerations

Anterior–inferior dislocation of the humerus (shoulder dislocation) may damage the axillary nerve or axillary artery.

Quadrilateral space syndrome(QSS): QSS is an uncommon condition that involves the compression of the posterior humeral circumflex artery and the axillary nerve within the quadrilateral space, secondary to acute trauma or from overuse, especially with overhead sports like throwing.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding obesity?

choices.text: Naltrexone and Bupropion combination is FDA approved for obesity
Canagliflozin is contraindicated in obese diabetic patients
Laron syndrome patients have central obesity

questions.solution:
Canagliflozin causes moderate weight loss and is used in diabetic patients who are obese.

It is a Sodium glucose transporter 2 (SGLT2) inhibitor, having an insulin-independent mechanism that offers a considerable advantage of increasing urinary glucose excretion without inducing hypoglycemia and promoting weight loss due to loss of 300 to 400kcal/day.

Drugs used in obesity treatment:

  • Orlistat: Acts in the gastrointestinal system inhibiting intestinal lipase and hence reducing fat absorption.
  • Lorcaserin: Selective serotonin receptor agonist
  • Combination of Phentermine hydrochloride and Topiramate
  • Combination of Naltrexone and Bupropion Hydrochloride
  • Liraglutide: Injectable Glucagon-like peptide-1 receptor agonist

Option C: Laron syndrome is an autosomal recessive disorder that is mainly caused by mutations in the gene that encodes the GH receptor, resulting in GH-resistance. This causes a severe deficiency in serum insulin -like growth factor – 1 (IGF- 1 ) , resulting in short stature (dwarfism). Affected individuals have a prominent forehead, depressed nasal bridge, small mandible, and central obesity.

They may have recurrent hypoglycemic seizures. Partial resistance to GH may cause some cases of idiopathic short stature without features of Laron syndrome.

Option D: Hypothalamic damage causes obesity.Obesity also causes variable degrees of GH deficiency and male hypogonadotropic hypogonadism that are typically reversible with sufficient weight loss.

Surgery for obesity is indicated in patient with BMI more than 40 or BMI more than 35 with associated co-morbidities.

questions.text: Pituitary adenoma with mucocutaneous myxomas and pigmentary nevi are features of  ____________
questions.solution:
Pituitary adenoma with mucocutaneous myxomas and pigmentary nevi are features of Carney complex.

Carney complex (CNC) is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by:

  • Skin lesions are the most common Carney complex manifestation. Spotty skin pigmentation (usually of the face, labia, and conjunctiva)
  • Myxomas (usually of the eyelids and heart, but also the tongue, palate, breast, and skin),
  • Psammomatous melanotic schwannomas (usually of the sympathetic nerve chain and upper gastrointestinal tract)
  • Endocrine tumors that involve the adrenals, Sertoli cells, somatotropes, thyroid, and ovary.
  • Null mutations in PRKAR1A, encoding a regulatory subunit of a cyclic-AMP-dependent protein kinase which results in Carney complex.
  • The most common type of endocrine tumors in Carney complex is the primary pigmented nodular adrenocortical disease (PPNAD) (present in two-thirds of the patients), a form of bilateral adrenal hyperplasia that leads to adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH)-independent Cushing syndrome.
  • NAME syndrome and LAMB syndrome are synonymous with Carney complex. 
    • LAMB - Lentigines, Atrial myxoma, and Blue nevi. 
    • NAME - Nevi, Atrial myxoma, Myxoid neurofibromas, and Ephelides.

Loeys-Dietz syndrome is a connective tissue disorder which is similar to Marfan's syndrome and most commonly presents with aortic aneurysms, bifid uvula(cleft palate) and hypertelorism. It is caused by mutations in the genes that encode TGF-β receptors 1 & 2. 

Related Pearl: MEN 4 Syndrome Features

It is associated with CDKN1B gene on chromosome 12.

Associated conditions:

  • Parathyroid adenoma
  • Pituitary adenoma
  • Reproductive organ tumors like testicular cancer, neuroendocrine cervical carcinoma
  • Adrenal and renal tumors

Related Pearl: MEN 2 Syndrome Features

MEN 2A

  • Known as Sipple’s syndrome
  • Chromosome 10 / RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Parathyroid adenoma (10–25%)

MEN 2B

  • Known commonly as MEN 3
  • Chromosome 10/ RET gene
  • Associated conditions are:
    • Medullary Thyroid Carcinoma (>90%)
    • Pheochromocytoma (>50%)
    • Other associated abnormalities include: (40–50%)
      • Mucosal neuromas
      • Marfanoid habitus
      • Medullated corneal nerve fibers
      • Megacolon

questions.text: Uroporphyrinogen III synthase enzyme is deficient in _____
questions.solution:
Uroporphyrinogen III synthase is deficient in congenital erythropoietic porphyria. Staining of teeth, increased risk of photosensitivity along with accumulation of coproporphyrin I and uroporphyrin I in bone marrow, RBC etc. is seen in Congenital erythropoietic porphyria.

Other features of Congenital erythropoietic porphyria:

  • Presents shortly after birth or in utero as non immune hydrops
  • Erythrodontia (reddish florescence of teeth when illuminated with UV light)
  • Portwine urine or pink stain in diapers
  • Beta carotene is used to protect from sunlight

Related Pearl: Types of porphyria

Clinically porphyrias can be classified into:

  • Hepatic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in the liver.
  • Erythropoietic porphyria: The overproduction of heme pathway intermediates occurs primarily in bone marrow erythroid cells.

  • ALAD enzyme deficiency porphyria

questions.text: In a group of 50 adult males, the mean height is 170 cm. The standard deviation is 2.5 cms. How many will have height between 170 to 172.5 cm, if the distribution is normal?
questions.solution:
17 men will have height between 170 to 172.5 cm.

According to the empirical rule of normal distribution, 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviations of the mean.

In this case,

S.D = 2.5 cm, mean = 170 cm

170 + 2.5 = 172.5 cm, 170 – 2.5 cm = 167.5 cm

Hence 68% men will have height between 167.5 cm and 172.5 cms. And 34% men will have height between 170 cm and 172.5 cms.

34/100 × 50 = 17 men will have height between 170 cms and 172.5 cms. 

Related Pearl: Normal Distribution

The normal distribution curve is the most common shape taken by continuous data distributions. It is also called bell curve (bell-shaped) or Gaussian distribution after mathematician Karl Friedrich Gauss.

The following is an image of three different normal distribution curves.

Salient features of the standard normal distribution:

  • Defined by two parameters: the mean and the standard deviation
  • Has mean of 0 and a standard deviation of 1
  • Mean = median = mode
  • Symmetric and have bell-shaped curves with a single peak
  • Total area under the curve is 1
  • Frequency of values is more around the center and less around the tails
  • No skew in the curve
  • Data like blood pressure, heights, IQ scores, etc. form a normal distribution
  • The empirical rule of a normal distribution:
    • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean (mean ± 1 SD)
    • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 2 SD)
    • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean (mean ± 3 SD)

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores: 
    • The deviation score of an element in distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • Denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • Sum of all the deviation scores of elements in distribution will be zero
  • Variance (also called mean square) 
    • The mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution
    • Used to measure how far data is spread out
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Population variance (σ2) is calculated as:
      • Find the deviation score of each element in the distribution
      • Square each of the deviation scores.
      • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores
  •  
    • Sample variance (s2): 
      • more commonly used in statistics than population variance
      • The denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance)
      • For small samples, it is better to use n-1 in the denominator.
      • For a very large sample, like a population, subtracting 1 from a huge number will not make much of a significant correction. Hence, we may choose to ignore subtracting 1.
  • Standard Deviation (SD)
    • It is the square root of variance.
    • The standard deviation of a population is denoted by σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s.
    • The formula for the standard deviation of a sample (usually <30):
    • For a population (large sample), the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • It is particularly useful for normal distributions but can be used in skewed distributions
    • It is used to calculate the proportion of the population within the given SD
    • A low SD means that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviation of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

questions.text: Ascoli’s thermo precipitin test is used to demonstrate the toxicity of:
questions.solution:
Ascoli's Thermo precipitation test is used for the diagnosis of anthrax (Bacillus anthracis) using a tissue extract and anthrax antiserum.

It is a precipitin test in which the antibody produces visible precipitate when it reacts with the antigen. It is used for detection of anthrax bacilli in animal hides and meat.

But this test lacks specificity because the thermostable antigen of bacillus anthrax is shares by other species of bacillus too.

Related Pearl: Serological tests in microbiology

Precipitation test:

  • Ascoli's thermoprecipitin test: Anthrax
  • Streptococci grouping: Lancefield technique
  • VDRL test for syphilis (slide flocculation test)
  • Kahn test for syphilis (tube flocculation test)
  • Elek gel precipitation test for C.diphtheria

Agglutination test:

  • Widal test- typhoid
  • Weil- Felix reaction- Typhus fever
  • Streptococcus MG agglutination test- Mycoplasma pneumoniae
  • Paul Bunnel test- Infectious mononucleiosis
  • Coombs test
  • Rose Waaler test- Rheumatoid arthritis
  • Microscopic Agglutination test- Leptospirosis
  • Anti streptolysin O test

Complement fixation test:

  • Wasserman reaction(syphilis)
  • Treponema pallidum immobilization test

Neutralization test:

  • Schik test for diptheria
  • Anti streptolysin O test
  • Nagler's reaction (clostridium perfringens)

questions.text: Immunohistochemical testing was performed on a biopsy sample taken from a patient with breast cancer. Which of the following subtypes indicates the best prognosis?
questions.solution:
The luminal A molecular subtype of breast cancer is associated with the best prognosis. 

The cells in breast cancer may overexpress estrogen receptors (ER), progesterone receptors (PR), human epidermal growth factor receptor 2/neu (HER2/neu), and androgen receptors (AR). Ki-67 mitotic index indicates the degree of mitosis or proliferation. 

Based on these factors, breast cancer is classified into 5 subtypes. These include: 

  • luminal A
  • luminal B
  • HER2/neu enriched
  • basal
  • normal-like group

The luminal A subtype is the most common. They are defined as hormone receptor-positive (ER-positive and/or PR-positive), HER2/neu negative, and low Ki67 by immunohistochemistry. These tumors have a low histological grade, low degree of nuclear pleomorphism, and low mitotic activity. They are associated with a good prognosis and a significantly lower relapse rate. 

Related Pearl: Molecular classification of breast cancer

*Update: Claudin low-molecular subtype is a triple-negative breast cancer with low expression of E-cadherin, with a poor prognosis. It is frequently associated with lymphocyte infiltration.

Almost all breast malignancies are adenocarcinomas and based on the expression of estrogen receptor and HER2 can be divided into three major biologic subgroups:

  • ER-positive HER2-negative tumors (50% to 65% of tumors) – range from well-differentiated cancers with low proliferative rates and few chromosomal changes to poorly differentiated cancers with high proliferative rates and large numbers of chromosomal rearrangements. All of these cancers express ER.
  • HER2-positive cancers - 10% to 20% of tumors, which may either be ER-positive or ER-negative.
  • ER-negative, HER2-negative carcinomas (triple-negative or basal-like)- are characterized by genomic instability, a high proliferative rate, and expression of many proteins typical of myoepithelial cells (e.g., basal keratins).

questions.text: The most common ovarian tumor detected during pregnancy is ___________
questions.solution:
The most common ovarian tumor detected during pregnancy is teratoma (mostly benign). Whereas the most common ovarian malignancy detected during pregnancy is dysgerminoma.

questions.text: An example of a complete sulcus among the following is _________.
questions.solution:
Collateral Sulcus is a complete sulcus. A complete sulcus is one that is deep enough to indent the wall of a ventricle.

If you get a choice between calcarine sulcus and collateral sulcus, allways go for collateral sulcus as the answer, because posterior part of calcarine sulcus is an axial sulcus.

 

Related Pearl: Classification of sulci of brain

Types of sulci:

On the basis of function, they're divided as:

  • Limiting sulcus - A sulcus that separates areas differing in structure and function at its floor. E.g. Central sulcus - separates motor and sensory area.
  • Axial sulcus - Sulcus that develops along the axis of a rapidly growing/ developing area. E.g. Posterior part of calcarine sulcus - primary visual area grows along this sulcus.
  • Operculated sulcus - A sulcus that separates two areas by its lip and contains a third area in its walls. E.g. Lunate sulcus - separates striate and peristriate areas.

On the basis of depth, they're divided as:

  • Complete sulcus - Deep enough to indent the wall of the lateral ventricle. E.g Anterior part of calcarine sulcus -  forms calcar avis at the lateral ventricle, Collateral sulcus -  forms collateral eminence at the inferior horn of the lateral ventricle
  • Incomplete sulcus - Superficially situated and does not indent the lateral ventricle. E.g. paracentral sulcus

questions.text: In precipitation reactions, excess of antibodies causes _____
questions.solution:
In precipitation reactions, excess of antibodies causes pro-zone phenomenon.

Marrack's Lattice Hypothesis was proposed to explain the mechanism of precipitation. 

According to that when multivalent antigens combine with bivalent antibodies in varying proportions,precipitation occurs in the zone of equivalence.

  • Pro–zone phenomenon: It is caused by excessive antibody in the test system.
  • Zone of equivalence: Antigen and antibody are in optimum proportion.
  • Post–zone phenomenon: Presence of excessive antigen in the test system

questions.text: Letulles technique is an autopsy technique characterised by ________

choices.text: Removal of organs one by one

questions.solution:
Letulle's technique is characterized by en masse removal of organs. It means thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed as one big organ block.

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: Which of the following structure is related to anterior wall of middle ear ?
questions.solution:
Canal of tensor tympani is related to anterior wall of middle ear.

The middle ear has a roof, floor and four walls: anterior, posterior, medial & lateral.

  • Roof: Formed by tegmen typani bone
  • Floor: Formed by a thin plate of bone
  • Anterior wall: Structures related are
    • Eustachian tube
    • Canal of tensor tympani
    • Internal carotid artery
  • Posterior wall: It has a bony projection called pyramid. The aditus connecting middle ear to attic is present above the pyramid.
  • Medial wall:  It is formed by labyrinth and it presents abulge called promontary. Medial wall is related to
    • Oval window
    • round window
    • Processus cochleoriformis
    • Horizontal semicircular canal
    • Canal of facial nerve
  • Lateral wall: It is mainly formed by tympanic membrane and also by bony outer attic wall called scutum.

questions.text: During a radiographical imaging procedure a person is positioned as shown in the image given below. Which key structure(s) that would be visualized best with this view?

choices.text: Antrum and upper part of attic

questions.solution:
The view in the given image is Schuller’s view. The key area seen in this view is antrum and upper part of attic.

Schuller's view is a lateral radiographic view of skull. The central beam of X-rays passes from one side of the head at angle of 30° to radiographic plate in the cranio-caudal direction.

Other areas seen in this view include:

  • External canal superimposed on internal canal
  • Mastoid air cells
  • Tegmen
  • Lateral sinus plate
  • Condyle of mandible
  • Sinodural angle

This angulation prevents overlap of images of two mastoid bones. Radiograph for each mastoid is taken separately.

The Schullers view serves as an alternative view to the Law projection which uses a 15 degree angle of patient's face toward the image receptor and a 15 degree caudal angulation to achieve the same result, a lateral mastoid air cells view without overlap of the opposite side. 

Law's view

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of paranasal sinuses and mastoid

Related Pearl: Radiographic views of temporal bone

questions.text: According to the modified International system of charting of teeth, the tooth numbered 43 represents?
questions.solution:
The tooth numbered 43 represents left lower canine according to the Modified International System of Charting of teeth.

Modified Federation Dentaire Internationale: This is a two digit system.

  • First digit represents the quadrant: 1 for right upper, 2 for left upper, 3 for right lower and 4 for left lower.
  • Second digit represents the teeth of each quadrant, numbered 1 to 8, starting from central incisor and moving away from the midline.

So, the No. 43 represent left lower canine.

According to the original Federation Dentaire Internationale system, teeth quadrants are numbered as follows:

questions.text: Fatty hernia of linea alba most commonly presents as?
questions.solution:
Fatty hernia of linea alba (epigastric hernia) most commonly presents as epigastric pain. It is very painful even when it is the size of a pea, mainly due to the fatty contents nipping off to produce partial strangulation.

It presents in midline anywhere between xiphoid and umblicus, may be congenital, due to defective in mid line fusion of lateral abdominal elements, usually common in men in middle age.

Treatment : Simple closure of fascial defect of linea alba.

questions.text: The emergency contraceptive of choice is _____________
questions.solution:
Emergency contraceptive of choice is levenorgestrel (progestogen-only pill).

With progestin-only regimens, levonorgestrel is taken as a single, one-time 1.5-mg dose. This is now recommended instead of two 0.75-mg doses separated by 12 or 24 hours. Dosing begins ideally within 72 hours of unprotected coitus but may be given up to 120 hours. This is found to be more effective with fewer side-effects compared to Yuzpe method (Ethinyl estradiol and Levonorgestrel).

Yuzpe method (Ethinyl estradiol and Levonorgestrel): Ethinyl estradiol and norgestrel pill each containing 50µg ethinyl estradiol and 0.5 mg of norgestrel, 2 tablets being given twice, 12 hours apart, within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse. This is commonly known as Yuzpe Method. It is not preferred because of the reports of higher efficacy and fewer side effects with levonorgestrel.

RU 486 (Mifepristone): They are anti-implantation agents when given post-coitally. They act as menses inducers if given in luteal phase and can act as abortifacients when given in early pregnancy. Current accepted dose for emergency contraception is 10mg. In a comparative trial of RU486 with Yuzpe regimen, side-effects were less common with mifepristone but menstrual disturbances occurred more often.

Intra uterine contraceptive devices: Insertion of copper-T and copper-7 within 7 days of unprotected intercourse is a highly successful method for post-coital contraception. Copper-T is effective following even multiple coital exposures during a short interval especially when the delay is beyond 120 hours, but less than 1 week, making hormonal methods ineffective. IUD is particularly suitable for women who would like to continue using it as a regular contraceptive.

questions.text: Barking cough is most commonly seen in infection with ?
questions.solution:
Barking cough is a feature of laryngeotracheobronchitis, which is caused by parainfluenza virus.

Laryngotracheobronchitis:

  • Median age: 6 months to 6 years
  • Clinical features include: barking cough, inspiratory stridor, hoarseness, low grade fever
  • X-ray findings: “Steeple sign” due to subglottic narrowing
  • Management:
    • Racemic epinephrine nebulization. It leads to rapid improvement of upper airway obstruction. Epinephrine constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption and improvement in airway edema.
    • Dexamethasone-by the least invasive route (Oral>IV>IM ). It is indicated in all the grades of croup.
    • Oxygen should be administered to children who are hypoxemic (SpO2 <92 %).
    • Antibiotics are not indicated in croup.

Related Pearl: Acute Stridor/ Noisy breathing

Stridor indicates an upper airway problem. Look for a history of foreign body aspiration and signs of toxicity.

Important differentials:

Condition  Findings
Croup

Non-toxic, viral prodrome, barking cough

X-ray neck shows steeple sign
Epiglottitis

Toxic child, drooling saliva

Lateral X-ray neck shows thumb sign
Diphtheria Unimmunized child, cervical lymph nodes (bull neck), dirty grey/ white membrane
Foreign body aspiration Choking, decreased air entry, unilateral hyperinflation

questions.text: Integrins are associated with all except _________
questions.solution:
Selectins are associated with rolling while Integrin is associated with adhesion, arrest, and transmigration.

Endothelial molecules Leukocytes Function
E-Selectin Sialyl-lewis X modified proteins Rolling and adhesion
P-Selectin Sialyl-lewis X modified proteins Rolling only
GlyCam-1(CD 34) L-Selectin Rolling
ICAM-1 B integrin (CD11/18) Adhesion, arrest, transmigration
VCAM-1 B Integrin Adhesion
CD 31(PECAM-1) CD 31 Leukocyte migration through endothelium

questions.text: A 22-year-old male presents with ascending muscle weakness for 2 days. On examination, the limb is flaccid.  Similar episodes were reported in the past, usually after prolonged exercise. What investigation should be done first?
questions.solution:
Flaccid ascending paralysis can be seen in case of hypokalemia. It causes periodic paralysis. Hence, serum potassium levels should be checked first.

Hypokalemic Periodic Paralysis:

  • This is an autosomal dominant disorder with onset in adolescence.
  • Males are more often affected because of decreased penetrance in females.
  • Two types:
    • Type 1 with mutation in voltage sensitive, skeletal muscle calcium channel gene CALCL1A3.
    • Type 2 with mutation in voltage sensitive sodium channel gene SCN4A.
  • Attacks are often provoked by meals high in carbohydrates or sodium and may accompany rest following prolonged exercise.
  • Weakness usually affects proximal limb muscles more than distal.
  • Ocular and bulbar muscles are less likely to be affected.
  • Respiratory muscles are usually spared, but when they are involved, the condition may prove fatal.
  • Weakness may take as long as 24 hours to resolve.
  • Life-threatening cardiac arrhythmias related to hypokalemia may occur during attacks.
  • As a late complication, patients commonly develop severe, disabling proximal lower extremity weakness.

Diagnosis:

  • A low serum potassium level during an attack, excluding secondary causes, establishes the diagnosis.
  • In the midst of an attack of weakness, motor conduction studies may demonstrate reduced amplitudes, whereas EMG may show electrical silence in severely weak muscles.
  • In between attacks, the EMG and routine NCS are normal. However, a long exercise NCS test may demonstrate decrementing amplitudes.

Treatment:

Mild attacks usually do not require medical treatment. However, severe attacks of weakness can be improved by the administration of potassium. Oral KCl (0.2–0.4 mmol/kg) can be given every 30 min. Only rarely is IV therapy necessary (e.g., when swallowing problems or vomiting is present).

The long-term goal of therapy is to avoid attacks. Patients should be made aware of the importance of a low-carbohydrate, low-sodium diet, and consequences of intense exercise.

Prophylactic administration of acetazolamide or dichlorphenamide can reduce attacks of periodic weakness. However, in patients with HypoKPP type 2, attacks of weakness can be exacerbated with these medications.

questions.text: A sexually active man diagnosed with syphilis presented with a recurrence of the primary lesion at its original site. On examination, there is painless lymphadenopathy and Treponema is isolated from the site of the lesion.  Which stage of syphilis is he currently in?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario showing recurrence of syphilis at the primary site and presenting with a painless lymphadenopathy isolating Treponema from the site is suggestive of early relapsing syphilis. This is also known as "chancre redux."

Chancre redux is a highly infectious recurrence of the primary sore at its original site. This may be associated with painless lymphadenopathy.

Syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, is usually acquired through sexual contact. However, congenital syphilis is acquired as a transplacental infection. Serological testing is done using standard non-treponemal antibody tests like VDRL and RPR. Specific treponemal antibody tests, like TPHA and FTA-ABS, are further required. Microscopically, Trepenoma pallidum is identified with a characteristic wave-like appearance on darkfield microscopy.
 
Parenteral penicillin G is the drug of choice for all stages of syphilis. If the patient has a history of drug allergies, it is advisable to keep the patient under observation for 15 to 20 minutes after injection. Treating recent sexual contacts is recommended. 

Note: Pseudochancre redux is a gummatous lesion seen in tertiary syphilis that is not infectious. It occurs at the site of a previously healed chancre, and the adjacent lymph nodes are not enlarged.

Related Pearl: Stages of syphilis

Primary syphilis:

  • Chancre - Painless, indurated, usually single. The chancre self heals in 1-4 months.
  • Lymphadenopathy - Painless, unilateral or bilateral, shotty and rubbery inguinal nodes
  • Dory flop sign - As the chancre is too hard to fold, it will flip over once the prepuce is retracted back.

Secondary syphilis:

  • A & B: Generalized non-itchy rash with no vesicles present on the palm and sole. This is the most common lesion.
  • C & D: Condyloma lata.
  • E: Moth-eaten non-scarring alopecia
  • F: Mucous patches are flat erosions on the tongue that can coalesce to form snail track ulcers. These are the most infectious lesions.
  • G: Pigmentary plaques
  • H: Psoriasiform syphilitic lesions
  • Generalized diffuse non-tender lymphadenopathy

Tertiary syphilis:

  • Gummatous syphilis are deep punched-out ulcers, with gum-like secretions on the floor
  • Pseudo-chancre redux is a gumma occurring at the site of a previously healed ulcer  
  • CVS - Aortitis and aneurysm of the ascending aorta
  • CNS - General paresis of the insane and tabes dorsalis 

Latent syphilis is the period between secondary and tertiary syphilis. In this period the patient is asymptomatic clinically and only serological evidence of the infection is present. It is classified into:

  • Early latent syphilis - Within 1 year of infection
  • Late latent syphilis - After 1 year of infection

questions.text: Which of the following is false about the image given below?

choices.text: Preferred donor site is thigh in cosmetically sensitive individuals and children
Heals well over muscle, perichondrium or periostium
Preparation of wound bed is essential part of graft success
Presence of group A beta hemolytic streptococci is an absolute contraindication

questions.solution:
The image given depicts harvesting of a split skin graft. Most preferable donor site is buttock in cosmetically sensitive individuals and children. Most commonly used donor site is thigh.

  • Graft is taken from the donor site with a hand held Humby knife.
  • Grafts are perforated to allow exudates to escape and improve ‘take’. It can further be meshed to allow expansion.
  • Grafts will take up only on the beds which are vascularized , hence preparation of wound bed is essential step.
  • Skin grafts are completely dependent for nutrition on the tissue over which they are placed and can heal well over muscle, perichondrium, and periosteum. They do not take well over bone or cartilage or on tissue that has been irradiated or infected or is hypovascular.
  • A clean healthy wound bed with a meshed graft tied in place to stop movemement will encourage take.
  • Presence of group A beta hemolytic streptococci is contraindicated in grafting as it can destroy split grafts completely and also convert donor to full thickness defect.

Skin grafts can be broadly divided into two categories:

Split thickness skin graft (Thiersch graft ): Partial-thickness skin grafts consisting of the epidermis and a portion of the dermis are called split-thickness skin grafts. Less dermis in the split-thickness skin graft translates into less primary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks in surface area after harvesting and before grafting) and more secondary contraction (the degree to which a graft shrinks during healing).

Full-thickness skin grafts (Wolfe graft) include the epidermis and entire dermis, with portions of the sweat glands, sebaceous glands, and hair follicles. More dermis in the full-thickness skin graft translates into more primary contraction and less secondary contraction.

Advantages of split skin graft over full-thickness skin graft:

  • Large grafts can be harvested.
  • In the case of thinner split-thickness grafts, the donor site heals more rapidly and can be reused in severe cases such as burns.
  • Uptake is good. Meshing can be done i.e. small splits are made in graft and any exudates collected can come out through this and this improves graft take up. 
  • Meshing also allows the graft to expand.

Advantages of full-thickness skin graft over split skin graft:

  • It has a lesser degree of post-graft contraction
  • Best cosmetic appearance as they include the highest number of skin appendage elements.

Related Pearl: Skin Grafting : Phases of Graft Uptake

Skin graft uptake occurs in three phases:

  1. Imbibition (Plasmatic circulation): During the first 48 hours, the graft is nourished with plasma exudate from the host bed capillaries.
  2. Inosculation: Cut vessels from the host bed line up with the cut ends of the vessels of the graft to form anastomoses.
  3. Neovascularization: Blood vessels grow from the recipient bed into the graft.

Sensations return to the graft over time, with reinnervation beginning at approximately 4 to 5 weeks and being completed by 12 to 24 months. Pain returns first, followed by light touch and temperature returning later.

Note: Some books give that the 3 phases are imbibition, revascularisation (inosculation+neovascularisation) and organisation (fibrin layer holds the graft in place and this is replaced with fibroblasts by day 7).

questions.text:
The ABG findings of a patient are given below. Which of the following metabolic abnormality is present in this patient?

PaCO2: 35 mmHg

HCO3-: 30 mEq/L

pH: 7.50

choices.text: Metabolic alkalosis with compensatory respiratory alkalosis

questions.solution:
The given scenario reveals metabolic alkalosis and respiratory alkalosis.

Interpretation of ABG:

Step 1:

Value in the question Normal value Interpretation
pH = 7.50 (7.35 – 7.45) 7.4 Increased
paCO2 = 35  (35 – 45) 40 Normal
HCO3- = 30  (22 – 28) 25 Increased

The values clearly suggest metabolic alkalosis.

Step 2:

Calculating the respiratory compensation:

In metabolic alkalosis, Compensation formula is as follows:

∆ [HCO3-] = Increase in HCO3-, in above case is  = 30 - 25 = 5

So, compensatory increase of CO2 should be = 0.7 x 5 = 3.5

Applying the above, the compensation value of CO2 should lie between

40 + 3.5 = 43.5 or approx. 44

Taking +/- 3 into consideration,  Compensatory values of CO2 = 41 – 47

Step 3:

Since CO2 = 35 which is below the compensatory values, hence this is not compensated.

It suggests that there is a simultaneous respiratory alkalosis.

Step 4:

Looking for anion gap:

Anion gap should be looked for only in cases of:

  • Metabolic acidosis
  • Normal pH

Since the primary disorder is metabolic alkalosis, anion gap is not looked into.

A situation like this is seen with liver disease and diuretics administration.

questions.text: A teenager presents with fever, malaise, skin rash and hepatomegaly. He is diagnosed with a rickettsial infection and the vector implicated in the disease is shown below. The vector can transmit all of the following diseases except:
questions.solution:
The vector shown in the image is a louse. It can transmit all diseases except endemic typhus. The vector for endemic typhus is rat flea. 

The table below shows diseases transmitted by the louse, and the causative agent:

Disease transmitted by louse   Causative agent
Epidemic typhus Rickettssia prowazeki
Relapsing fever Borrelia recurrentis
Trench fever Bartonella quintana
Pediculosis Infestation with the louse

Rickettsial infections are classified based on clinical features and epidemiology as follows:

Group

Zoonotic disease

 Vector
Typhus group  

Epidemic typhus

 Louse

Murine typhus

Flea

Scrub typhus

 Mite
Spotted fever group  

Indian tick typhus

Tick

Rocky Mountain spotted fever

 Tick

Rickettsialpox

 Mite
Others 

Q fever 

 -
Trench fever Louse

Rickettsial infections present with fever, malaise, headache, prostration, hepatosplenomegaly and a skin rash. Q fever does not have skin lesions. Tetracycline is the drug of choice for all rickettsial infections. 

Related Pearl: Lice

  • There are 3 kinds of lice. They are:
    • Head lice (Pediculus capitis)
    • Body lice (Pediculus corporis)
    • Crab louse (pubic louse – Phthirus pubis).
  • Their morphology consists of a head with a pair of antennae, three pairs of legs attached to the thorax, and a segmented abdomen.
  • The stages in their life cycle are eggs (nits), larva (nymph), and the adult, which live for 30 to 50 days.
  • They are spread by direct or indirect contact.
  • They are vectors for epidemic typhus, relapsing fever, trench fever, and pediculosis.
  • Insecticidal control of lice is mainly by malathion in the form of lotion or powder.
  • There are reports of resistance to DDT and HCH.
  • Personal hygiene is of utmost importance to prevent infestation.

Related Pearl: Rat Fleas

  • Rat fleas (Xenopsylla cheopis) belong to the genus Xenopsylla.
  • Their morphology includes a conical head, absent neck, a thorax with 3 segments, and an abdomen with 10 segments. They have three pairs of legs and no wings.
  • The four stages in their life cycle are egg, larva, pupa, and adult.
  • They cannot fly but can leap up to 6 inches horizontally.
  • They transmit diseases by biting, mechanical transmission, and feces.
  • Flea indices that are used in flea surveys are the general flea index, specific flea index, percentage incidence of flea species, and rodent infestation rate.
  • Rat fleas are vectors for endemic typhus (murine typhus), chiggerosis, bubonic plague, and Hymenolepis diminuta.
  • Insecticidal control is mainly by 10% DDT.
  • Resistance to DDT, gamma-HCH, and dieldrin has been recorded.
  • Repellants like diethyltoluamide and benzyl benzoate are efficient.
  • Rodent control also aims to reduce flea infestation.

questions.text: A patient presents with discrete thyroid swelling and FNAC reports is Thy 3. What would you infer from the report?
questions.solution:
Thy 3 in FNAC corresponds to follicular cytopathology.

Classification of fine- needle aspiration cytology reports according to Royal College of Pathologists, UK: 

Type Meaning
Thy 1 Non diagnostic
Thy 1c Non diagnostic cystic
Thy 2 Non neoplastic
Thy 3 Follicular
Thy 4 Suspicious of malignancy
Thy 5 Malignancy

This classifcation of thyroid FNAC reports has been described according to the 27th edition of Bailey and Love.

To address the issue of reporting confusion due to mulitplicity of terminologies and categories, the Thyroid Fine needle Aspiration State of the Science consensus Confererence recommended a six tiered system called as The Bethesda System for Reporitng Thyroid Cytopatology (TBRSRTC). The system unifies the termionlogy and morphologic criteria of FNAC reporting along with the corresponding risk of malignancy that links to a rational clinical management guideline. 

Bethesda Criteria for Reporting Thyroid Cytopathology:

questions.text: Under Southampton grading scale for assessing severity of wound infection, erythema with other signs of inflammation has a grade of?
questions.solution:
Southampton wound grading system is a scoring system for the severity of wound infection. Erythema with other signs of inflammation has a grade of II .

Southampton grading system:

GRADE 0 : Normal healing

GRADE 1 : Normal healing with mild bruising and erythema

  • A- Some bruising
  • B- Considerable bruising
  • C- Mild erythema

GRADE 2 : Erythema plus signs of inflammtion

  • A- at one point
  • B- around suture
  • C- along the wound
  • D- around the wound

GRADE 3: Clear or hemoserous discharge

  • A- at one point only (< 2cm)
  • B- along wound (>2cm)
  • C- large volume
  • D- prolonged >3days

GRADE 4: Major complication (pus)

  • A- at one point only (< 2cm)
  • B- along wound (>2cm)

GRADE 5: Deep or severe infection with or without tisssue breakdown ; hematoma requiring aspiration.

questions.text: Which among the following does the graph given below depict?
questions.solution:
The graph given above depicts the Haldane effect.

The binding of O2 with hemoglobin tends to displace CO2 from the blood. This is known as the Haldane effect. It helps in the transport of CO2 from the tissues to the lungs. The graph shows small portions of two CO2 dissociation curves:

  • When the PO2 is 100 mm Hg, which is the case in the blood capillaries of the lungs.
  • When the PO2 is 40 mm Hg, which is the case in the tissue capillaries.

At the normal PCO2 of 45 mm Hg in the tissues represented by point A, 52 volume percent of CO2 combines with the blood. Upon entering the lungs, the PCO2 falls to 40 mm Hg and the PO2 rises to 100 mm Hg. The increase in PO2 shifts the CO2 dissociation curve from the top curve to the lower curve, so the CO2 content falls to point B.

Thus, the Haldane effect approximately doubles the amount of CO2 released from the blood in the lungs and the amount picked up by the tissues.

(Remember - HaLdane effect occurs in Lungs and causes Left shift of O2-Hb dissociation curve)

Other options:

Option A: Bohr effect: A right shift of the oxygen-hemoglobin dissociation curve in response to an increase in blood CO2 and hydrogen ions, enhances the release of O2 from the blood in the tissues. This enhances the oxygenation of the blood in the lungs.

Option B: Henry's Law in Respiration: The amount of oxygen that dissolves into the bloodstream is directly proportional to the partial pressure of oxygen in alveolar air.

Option D: Boyle's Law: The pressure of a fixed mass of gas is inversely proportional to its volume if its temperature is kept constant.

questions.text: False about Magnetic Resonance Cholangio-Pancreatography (MRCP) is:

choices.text: Contrast material must be injected in to ductal system
It evaluates both intrahepatic and extrahepatic bile ducts

questions.solution:
MRCP uses the fluid which is present in the biliary and pancreatic ducts as a contrast agent and does not require external contrast material administered into the ductal system.

It is a non invasive investigation for evaluating extrahepatic, intrahepatic bile duct and pancreatic duct. No interventions are performed under MRCP.

MRCP uses T2 weighed  MRI and it recognizes slow flowing or stationary fluid within ducts, which appear brighter relative to adjacent solid tissues.

MRCP can be used to evaluate various conditions of pancreatobiliary ductal system, examples:

  • Congenital anomalies of the cystic and hepatic ducts
  • Post-surgical biliary anatomy
  • Pancreas divisum
  • Anomalous pancreaticobiliary junction
  • Choledocholithiasis
  • Biliary structures
  • Chronic pancreatitis
  • Pancreatic cystic lesions
  • Trauma to biliary system

Related Pearl: Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

Diagnostic Evaluation of the Bile Ducts

  • Hepatobiliary ultrasound: Initial procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary tract obstruction
  • CT scan: Procedure of choice in investigating possible biliary obstruction if diagnostic limitations prevent HBUS
  • MRCP: Useful modality for visualizing pancreatic and biliary ducts
  • ERCP: Best visualisation of distal biliary tract
    • Endoscopic sphincterotomy and stone removal can also be done
  • PTC(Percutaneous Transhepatic Cholangiography): Best visualisation of proximal biliary tract
    • Indicated when ERCP is contraindicated or failed
  • EUS: Most sensitive method to detect ampullary stones

questions.text: A lady with placenta previa delivered a baby. She had excessive bleeding and shock. After resuscitation, most likely complication would be______________
questions.solution:
The most likely complication in the above case would be the loss of menstruation.

Massive obstetrical hemorrhage whether antepartum, intrapartum or postpartum can be followed by pituitary failure or Sheehan syndrome. Patients experience a failure to lactate, loss of pubic and axillary hair and failure to resume menses after delivery.

Patients have hypotension, tachycardia, and hypoglycemia.

Management: Adrenal function should be assessed and glucocorticoid replacement should be done. Replacement of thyroid, gonadal and growth hormones can be considered after assessment.

questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding secondary lactose intolerance?
questions.solution:
Breast milk should not be stopped in secondary lactose intolerance.

Secondary lactose intolerance follows small bowel mucosal damage (celiac disease, rotavirus infection) and is usually transient, improving with mucosal healing.

Lactase deficiency can be diagnosed by H2-breath test or by measurement of lactase activity in mucosal tissue retrieved by small bowel biopsy. Diagnostic testing is not mandatory, and often simple dietary changes that reduce or eliminate lactose from the diet relieve symptoms, so breast milk is not stopped in secondary lactose intolerence.

questions.text: Management of facial nerve injury during mastoidectomy is?
questions.solution:
During mastoidectomy if facial nerve is injured, it is immediately explored.

Injury to greater than 50% of neural diameter is repaired with primary re-anastomosis or reconstructed with use of nerve graft.

questions.text: Which of the following trace elements is not routinely included in total parenteral nutrition (TPN) solutions?
questions.solution:
Iron is not routinely included in the parenteral nutrition mixtures because - 

  • TPN solution mixtures usually contain lipids &  Iron cations are highly reactive and destabilize these lipid-emulsions leading to precipitation of contents.
  • There are no well-defined recommendations regarding the optimum content of iron in parenteral feeds & a major concern is that of iron overload. Parenteral administration of iron bypasses the homeostatic control of gastrointestinal iron absorption, causing loss of protection from iron overload if excessive quantities are provided.

Iron deficiency should be considered in every patient receiving parenteral nutrition and if necessary can be administered as iron dextran in a solution containing dextrose.

questions.text: The color of postmortem staining in a case of Clostridium perfringens septicemia is
questions.solution:
Bronze colored postmortem staining is seen in Clostridium perfringens septicemia.

Related Pearl: Color of Postmortem Hypostasis in Various Conditions

Poisoning/Condition Postmortem staining

Carbon monoxide   

Cherry red
Cyanides     

Brick red/dark pink

questions.text: The incidence of bladder carcinoma in a population was found to be 5 times higher in smokers than in non-smokers. What is the attributable risk?
questions.solution:
The attributable risk, in this case, will be 80%.

Let the incidence of bladder carcinoma in non-smokers (non-exposed) be x. Therefore, the incidence in smokers (exposed) will be 5x.

According to the formula, attributable risk (AR) is given as follows:

AR (%) = [(IP exposed - IP non-exposed)/ IP exposed] x100, where IP = Incidence proportion

= [(5x - x)/5x] x 100

= 4x/5x x 100

= 80%

Thus, the attributable risk is 80%.

Related Pearl: Relative and Attributable Risk

Relative Risk:

  • Ratio of incidence of disease or death among exposed to that among the non-exposed is called relative risk (RR).
  • It is also called risk ratio.
  • It is the direct measure of the strength of association between suspected cause and effect in cohort studies.
  • RR < 1 indicates inverse association(protective effect)
  • RR = 1 indicates no association.
  • RR > 1 indicates positive association.
  • RR of 2 indicates a 100% increase in risk.
  • Relative risk calculation (RR) = [ a/(a+b) ]/ [ c/(c+d) ] where, 
  Cancer
Exposure   yes no
yes a b
no c d

 

Attributable Risk:

  • Attributable risk (AR) is the difference in incidence rates or proportions of disease or death between an exposed and non-exposed group.
  • It is expressed in percentage and gives the extent to which the disease can be attributed to the exposure in a cohort study.

questions.text: Which of the following is true about lipoprotein metabolism and its disorders?

choices.text: HDL has maximum cholesterol and cholesterol ester
Molecular defect in familial hypercholestrolemia is lipoprotein lipase
Abetalipoproteinemia is due to mutation in Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP) gene

questions.solution:
Abetalipoproteinemia is due to loss of function mutation in gene encoding Microsomal triglyceride transfer protein (MTP).

MTP transfers lipids to nascent chylomicrons and VLDL's in the intestine and liver, respectively. Therefore, when MTP gene is mutated, chylomicrons, VLDL and LDL are not produced.

Other options:

LDL has maximum cholesterol and cholesterol ester.

HDL has maximum electrophoretic mobility, least diameter and maximum protein content.

Molecular defect in familial hypercholesterolemia is in LDL receptors. Whereas molecular defect in familial chylomicronemia syndrome is in lipoprotein lipase or Apo CII.

questions.text: Identify trabeculae in the following image below showing histological section of lymph node:
questions.solution:
Structure marked as 5 is trabeculae in the given histological image of lymph node.

The structures marked in the above histological section of the lymph node are as follows:

  • Capsule
  • Subcapsular sinus
  • Germinal centre
  • Lymphoid nodule
  • Trabeculae

Histology of lymph node:

Each lymph node consists of a connective tissue framework and of numerous lymphocytes of all types which are arranged in a stroma of reticulin fibers and cells to form 3 major regions within each Lymph node:

  • Outer zone known as Cortex which contains Subcapsular sinuses, Lymphoid nodules and densely packed lymphocytes, and therefore stains darkly. Each nodule has a paler staining germinal centre surrounded by a zone of densely packed lymphocytes. 
  • A deeper extension of cortex called the paracortex , which lacks nodules. and has fewer lymphocytes, therefore, lighter staining
  • And a medulla (lighter staining zone in which lymphocytes are fewer) with prominent draining sinusoids adjacent to the hilum.

questions.text: Which among the following is the treatment of choice for confirmed microinvasion of cervix neoplasia?

choices.text: Large loop excision of transformation zone (LLTEZ)

questions.solution:
Hysterectomy is done when microivasion is confirmed. Whereas conization is the treatment of choice when microinvasion is suspected.

  • Indications of hysterectomy
    • Older & parous women
    • Uterus is suspected with fibroid, DUB or prolapse
    • Microinvasion exists
    • Recurrence or persistent lesion
    • In situ adenocarcinoma cervix
  • Indications of conization
    • Endocervical dysplasia
    • Transformation zone is not completely visualized
    • When there is discrepancy of findings between cytoloigy, colposcopy & biopsy
    • Microinvasion is suspected

Option a and b: LLETZ (Large loop excision of transformation zone) is the most commonly used treatment option for cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN). This procedure is also known as Loop electro surgical excision procedure (LEEP).

 

Related Pearl: Management of CIN

questions.text: In a road traffic accident victim with a GCS scale of 8/15, rapid-sequence intubation is planned. Which of the following is not done in this procedure?
questions.solution:
Manual ventilation before intubation is not done in rapid-sequence induction (RSI).

RSI is done during emergency surgery, with the objective of securing the airway rapidly and preventing aspiration.

Steps of RSI are shown in the image below:

Steps not done in RSI:

  • Manual ventilation before intubation: Avoided as this inflates the stomach and causes regurgitation
  • Premedications: Not given as surgery is done immediately under emergency

RSI is avoided in patients with raised intracranial pressure as it worsens the condition.

questions.text: A chronic smoker presented with mild hemoptysis. He also gave a history of recent onset hypertension & weight gain. Lab data showed raised ACTH levels not suppressed by high dose dexamethasone. The most likely cause of Cushing's syndrome in the patient is?
questions.solution:
In the backdrop of chronic smoking and hemoptysis - a history of recent onset hypertension & weight gain, with a raised plasma ACTH level (which fails to be suppressed by high dose dexamethasone) - is strongly suggestive of Cushing's Syndrome caused by Paraneoplastic ectopic ACTH production associated with underlying bronchogenic carcinoma.

Ectopic ACTH syndrome:

  • It is a Paraneoplastic syndrome which accounts for around 20% of Cushing syndrome cases.
  • It is particularly seen with neuroendocrine tumors - Small Cell Lung Cancer (SCLC) being the most common cause, followed by carcinoid tumors (bronchial & thymic), islet cell tumors & pheochromocytomas.
  • In SCLC, mutated cells may cause increased & abnormal expression of the Pro-opiomelanocortin (POMC) gene leading to elevated production of POMC (ACTH precursor) resulting in elevated & aberrant ACTH production.
  • In SCLC associated ectopic ACTH Cushing syndrome, manifestations are predominantly - hypertension and weight gain caused by fluid retention (rather than fat deposition & redistribution - which is less due to cachexia), glucose intolerance, hypokalemia & metabolic alkalosis, and occasionally steroid psychosis. Pigmentation may be seen with very high ACTH levels due to elevated MSH (also POMC precursor).
  • The diagnosis is based on clinical features suggestive of Cushing's in a setting of an underlying malignancy & can be confirmed by demonstrating elevated (2- 4 times) plasma ACTH which fails to be suppressed by High-dose Dexamethasone (High-dose Dexamethasone suppresses plasma ACTH in Pituitary ACTH producing tumors i.e. 'Cushing's disease').

questions.solution:
Milestone shown in the image is a mature pincer grasp which is seen at the age of 12 months. At 12 months, a child should know 1-2 words with meaning.

questions.text: A patient who is a known case of alcoholic liver disease is being taken up for cholecystectomy. Which anesthetic agent would be ideal for this patient?
questions.solution:
The anesthetic agent that is ideal for a patient with liver disease is sevoflurane.

Sevoflurane is a fluorinated volatile anesthetic and is an ideal induction agent (has a rapid recovery profile and is not irritating to airways). 

The hepatic effects of volatile anesthetics are caused by alterations in liver perfusion. Hepatic arterial buffer response (HABR) is an autoregulatory mechanism of hepatic blood flow. When portal blood flow decreases due to decreased cardiac output or hypovolemia, the hepatic arterial blood flow increases in order to maintain total hepatic blood flow. This response is best preserved with sevoflurane and isoflurane. Thus, sevoflurane is not known to cause hepatotoxicity. 

Other options:

Option B: Halothane is a volatile anesthetic that has been used for maintenance but it can cause fulminant hepatic necrosis known as halothane hepatitis. 

Option C: Midazolam is an intravenous anesthetic. Its elimination is reduced in liver disease leading to an increased sedating effect.

Option D: Dexmedetomidine is also an intravenous anesthetic that has reduced elimination in patients with liver dysfunction.

 

Related Pearl: Inhalational anaesthetic agents

7. Neurosurgery    Sevoflurane>Isoflurane
8. Asthmatics Sevoflurane

questions.text: Which of the following disorders is not associated with chromosome 13?
questions.solution:
BRCA 1 gene mutation associated breast carcinoma maps to chromosome 17 while BRCA –2 mutation associated carcinoma breast maps to chromosome 13.

Retinoblastoma and osteosarcoma are chromosome 13 associated disorders. Patients with familial retinoblastoma are at increased risk for the development of osteosarcoma and other soft tissue tumors.

Wilson's disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutation of the ATP7B gene on Chromosome 13, which results in impaired copper excretion into bile and a failure to incorporate copper into ceruloplasmin.
