questions.text: Which of the following is false regarding the fracture shown in the image given below?

choices.text: Extension type is the most common type
Three point bony relationship is maintained
Malunion is the most common complication
Baumann’s angle is less than 80 degrees in this child

questions.solution:
The image shows an X-ray of supracondylar fracture of the humerus. Normal Baumann’s angle is <80 degrees. In a supracondylar fracture, the Baumann's angle is >80 degrees, it suggests a varus displacement.

A supra-condylar fracture can be flexion type or extension type based on the distal fragment’s displacement. In extension type, the distal fragment is displaced posteriorly and is the commoner of the two types.

Malunion leading to gunstock deformity (cubitus varus) is the most common complication.

Related Pearl: Three point bony relationship in elbow:

The three bony points in the elbow are :

  • Tip of the medial epicondyle
  • Tip of the lateral epicondyle
  • Olecranon

When the elbow is in 90 degrees of flexion, these points form an isosceles triangle. When the elbow is extended, they lie transversely in a straight line.

The three-point bony relationship is maintained in the case of supracondylar fracture of the humerus as the fracture occurs above the level of these bony landmarks.

Conditions where it is distorted:

  • Fracture medial condyle and epicondyle
  • Fracture lateral condyle and epicondyle
  • Intercondylar fracture of humerus
  • Fracture olecranon
  • Elbow dislocation

questions.text: All of the following are causes of permanent hardness of water except:

choices.text: Calcium and magnesium salts of Bicarbonates
Calcium and magnesium salts of Sulphates
Calcium and magnesium salts of Chlorides
Calcium and magnesium salts of Nitrates

questions.solution:
Calcium and magnesium bicarbonates are causes of temporary hardness of water.

  • Temporary hardness (carbonate hardness): due to presence of calcium and magnesium bicarbonates.
  • Permanent hardness (non-carbonate hardness): due to presence of calcium and magnesium sulphates, chlorides, nitrates.

Related Pearl: Hardness of Water

  • Hardness is the soap destroying power of water or the amount of dissolved calcium and magnesium in water.
  • It is most commonly caused by bicarbonates and sulphates of calcium and magnesium, but their nitrates and chlorides can also cause hardness.
  • Temporary (carbonate) hardness is due to bicarbonates of calcium and magnesium. 
  • Permanent (non-carbonate) hardness is due to sulphates, chlorides and nitrates.
  • 1 mEq/L of an ion that produces hardness is equal to 50 mg CaCO3 (50 ppm) in 1 litre of water.
Classification Level of hardness (mEq/l) Amount of ion producing hardness (mg/l)
Soft water Less than 1 Less than 50
Moderately hard 1 – 3 50 – 150
Hard water 3 – 6 150 – 300
Very hard water Over 6 More than 300
  • Drinking water must be moderately hard
  • Softening of water is recommended when the hardness exceeds 3 mEq/L (150 mg/litre)
  • Removal of hardness:
    • Boiling: 
      • This removes temporary hardness by expelling carbon dioxide and precipitating insoluble calcium carbonate. It would be expensive to do this on a large scale.
    • Addition of lime: 
      • This removes temporary hardness and also reduces magnesium. Lime absorbs carbon dioxide and precipitates insoluble calcium carbonate. In Clark’s method of softening water, lime is used.
    • Addition of sodium carbonate (soda ash): removes both temporary and permanent hardness.
    • Base exchange process:
      • This removes permanent and temporary hardness and can be used on a large scale. In this method, permutit is used. Sodium permutit is a complex compound of sodium, aluminium and silica. When hard water is passed through this permutit, the calcium and magnesium ions are removed by base exchange and is converted into calcium and magnesium permutit. This process reduces water to zero hardness, which is corrosive and thus it is then mixed with a part of raw water.

questions.text: A patient suffered from a myocardial infarction because of thrombosis of the coronary arteries. Which of the following factors most likely contributed to this pro-thrombotic state?
questions.solution:
ADP would have contributed to the pro-thrombotic state in this patient.

Following a traumatic vascular injury, the circulating platelets come in contact with the subendothelial connective tissue. Platelet adhesion is mediated by GpIb glycoprotein receptor present on the platelets and the von Willebrand factor (vWF) present on the exposed tissue below the vascular endothelium. Following this, the platelets rapidly change shape and release granule contents. This is known as platelet activation. ADP, which is present in dense granules, causes the activation of more platelets by binding to P2Y12 receptor. This phenomenon is called recruitment. The next step is platelet aggregation. GpIIb/IIIa undergoes a conformational change during platelet activation and allows binding to fibrinogen, leading to their aggregation. 

Local activation of the coagulation cascade occurs following the formation of the platelet plug. This leads to fibrin polymerization and cementing of the platelets into the definitive secondary hemostatic plug. However, there are certain counter-regulatory mechanisms that keep the process of coagulation limited to the site of the injury. This includes fibrinolysis, which is mediated by plasmin. Fibrin is broken down during this process and its further polymerization is stopped. Plasmin is generated by the catabolism of the precursor plasminogen by circulating plasminogen activators, such as t-PA (option A). Furthermore, thrombomodulin (option B) binds to thrombin and converts it into an anti-coagulant. Prostacyclin (option D) is PGI2. It is produced by the intact endothelium and acts as a potent vasodilator and an inhibitor of platelet aggregation.

questions.text: Drug of choice for actinomycosis is:
questions.solution:
Penicillin G is the agent of choice for the treatment of all forms of actinomycosis.

The dose should be 18-24 million units of penicillin G intravenously per day for 6 weeks. Some physicians continue therapy for 2-3 months with oral penicillin V (500 mg four times daily). Surgical drainage or excision of the lesion may be necessary before a cure is accomplished.

Alternatively, treatment can also be done with tetracyclines.

questions.text: Given below is ventriculography showing cardiac morphology in systole of a 65-year-old lady. Which of the following statements is false regarding the condition?

choices.text: Myocardial stunning pattern does not match ECG
Histologically acute cases may show contraction band necrosis
Left ventricular apex is most commonly affected
ECG abnormalities don't include ST-segment elevation

questions.solution:
The image shows global ventricular dilation with basal contraction in a 65-year-old lady, which is strongly suggestive of Takotsubo cardiomyopathy.  ECG abnormalities including ST-segment elevation and elevated biomarkers of myocardial injury can be seen because Takotsubo mimics acute MI. 

Takotsubo Cardiomyopathy (Broken heart syndrome / Apical ballooning syndrome / Stress-induced cardiomyopathy)

  • It is a type of ischemic dilated cardiomyopathy caused due to elevated levels of catecholamines.
  • Also called broken heart syndrome due to its association with emotional duress.
  • The ventricle shows global ventricular dilation with basal contraction, forming the shape of the narrow-necked jar (takotsubo).
  • It is most common in postmenopausal women after sudden intense emotional or physical stress presenting as pulmonary edema, hypotension and chest pain.
  • Myocardial Stunning is a state where certain segments of the myocardium (corresponding to the area of major coronary occlusion) show forms of contractile abnormality. In takotsubo cardiomyopathy, while the ECG changes mimic a myocardial infarction, the left ventricular dysfunction extends well beyond the distribution of a specific coronary artery. Thus, the myocardial stunning pattern might not fully match the ECG.
  • Coronary angiography may be needed to rule out acute coronary occlusion.
  • Histologically acute cases may show microscopic areas of necrosis characterized by myocyte hypercontraction known as contraction band necrosis.
  • Subacute and chronic cases may show microscopic foci of granulation tissue and/or scar.
  • Treatment: No treatment has been proven beneficial. However, the following measures can be taken:
    • Nitrates for pulmonary edema
    • Intraaortic balloon pump for low output
    • Combined alpha+beta blockers if hemodynamically stable
    • Magnesium for arrhythmias related to QT prolongation

Ventriculography showing cardiac morphology in systole in a patient with takotsubo cardiomyopathy - global ventricular dilation with basal contraction. A takotsubo – a pot (tsubo) for catching an octopus (tako).

questions.text: Lacosamide acts by __________

choices.text: Enhancing fast inactivation of Na+ channels
Enhancing slow inactivation of Na+ channels
Enhancing fast inactivation of Ca2+ channels
Enhancing slow inactivation of Ca2+ channels

questions.solution:
Lacosamide enhances slow inactivation of voltage-gated Na+ channels and limits sustained repetitive firing.

Lacosamide is a functionalized amino acid that was approved by the FDA as adjunctive therapy for focal-onset seizures in patients older than 17 years of age. An injectable formulation is available for short term use when oral administration is not feasible.

questions.text: A young girl presents with continuous dribbling of urine but she voids normally. Her parents tell you that she had never been totally dry since her birth. Identify the correct statement about her condition.

choices.text: Drains upper pole of kidney and opens above the sphincter of urethra
Drains lower pole of kidney and opens below the sphincter into urethra
Drains upper pole of kidney and opens below the sphincter into urethra
Drains lower pole of kidney and opens above the sphincter into urethra

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario with continuous dribbling of urine, in spite of regular voiding, is suggestive of an ectopic ureter. The ectopic ureter drains the upper pole of the kidney and opens into the urethra below the sphincter. 

Ectopic ureter is a congenital anomaly that occurs as a result of abnormal caudal migration of the ureteral bud during its insertion into the urinary bladder. They are usually associated with duplex ureters and drain from the upper pole of the kidney.

It is more common in females. The ectopic ureter usually opens into the urethra below the sphincter, vagina, and perineum. Hence, female patients present with constant urinary dripping all day, even though the child voids regularly (Paradoxical incontinence). It can cause hydroureteronephrosis and recurrent UTI.

In males, the ectopic ureter opens always above the external urethral sphincter.  Hence they are usually continent. However, it can cause other complications such as orchitis and epididymitis.

Management involves re-implantation of the ureter into the bladder to treat incontinence and preserve renal functions. If the kidney is severely affected, partial nephrectomy is helpful.

questions.text: Which of the following is not correctly paired?

choices.text: Nerve growth factor - Orthograde axonal transport

questions.solution:
Nerve growth factor have retrograde axonal transport (from axon terminal to soma).

Orthodromic and Antidromic conduction:

  • An axon can conduct in either direction.
  • Conduction of impulse away from soma towards axon terminals is called orthodromic while conduction of impulse away from axon terminals towards soma is called antidromic.
  • Because synapses, unlike axons, permit conduction in one direction only, an antidromic impulse will fail to pass the first synapse they encounter and die out at that point.

Other options:

Orthograde axonal transport occurs along microtubules that run along the length of the axon and requires two molecular motors, dynein and kinesin.

Orthograde transport moves from the cell body toward the axon terminals.

It has both fast and slow components, fast axonal transport occurs at about 400 mm/day, and slow axonal transport occurs at 0.5 to 10 mm/day.

Retrograde transport, which is in the opposite direction (from the nerve ending to the cell body), occurs along microtubules at about 200 mm/day.
